story:
"Project: Unity" A Bullying Prevention Program by The Runway to Hope Foundation.

Bullying has become one of our world's leading social issues, leaving countless teens turning to suicide as an irreversible conclusion to the life they have been told wasn't good enough.  According to statistics taken in 2010, around 71% of the student population report being bullied on a consistent basis. This number can only be stated as unmentionable in today's world because over 2/3 of those students feel the school systems are NOT responding properly.  

How have we, as advanced as our world has become, subjecting our children to such hate, anger, and worthlessness when not a single one of us is better than the next?  Why are we continuously advocating our educational standards towards higher learning, when we can't even allow the next generation to feel as though their true talents are good enough to apply to the real world?  What has brought us to think that any one of us have been given the right to repress the natural well-being and happiness of any other being?

To the people of our world: It's been long enough. It is time to finally put an END to bullying in every single way. Due to the unfortunate use of technology, it has made it much easier for students to bully each other because words in text are utilized more than words in voice. Besides that, the measures taken by our school districts focus on the differences between our students, rather than creating a medium channel of equality. There are many programs and "laws" within our states that take the exact same approach to bullying as what was seen decades ago, and they are obviously not producing ANY sort of positive outlook or change. Anyone can state that there is growth happening on the field of bullying, but when even as recent as last week, a 12 year old girl threw herself off of a building to her death because of it, I would like to aggressively disagree with any and ALL of our educational institutions standpoint. 

So please, we are begging you: Read forward to see exactly how we can finally bring this global pandemic of inequality to it's necessary demise. 

The Runway to Hope Foundation is a non-profit company based out of the North East United States. We are a group of individuals that have realized the world that society has created for our new generation is not aimed towards peace or individual self-worth. Therefore, in order to start moving in the right direction, we have begun to introduce our new bullying prevention program, Project: Unity. I say bullying PREVENTION instead of Anti-Bullying because it's time to put an end to the hate before it even begins.

The overall goals and mission behind Project: Unity are to foster the TRUE individuality of each and every student, because is it not psychologically proven to think that if each person could love themselves, they could love each other? Wouldn't it be right to say that if each person was given the opportunity to excel and embrace their own unique traits, we could all co-create peace within the school environments?

Project: Unity takes an innovative look at bullying by beginning to unify school atmospheres through creativity, music, individualized skills, and a universal philosophy of positive self-esteem. Not only does the program offer the necessary mediation services, documentation, and reporting of bullying situations that are required by the state, but we have also developed various programs that will allow our students to embrace the life they were born to live. We also aim to offer FREE outlets of psychological support through Music Therapy, Art Therapy, Chromotherapy, Heliotherapy, Animal Therapy, Group Physical Activity (Hula Hooping, Dance, etc.), and Self-Motivational Exercises.

Please visit: www.HateIsUgly.com to learn more about The Runway to Hope Foundation and our "Project: Unity" bullying prevention program. It lists the various programs and services that can be enacted IF we all stand together to bring the change we NEED for our children.   

Due to the fact that our school districts are low on budgeting and funds, it is imperative to come together as communities of the world so that we may offer these extremely necessary programs to our students. We are looking for ANY donation or contribution that can assist us in the end result of peace. As of now, we are based in Buffalo, NY which is where we will begin implementing "Project: Unity" by February 2014 to gain the statistics we need in order to receive the national support that can finally make a difference. 

Please "Like" us on Facebook: The Runway to Hope Foundation

Or "Follow" us on Twitter: @HateIsUgly, #ProjectUnity

If you are a victim or bully that wants to share your story, please write us at: info@hateisugly.com

story:
Our Story

Hereditary Breast and Ovarian Cancer Risk - It's Not All About BRCA1 and BRCA2

Each year, tens of thousands of women are genetically tested for mutations in two Hereditary Breast and Ovarian Cancer genes, called BRCA1 and BRCA2.  When present, a mutation in one of these genes can dramatically increase the lifetime risk of breast and ovarian cancer.  Most often, these women end up pursuing genetic testing because of a personal and/or family history of breast or ovarian cancer.

For women from families in which one or more people are known to have a mutation, the genetic test can clarify whether they did not inherit the known mutation in the family (and therefore have cancer risks typical for the general population) or did inherit the known familial mutation (which can allow them to make proactive decisions about managing and reducing their cancer risk).

Overall, about 80 to 90 percent of women who are tested for mutations in the BRCA1 and BRCA2 genes do not have a mutation.
 
Lost in the focus on women and families with mutations are the tens of thousands of women (hundreds of thousands?) with a substantial personal/family history of breast and/or ovarian cancer where genetic testing has not revealed a BRCA1 or BRCA2 mutation explaining the clustering of cancer in the family.

These "BRCA Negative" women and families are the focus of this campaign.

I know from experience - both in the clinic and interactions online - that a significant number of these women and families continue to actively search for an explanation for what can be a substantial history of cancer in their families.  In many cases, we may never know; however, for a subset of these women, the last 15 years of cancer genetics research have yielded other genes that may be relevant to their families.


Our Knowledge of Other Genes Involved in Hereditary Breast and/or Ovarian Cancer Risk is Growing Every Year
 
Over the last two decades, steady research progress has led to the identification of a growing list of genes that can be responsible for breast or ovarian cancer risk within a family.  Most are uncommon, but they have the potential to be very meaningful for the subset of BRCA Negative families that they impact. 
 
For some of these risk genes (for example: TP53, PTEN, MLH1, MSH2, MSH6, CDH1, STK11, and others), there are certain personal/family history clues that may suggest that they could be relevant to a particular family.  For others (RAD51C and RAD51D, for example), family histories in families with mutations are generally similar to those considered for testing for BRCA1 and BRCA2 mutations.
 
Marked Improvements in "Next-Generation Sequencing" Technology are Leading to a New Generation of Genetic Tests for Cancer Risk that Can Assess 10-20 Genes Simultaneously in a Much More Cost-Effective Manner
 
Impressive new sequencing technologies are beginning to be deployed in clinical diagnostics laboratories.  They have the potential to change both the logistics and economics of testing for mutations in multiple cancer risk genes simultaneously.  Thus, it will be increasingly feasible to test appropriate individuals from BRCA negative families with substantial breast or ovarian cancer histories for mutations in other cancer risk genes (even if the chance of a mutation in each of those genes ranges from just a few percent to a fraction of a percent).
 
 
Why I Decided to Create The BRCA Negative Book - a Guide to New Information Relevant to BRCA Negative Women and Families
 
As a clinical cancer geneticist with board certification in both Clinical Genetics and Internal Medicine, my career has been focused on studying, understanding, assessing, and communicating information about inherited cancer risk - both in the clinic and via online educational efforts.
 
Since 2007, I've focused increasingly on using the internet as a tool to communicate information.  This has included:
 
  • Writing online about the genetics of cancer risk at CancerAndYourGenes.com since 2007
  • Founding Evinome to educate and spread important information related to inherited cancer risk and cancer genetics to people regardless of geography or ability to pay for healthcare in the physical world
  • Launching BRCAscoop.com in 2011 to provide high quality health information and education to the hundreds of thousands (and millions worldwide) of women and men with BRCA1 and BRCA2 mutations
  • Developing CancerGeneticsPro - a useful curated newsletter source of state-of-the-art clinical cancer genetics information for both physicians without genetics training who order genetic testing in their practices and genetic counselors
Over the last few years, it has become clear that a convergence of several trends underscores the need for this book:
 
  1. BRCA1 and BRCA2 testing is fairly widespread in the developed world.  Regardless of geography or access to genetics professionals, patients are being getting tested...and in most cases, the answer is that a mutation does not appear to be causing breast/ovarian cancer risk in their family.
  2. There is a broad trend towards individuals taking increasing responsibility in their own care by accessing high quality information resources (online resources, books, etc.)
  3. There is a growing list of genes that explain risk in a subset (small but growing) of BRCA Negative families. 
  4. The proliferation of new sequencing technologies in clinical labs is already beginning to make it more feasible to sequence most or all of these genes in appropriately selected families.

The BRCA Negative Book will detail, in lay terms, the following: (1) The key family history clues that may point to other genetic syndromes involving breast or ovarian cancer risk; (2) The sequencing technology advances that will increasingly open up other testing options for BRCA Negative families with a substantial family history of breast and/or ovarian cancer; (3) A realistic view of the likelihood of further testing making a difference for ones family; and (4) Concrete useful suggestions for getting further information.

If you come from a BRCA Negative family, consider preordering the book, or even better, helping us create the best book possible by becoming a co-contributor!

About the Author - Matt Mealiffe, M.D.

Dr. Mealiffe is a Clinical Cancer Geneticist and social entrepreneur with dual board certification in Internal Medicine and Clinical Genetics.  He received his undergraduate degree at Stanford University and his M.D. at the Yale University School of Medicine.  Subsequently, he did his postgraduate clinical training in Internal Medicine and in Clinical Genetics at the University of Washington.  Following several years at the University of Washington as an attending physician and junior faculty member, he left for a clinical research position in industry, but shortly thereafter, founded Evinome which aims to use the power of the internet to support people with may have inherited risk for serious, adult-onset diseases with high quality, expert-vetted information and education relevant to their health and wellness.

 

What We Need & What You Get

What We Need

It's pretty simple.  Our online education and information efforts - including BRCAscoop.com, BRCAnegative.com and CancerAndYourGenes.com - are bootstrapped and growing significantly, but the revenue (after taking out the significant chunk that we donate to nonprofits from products like The BRCAscoop 2011 Research Report) is nothing to write home about.  There is a crystal clear need for The BRCA Negative Book, and your support can help us focus on getting it out there as soon as possible!

What You Get

A contribution to this effort can help in a multitude of ways:

  1. It will help support the effort of getting the book out there for all of the women and families who need it.
  2. It will help us stay connected to all of the women, men, and families interested in the book during the writing process.
  3. You can proudly register your support.
  4. You can also access some great unique perks during the book creation process that can add extra educational value.

Here are a few unique perks that I'd like to highlight:

1. In Remembrance is a great way to honor the memory of a loved one and help support efforts to spread the word about inherited risk for breast/ovarian cancer.

2. We are really excited about experimenting with crowdsourced feedback and editorial comments on early chapter and book drafts.  If this is something you'd be interested in and you'd like to have access to chapter and book drafts before it is published, the Be a Co-Contributor perk may be of interest to you.

3. I believe Get Educated is likely to be the best value of all the perks for BRCA Negative individuals interested in more education about non-BRCA1/BRCA2 gene-related inherited cancer risks and genetics.  It couples the "Be a Co-Contributor" perk with exclusive access to a new series of online educational videos for BRCA Negative women and families.

Other Ways You Can Help

Regardless of whether you are able to purchase a book or one of the other options, you can make a HUGE, HUGE contribution by helping to spread the word. 

Whether you prefer email or have a particular favorite flavor of social media like Facebook or Twitter, we would be tremendously grateful if you can help us to spread the word about the book!

story:
First of all, I would like to thank you for your time and support while visiting my campaing.

My name is Eduardo and little bit about me is that I was born in Honduras from an American veteran father and a Hispanic mother. I came to America 11 years ago without speaking any English; I have learned the language and now achieving my bachelor’s degree in CJ. It has been a long journal, working and studying full-time at the same time make things more difficult but not impossible!!

Now, my graduation ceremony will be in December and I am very excited about it. I am proud of myself for achieving this goal in my life.

As reward, I would like to go visit Europe (Spain, France & Italy) but I need your support to make this dream come true.

I know there are many others out there who have been in my position at one point in their lives and understand what I am feeling right now, please help me make my dream come true.

Please support my campaign!!

Regards,

Ed

story:
One of the most common reactions parents and other adults have when they visit an Earth Explorers classroom is, "Wow! I wish I had this program when I was in middle school!" Scroll along to learn how Earth Explorers is bringing its innovative program to students on the Front Range of Colorado. 

Our program and passion:

The mission of Earth Explorers is to open doors to science and engineering careers by educating and mentoring underrepresented youth. We define underrepresented as girls, minorities, students living in poverty, students who will be among the first generation in their families to attend college, and people with disabilities. We use video and new media technology to connect young people to science and engineering professionals in their communities, and to deepen networks of resources that will help our students succeed beyond the classroom.

To achieve maximum impact, Earth Explorers focuses on creating positive connections between young people and scientists. Students work together in carefully diversified groups of four, and each team is paired with an enthusiastic scientist or engineer. Teams meet with their scientists several times on filming trips to national and commercial labs; over the course of an average semester, each team spends 10 hours working directly with their scientist and 30 hours interacting with an energetic graduate-student mentor. EE students learn basic research skills, storytelling, interviewing, and videography. Teams participate in after-school and weekend workshops where they produce 8-10 minute videos about their scientists, and those videos are presented at a fancy red-carpet film premiere for the students, their families, scientists, and the community.

We live to witness 'ah-ha!' moments inside and outside of the classroom, and our primary goal is to introduce young people to the possibility that they can become science professionals. One such 'ah-ha!' moment happened last fall in a sixth grade classroom: A group of scientists shared their struggles to succeed, and one of our scientists revealed he didn't do very well in school until he made it to college and discovered genetics research. Almost instantly, a boy in the class raised his hand high and asked, "Does that mean I can be a scientist too?!" Many of our students live in unstable homes without access to computers and other technology. Outside of experiences in school, these young people rarely encounter adults who have a college education, and they are even less likely to know a working scientist or engineer. Earth Explorers connects students to scientists who bridge that social gap. Students who participate in Earth Explorers are given opportunities to broaden the scope of their learning and to see themselves in careers and roles they never thought they could achieve. 

Our campaign:

Over the past three school years, Earth Explorers has grown organically from an after-school enrichment program for 7th and 8th graders to a full middle school curriculum. During the 2012-2013 school year, more than 250 students participated in 6th, 7th and 8th grade Earth Explorers courses. 

The demand for Earth Explorers to expand to additional schools is high! Interested schools are now approaching us, and we are almost ready to accept applications to add a new school in the fall. This campaign aims to raise the $14,000 necessary to offer Earth Explorers programming at one additional Boulder County middle school and reach a new group of young people. 

Community Impact:

STEM education is a hot topic in in the media, drawing strong praise from entrepreneurs and policy-makers alike. Concensus is forming in the United States about the urgent need to give science and math education a boost. According to research from the National Science Foundation, a disproportionately small number of underrepresented students enter science and engineering careers in the United States. For students from middle-income families, college is usually a given. Unfortunately, minorities, women, and lower-income students often think a college degree and a professional life in the sciences is 'something for other people.' While unemployment rose nationally above ten percent a few years ago, unemployment in science and engineering careers remained below five percent. The successes of this program and others like it mean more middle-income families living stable, comfortable lives and contributing to the collective economic and intellectual prosperity of America.

Final thoughts:

Earth Explorers is a Boulder-based nonprofit corporation with 501(c)(3) approval. We incorporated as a nonprofit in 2011 to support and enhance our rapidly growing program and to take our work to schools throughout Boulder County, Colorado, and eventually, the country.

Please consider supporting the work we do at Earth Explorers with a monetary contribution, and use Indiegogo's sharing tools to link our page with other social networks. Take a look at our website (earthexplorers.org), get involved on our facebook page (facebook.com/EarthExplorersTM), and watch our students' movies on Vimeo (vimeo.com/earthexplorers).

Over the past three school years, Earth Explorers has grown organically from an after-school enrichment program for 7th and 8th graders to a full middle school curriculum. During the 2012-2013 school year, more than 250 students participated in 6th, 7th and 8th grade Earth Explorers courses. 
The demand for Earth Explorers to expand to additional schools is high! Interested schools are now approaching us, and we are almost ready to accept applications to add a new school in the fall. This campaign aims to raise the $14,000 necessary to offer Earth Explorers programming at one additional Boulder County middle school and reach a new group of young people. 
Community Impact:
STEM education is a hot topic in in the media, drawing strong praise from entrepreneurs and policy-makers alike. Concensus is forming in the United States about the urgent need to give science and math education a boost. According to research from the National Science Foundation, a disproportionately small number of underrepresented students enter science and engineering careers in the United States. For students from middle-income families, college is usually a given. Unfortunately, minorities, women, and lower-income students often think a college degree and a professional life in the sciences is 'something for other people.' While unemployment rose nationally above ten percent a few years ago, unemployment in science and engineering careers remained below five percent. The successes of this program and others like it mean more middle-income families living stable, comfortable lives and contributing to the collective economic and intellectual prosperity of America.
Final thoughts:
Earth Explorers is a Boulder-based nonprofit corporation with 501(c)(3) approval. We incorporated as a nonprofit in 2011 to support and enhance our rapidly growing program and to take our work to schools throughout Boulder County, Colorado, and eventually, the country.
Please consider supporting the work we do at Earth Explorers with a monetary contribution, and use Indiegogo's sharing tools to link our page with other social networks. Take a look at our website (earthexplorers.org), get involved on our facebook page (facebook.com/EarthExplorersTM), and watch our students' movies on Vimeo (vimeo.com/earthexplorers).

story:
The 2013 HELP International Uganda team, comprised of 23 volunteers, is currently serving in Mbale, Uganda working in schools, health clinics, women's support groups, business organizations, and providing education on health, hygiene and sanitation in local schools. We are currently working closely with two schools in rural villages outside of Mbale that both need extra help to achieve their full potential. The administrators of these schools are very passionate individuals, and we have been so impressed by them and really believe in the work they are doing.

 

Pathways Development Initiative Nursery School (PDI)

PDI is a community-based NGO that was founded by David and Elizabeth Zaale in the Bududa district of Uganda. The Zaales have developed several different programs to help improve the lives of the people in their community, one of which is a nursery school that focuses on giving children a head start in their English skills. The Bududa area is known for its lacking education system and the Zaales are trying to address the problem early by starting with the youngest in the community. They also have plans for an after school program to help the older children already in school with their English skills.

PDI was making great strides in improving education until this May when the two-room school building that the nursery school classes were being held in, was taken back by the landlord, torn down, and turned into a new secondary school. Because of this, the Zaales were forced to move the nursery school classes into their own home and put the plans for the after school program on hold. Their home does not have adequate space for all of the children, and having them there every day has become a huge burden on the family.

Fortunately, before the old school was torn down, PDI had already purchased land and started construction on a new, bigger school building down the road. Initially, the school was being built a little at a time as the funds became available, but with the recent turn of events this is no longer an option. Getting this new school done has become a major priority for the Zaales, and we have the opportunity to help this community in a big way!

PDI desperately needs to get the new school done, but they do not have the funds they need to do so. Our team wants to help provide PDI with the funds, materials, and labor that they need to finish the school before the end of the summer. Unfortunately, we don't have the money within our project funds to accomplish this ourselves. This is why we need YOUR help!

Construction of the PDI nursery school will be our team's first priority with the funds we are able to raise. If enough funds are raised, we may be able to provide the school with features that we would consider additional options to the essential materials needed for construction.

Essential Materials:

-Roof: $434

-Floor: $366

-Walls: $50

-Shutters and Doors: $100

-Transportation of materials: $90

-Total: $1,040

 

Optional Materials:

-Plaster for walls: $135

-Paint: $172

-Clean Water System: $180

-Outdoor Sign: $40

-Total: $527

 

 Liahona Education Center

The Liahona Education Center was started by Stephen and Sarah Butali in a rural village near the Uganda-Kenya border. Their school has been very successful and has grown from just 20 students to almost 400 in just three years!

The Liahona Education Center has provided a huge service and blessed the lives of many children living in the surrounding community who otherwise would not receive an education. The growth that the school has seen has been incredible, but with so much growth, and limited funds, problems arise. One concern expressed by the Butalis is the school’s inadequate restroom facilities. Right now, the school has two pit latrines that are in bad shape and are quickly crumbling from termite damage. With the ideal ratio being 50 students per latrine, the school is obviously over capacity with only two latrines and 400 students.

Because we have been so impressed with the service the Butalis have given, and the work that they have put in to make their school so successful, our team wants to be able to give back to them. We have decided to help them raise the money necessary to build five new pit latrines – two for girls, two for boys, and one for staff. Latrines can be relatively expensive to construct and, once again, we don’t have the money within our budget to do it ourselves. In addition to the new latrines, we would love to provide this school with a water catchment system to more easily provide their students with clean water on a daily basis. If we are able to raise all of the funds that we are hoping to, we will easily be able to provide them with this water catchment system. We would love to be able to help the Butalis make their school an even better place for their students to learn.

Costs:

Building Materials: $1,894

Labor Costs: $240

Water Catchment System: $589

Total: $2,723

 

Thank you in advance for your generous donations and support in helping us to provide these schools with the things they need to continue to bless the lives of the children of Uganda.

story:
Short Summary

My possibility is that of being a bestselling romance novel author.  I have an internationally renowned publicist, Jill Lublin, representing my series of books at the end of May at the Book Expo of America in New York. When I receive my publishing deal, I plan to move powerfully forward with my own brand of travel romance novels. In order to have the proper structure of my bestselling business together, I need to raise the funds to be present at the Forbes must-attend conference for entrepreneurs, CEO Space, in May. Please support me in helping to fulfill on my possibility of telling love stories from around the world.

The Impact

"Our deepest fear is not that we are inadequate. Our deepest fear is that we are powerful beyond measure. It is our light, not our darkness that most frightens us. We ask ourselves, Who am I to be brilliant, gorgeous, talented, fabulous? Actually, who are you not to be? You are a child of God. Your playing small does not serve the world. There is nothing enlightened about shrinking so that other people won't feel insecure around you. We are all meant to shine, as children do. We were born to make manifest the glory of God that is within us. It's not just in some of us; it's in everyone. And as we let our own light shine, we unconsciously give other people permission to do the same. As we are liberated from our own fear, our presence automatically liberates others."

Please contribute to me so that I can do the work I love, be financially free, and more effectively allow others to let their lights shine..

Other Ways You Can Help

Even if you cannot help by contributing financially, please pass my campaign forward to others that will be able to assist me in reaching my goal. Thanks so much for your support!

story:
CALL TO ACTION:

Our non-profit organization, the Global Resiliency Initiative, provides positive educational training and materials to help change the lives of young girls living in extreme poverty around the globe.  

Donate now and help us launch our Kenya project to help educate over 100 girls living in one the largest slums in the world. We have partnered with a local school, Shining Hope, to provide a life changing positive psychology curriculum in Kiberia, Kenya where only 8% of girls ever have the chance to go to school.

Without access to education, most girls in Kibera struggle to make a living and often lead troubled lives.  In fact, 66% of girls in Kibera routinely trade sex for food by the age of 16 (many begin as early as age six).

Your contribution will provide a young girl access to our unique positive psychology curriculum that teaches them how to build resilience, hope and optimism. It encourages her to focus on her strengths and empowers her to stay in school.

You have the opportunity to give a young girl a better life by educating her.  You have a chance to help a young girl raise herself out of poverty.

    HOW YOUR FUNDS WILL BE INVESTED:

    Our fundraising goal is $4000.  All funds raised will be used to:

    • Provide positive psychology education to over 100 girls between the ages of 10 and 14;
    • Supply workbooks, teaching aids, learning tools and other resources to over 100 girls and a dozen teachers and social workers;
    • Train over a dozen teachers and social workers; and
    • Supplement travel expenses to send one or two GRI trainers to deliver the curriculum and report its results.

    OUR TEAM:

    The Global Resiliency Initiative was co-founded by Carl and Kathy (who are recently engaged).  Carl is a senior international attorney, policy advisor and diplomat who designs and implements international development programs for a leading US government agency.  He received his masters in applied positive psychology from the University of Pennsylvania while being mentored by the founder of positive psychology, Dr. Martin Seligman.  Kathy is a speech language pathologist for a reputable private practice in Washington, DC.  She has extensive experience working with children and with specialized educational programs.

    Thank you!

    -Carl and Kathy

story:
'A Place to Be': Make Friends, Have Fun, Be Yourself!

When 'A Place to Be' was launched nearly three years ago, my daughter, now 25, made me aware of a growing epidemic in our communities. Month after month for three years, I was hearing about youth in our communities in Essex County, Massachusetts, that were overdosing on drugs and committing suicide at an alarming rate. I knew that something was terribly wrong. It was then that I decided to launch GenYLife Design (pronounced 'Jen Why Life Design'), and become an advocate for at-risk youth in Generation Y. http://www.genylifedesign.com/about_us

Initially, I invested $10,000 of my own money, and also raised another $28,000 from a generous family member, and one patron who believed in me, and our cause. This was in February of 2010. Within two months of launch, our first program was funded by the Commonwealth of Massachusetts--a pre-vocational program co-sponsored by The Boys and Girls Clubs. Since then, we've grown our budget to $135,000 a year solely through state funding. This has has made it possible for us to provide year-round, out-of-school time programs to disadvantaged youth with social, emotional and behavioral issues, in several under-served communities in Massachusetts, including Lawrence, Haverhill, Gloucester and Salisbury.

Why we need your help. The Commonwealth of MA has been good to us, and helped get us launched. We're grateful! However, just recently, we learned that our prime funding source at the state level is changing how they fund their Youth Support Programs. This means, we can no longer afford to operate the quality of programming we've built our reputation on-- given the new rate and payment structure. In addition, the eligibility requirements for our kids to be funded by this state program are eliminating many deserving kids from the state's approved program roster--including some kids who we've served for over two years. What may appear to be a challenge to others is an opportunity in disguise to us! 

Our Mission and Programs

The focus of our programs is two-fold: First, we help our kids make friends, learn to socialize (without the use of electronics!), and navigate issues such as bullying and cyber-bullying before these incidences cause damage. Second, through one-on-one Personal Coaching/Mentoring, we guide our kids to discover what they're passionate about and do naturally and well. We call this their 'WOW Factor'. We then activate this life force in their communities as paid internships and jobs, micro-businesses, social ventures, or community outreach opportunities. This is the hallmark of what we do! Our uncommon approach builds confidence, self-esteem, and know-how! (See case studies below for examples.)http://www.genylifedesign.com/our_mission

Our programs have been hosted in well-respected youth and community organizations such as Salvation Army in Haverhill, the YMCA and Lawrence Community Connections in Lawrence, and Cape Ann Art Haven in Gloucester. As a Massachusetts small business, we've also created jobs for 15 staff employees, and contributed over $100,000 in payroll to talented folks who were previously unemployed, or underemployed. GenYLife Design received certification in 2011 as a Woman Owned Business Entreprise (WBE) with the Commonwealth of Massachusetts Office of Supplier Diversity. (See copy of certification in our gallery.)

We're Looking for 100 Angels Who Will Help 'A Place to Be' Empower Youth This Fall!

With your help, we can now offer our programs to ALL kids that fit our profile--regardless of their state eligibility. To do this, we need 100 Angels who will help us raise approximately $44,000 to keep our program going into 2013. That's 100 Angels (friends and family) referring the campaign to 10 prospective donors that make a contribution of $44 each. That's all we need to reach our goal....
 
This will provide a bridge of funding so our kids don't have a gap in programming this fall. It will also give us time to apply for other state funding and grants with our partner nonprofit, The Salvation Army.
 
With your generous support, our kids will continue to have 'A Place to Be' where they feel safe, loved, hopeful about the future, and appreciated for who they truly are--without labels or stigma from past incidences or behavior. Once the campaign has ended, The Salvation Army in Haverhill, MA, a non-profit, 501c(3) organization, will receive a donation from GenYLife Design to administer the funds raised, and support 'A Place to Be' programming. This means your donations are be tax deductible. 

Whether we reach our goal of $44,000 or not by October 8th (and we're confident we will), we'll offer our programs, regardless. We can do this on a less frequent basis if need be, with whatever funds we raise. With one afternoon a week of programming, we would collaborate with Valleyworks Career Center to help our kids, ages 16-18, gain the job skills they need to become employed, more independent young adults. Our younger youth would work one-on-one with a Personal Coach on an empowering, self esteem-building project to help them take their next steps. This is our commitment!

Real Case Studies of Kids We've Helped

We know you'll feel a lot more comfortable supporting 'A Place to Be' if you know how much we've helped! Here are a few of compelling case studies from our 2012 programs thus far. Also take a look at our gallery to see photos of our kids doing great work in the program.

Frances, Age 14, Found Her 'Voice'

Frances' letter to staff below says it all. Frances has been with 'A Place to Be' for two years, since she was 12 years old.

"To Barbara, Jane, Allison and Whitney:

Thank you gizes so much for making me belive in myself if you gizes werent never in my life wouldnt now what to do you gize always cared and care about me thank you gizes alot. I dont see you gizes as staffs in program im always ganna see you all as familyies i thank you gizes for everything and for changing me from getting bullyed to stand up for myself I love love love love you gizes so much.....never leave my side lotz of hugs Laugh out loud" From Frances T.

Olivia, Age 15, Emerging Artist

Olivia is a gifted artist, and knows what she wants. Working closely with her Personal Coach at 'A Place to Be,' Olivia created a portfolio of her pen and ink drawings, and targeted several galleries where she wanted to show her work. All three galleries accepted her work, including Cameleon in Newburyport, and The Sage Gallery and Artist's Cafe in Haverhill. Olivia has already sold four of her framed pieces just since the beginning of August! Her art career is launched! (See a photo of Olivia at her first art opening in August in our gallery.)

Shantay, Age 16, Legal Youth Advocate

Shantay joined 'A Place to Be' less than six months ago with a goal of working in the law. After spending more time with Shantay, we learned that she wanted to be a youth law advocate so that "kids like her didn't have to go through what she did in her life." For her project, Shantay working closely with her Personal Coach this summer to accomplish the following:

  • Researched how The Americans With Disabilities Act and other laws help teens and young adults make a transition to secondary education and into the workforce.
  • Wrote a summary paper about her research.
  • Drew a picture of a youth advocating for himself. (See gallery)
  • Met with The Essex County District Attorney's Office to learn about job opportunities as a youth law advocate.
  • (Still to be completed): Attend a day of adult court session with an attorney from the Assistant District Attorney's Office to learn more about how the court system works, and the role of a youth law advocate.

Chris, Age 18, 'Mr. Breezy', Budding DJ

Chris came to 'A Place to Be' reluctantly on the referral of his Case Manager. When Chris participated in a presentation by DJ Clyde of Encore DJ Services, he decided he wanted to become a DJ too. 'A Place to Be' told Chris that we were investing in him by hiring a professional DJ to help him. After several months of sessions with DJ Clyde, Chris earned his certificate at a DJ from the National Association of Mobile Entertainers. Chris had his DJ debut at the Salvation Army in Haverhill on March 3rd, 2012, and earned his first stipend as a paid DJ!

Elizabeth, Age 17, Shares Her Big Heart Through Community Service

Elizabeth, who has been with 'A Place to Be' since April, 2010, has a big heart, and a passion for helping older people. Knowing this, 'A Place to Be' staff created two opportunities for Liz to lead her peers in projects working with a local nursing home in Haverhill. In one project, Liz and Kids Cook, made appetizers and served them to the residents before dinner. During the second project, Liz and her Personal Coach organized an activity to make Easter cards for relatives and friends of the residents. One possible career path that these activities have opened for Liz is an internship now at the nursing home. We'll help Liz with this when the program continues...

Other Ways You Can Help

If you can't make a donation at this time, we understand. You can still become a campaign Angel and lend a hand!

Please get the word out to your family and friends, and all those who might be willing to donate to our program. Every amount is welcome and appreciated! Facebook, Twitter, and other social media that connects you to prospective donors will help our cause. You have my, and our kids' sincere thanks for being one of 100 Angels; we wouldn't be able to reach our goal without your help and support!

Finally, please remember that your donation is tax deductible.

Watch for updates, including video testimonials from our kids, coming soon.....

We can do this on a less frequent basis if need be, with whatever funds we raise. With one afternoon a week of programming, we would collaborate with Valleyworks Career Center to help our kids, ages 16-18, gain the job skills they need to become employed, more independent young adults. Our younger youth would work one-on-one with a Personal Coach on an empowering, self esteem-building project to help them take their next steps. This is our commitment!


Real Case Studies of Kids We've Helped
We know you'll feel a lot more comfortable supporting 'A Place to Be' if you know how much we've helped! Here are a few of compelling case studies from our 2012 programs thus far. Also take a look at our gallery to see photos of our kids doing great work in the program.Frances, Age 14, Found Her 'Voice'
Frances' letter to staff below says it all. Frances has been with 'A Place to Be' for two years, since she was 12 years old.
"To Barbara, Jane, Allison and Whitney:
Thank you gizes so much for making me belive in myself if you gizes werent never in my life wouldnt now what to do you gize always cared and care about me thank you gizes alot. I dont see you gizes as staffs in program im always ganna see you all as familyies i thank you gizes for everything and for changing me from getting bullyed to stand up for myself I love love love love you gizes so much.....never leave my side lotz of hugs Laugh out loud" From Frances T.
Olivia, Age 15, Emerging Artist
Olivia is a gifted artist, and knows what she wants. Working closely with her Personal Coach at 'A Place to Be,' Olivia created a portfolio of her pen and ink drawings, and targeted several galleries where she wanted to show her work. All three galleries accepted her work, including Cameleon in Newburyport, and The Sage Gallery and Artist's Cafe in Haverhill. Olivia has already sold four of her framed pieces just since the beginning of August! Her art career is launched! (See a photo of Olivia at her first art opening in August in our gallery.)
Shantay, Age 16, Legal Youth Advocate
Shantay joined 'A Place to Be' less than six months ago with a goal of working in the law. After spending more time with Shantay, we learned that she wanted to be a youth law advocate so that "kids like her didn't have to go through what she did in her life." For her project, Shantay working closely with her Personal Coach this summer to accomplish the following:

Researched how The Americans With Disabilities Act and other laws help teens and young adults make a transition to secondary education and into the workforce.
Wrote a summary paper about her research.
Drew a picture of a youth advocating for himself. (See gallery)
Met with The Essex County District Attorney's Office to learn about job opportunities as a youth law advocate.
(Still to be completed): Attend a day of adult court session with an attorney from the Assistant District Attorney's Office to learn more about how the court system works, and the role of a youth law advocate.

Chris, Age 18, 'Mr. Breezy', Budding DJ
Chris came to 'A Place to Be' reluctantly on the referral of his Case Manager. When Chris participated in a presentation by DJ Clyde of Encore DJ Services, he decided he wanted to become a DJ too. 'A Place to Be' told Chris that we were investing in him by hiring a professional DJ to help him. After several months of sessions with DJ Clyde, Chris earned his certificate at a DJ from the National Association of Mobile Entertainers. Chris had his DJ debut at the Salvation Army in Haverhill on March 3rd, 2012, and earned his first stipend as a paid DJ!
Elizabeth, Age 17, Shares Her Big Heart Through Community Service
Elizabeth, who has been with 'A Place to Be' since April, 2010, has a big heart, and a passion for helping older people. Knowing this, 'A Place to Be' staff created two opportunities for Liz to lead her peers in projects working with a local nursing home in Haverhill. In one project, Liz and Kids Cook, made appetizers and served them to the residents before dinner. During the second project, Liz and her Personal Coach organized an activity to make Easter cards for relatives and friends of the residents. One possible career path that these activities have opened for Liz is an internship now at the nursing home. We'll help Liz with this when the program continues...


Other Ways You Can Help
If you can't make a donation at this time, we understand. You can still become a campaign Angel and lend a hand!
Please get the word out to your family and friends, and all those who might be willing to donate to our program. Every amount is welcome and appreciated! Facebook, Twitter, and other social media that connects you to prospective donors will help our cause. You have my, and our kids' sincere thanks for being one of 100 Angels; we wouldn't be able to reach our goal without your help and support!
Finally, please remember that your donation is tax deductible.
Watch for updates, including video testimonials from our kids, coming soon.....

story:
Help Tibetan Monks Rebuild Facilities and Preserve their Culture for Years to Come


Eight monks from the historic Gaden Shartse Dokhang Monastery are touring the U.S. with the blessing of His Holiness the 14th Dalai Lama. They are here to share their culture, philosophy, and arts, and to raise awareness about the need for funds to build dorms and a prayer hall at their monastery in Southern India.

The Compassion Tour brings the monks to towns and cities throughout the United States where they offer teachings, cultural performances, cultural exchanges, chanting concerts, private consultations, and Tibetan arts demonstrations such as the building of sand mandalas. The tour is a low-budget, grass roots effort financed entirely by donations and volunteers.

The immediate goal of this Indiegogo Campaign is $30,000, the cost of putting the monks on the road. These expenses cover some, though not all of these costs, including a van, gas, driver, hotels, etc. All funds raised through this campaign will go towards the expenses of the tour, which is in excess of $100,000.

By contributing to this campaign, you will help the monks raise awareness about their need for funds to rebuild their facilities at their monastery. There hope is to build a prayer hall, dormitories and medical facilities.


On the Road


So far, the tour has crossed the country and made appearances at many schools and colleges, including MIT, Rutgers, the University of Oklahoma, and Stetson University. We delayed launching this campaign in order for the monks to meet people who would help us get the word out about the tour and our Indiegogo Campaign.

The Compassion Tour is supported by The Foundation of the Sacred Stream, a school for consciousness studies in Berkeley, CA. The primary liaison for the tour is Geshe Thupten Jinpa, PhD, the principal English interpreter for His Holiness the Dalai Lama, Chairman of Mind and Life Institute, and former member of Gaden Shartse Dokhang Monastery.


Rebuilding Gaden Shartse Dokhang Monastery


Recently, building started on the first portion of dorms thanks to a loan they are diligently working to repay. This December, H.H. the 14th Dalai Lama blessed the site with a ribbon cutting during the Lam Rim teachings at the monastery in Karnataka.

To rebuild Gaden Shartse Dokhang, it will take 1.2 million dollars. This will provide living space for up to 400 monks, a prayer hall, library, and medical facilities. The initial goal is to raise $300,000 to build the first portion of dorms so that the monks can return to the monastery and resume living and practicing together. Currently, they are homeless and spread throughout the Tibetan settlement in Mundgod, India.


More Ways You Can Help


The costs of running a tour in the U.S. are great. The tour expenses include plane fare from India for the monks, a van, driver, and other logistical expenses, as well as the cost of providing for the basic daily needs of monks (food, lodging, gas, etc). Actual tour expenses will be in excess of $100,000. For a tour of this magnitude to be successful, we rely on the generosity of many people – fiscal donors, volunteers (who promote the events, provide meals, etc), hosts (who provide lodging and manage the events in their town or region), and venues (that provide space for the monks’ events). For more information on how you can help support the Compassion Tour, visit our website at tibetanmonktour.org or email us directly at info@tibetanmonktour.org.


More About Geshe Thupten Jinpa, Ph.D.


Geshe Thupten Jinpa, Ph.D., was born in Tibet in 1958, and received his early education and training as a monk at Zongkar Chöde Monastery in South India. He received the Geshe Lharam degree from Shartse College of Ganden Monastic University, and holds B.A. Honors in Western Philosophy and a Ph.D. in Religious Studies, both from Cambridge University, UK.

He has been the principal English translator to H.H. the Dalai Lama since 1985, and has translated and edited more than 10 books by the Dalai Lama, including the New York Times bestseller, Ethics for the New Millennium. His own works include numerous contributions to various collections and academic journals and several works in the Tibetan language.

He is the president of the Institute of Tibetan Classics in Montréal, Canada, and the editor-in-chief of the translation project The Library of Tibetan Classics. He is on the advisory board of various educational and cultural organizations including, the Mind and Life Institute (USA), The Orient Foundation (UK & India), The Meridien Trust (UK), and Global Ethics and Religion (USA). He is also a Visiting Research Scholar at the Stanford Institute for Neuro-Innovation and Translational Neurosciences at Stanford University.


Video Transcript


Eight monks from the Gaden Shartse Dokhang Monastery are coming to the U.S. with the blessing of His Holiness the 14th Dalai Lama to share their culture and paths to inner peace and compassion. The purpose of the tour is to raise funds for their monastery to build dormitories, a prayer hall and to support the educational and medical needs of the monks.

Gaden Monastery is one of the three most renowned monasteries of Tibet. Originally founded in Tibet in 1409 by Tsongkhapa, Gaden is where the Gelugpa School of Tibetan Buddhism emerged.

After the invasion and subsequent occupation of Tibet by the People's Liberation Army of China, in the 1950s, the monastery was rebuilt from scratch by a few exiled monks in Southern India. Today it is home to over 1200 monks, scholars and students and it has produced many significant teachers in the tradition, including Geshe Thupten Jinpa, PhD, the primary English interpreter for His Holiness the 14th Dalai Lama.

"This is a community that is so important historically as part of Ganden Monastery and lately the community has gone through a very difficult time. And the community needs to be rebuilt and the continued presence of this community in Ganden is very important.

The Foundation of the Sacred Stream is a non-profit organization in Berkeley, CA, and is host of the tour and will be providing ongoing support and assistance to the monks throughout their time in the U.S.

By contributing to this campaign, you will literally put the monks on the road. Contributions will help pay for a van and travel expenses for the eight monks and their assistant. Your contributions will also help with the building of much needed facilities at the monastery in Southern India. And most importantly, you will be directly helping the monks preserve and share their beautiful traditions. We have some very special gifts for you as part of this campaign and if you would like the monks to come to your town for a dharma talk, cultural performance, chanting concert or to build a sand mandala all you have to do is let us know.


Thank You for Your Support!

story:
Who We Are  

Hi, my name is Sarah Parkes and I am the Program Director for the San Joaquin River Parkway and Conservation Trust, Inc (the Trust). We are a 501 (c)3 non-profit land trust working to protect open space and share the wonders of the San Joaquin River with people throughout the San Joaquin River Valley. For more information about our organization visit www.riverparkway.org. 

One of our most popular community programs is River Camp. Every summer over 1,000 children from the community of Fresno spend a week by the San Joaquin River learning about the local wildlife, playing, swimming, and having fun in the outdoors. Two years ago we expanded the River Camp program to the rural community of Firebaugh. 

The River Camp Firebaugh Story  

In 2012 the community of Firebaugh welcomed the Trust with open arms and helped us launch a grant-funded pilot program of River Camp. During that first summer we offered two weeks of camp and served 100 kids from Firebaugh, Mendota, and Madera. The program was accepted widely, so much so, that we ended up with a waitlist for both weeks. 

The community of Firebaugh expressed a great desire to have the program offered again during the summer of 2013. Again with grant funding, the Trust expanded the program from two weeks to four weeks and doubled the number of children served. 

We are already receiving requests from families in Firebaugh and Mendota to sign their kids up for River Camp Firebaugh 2014. Without a grant this year, we've been working hard to raise the funds needed to make the program possible...

But we need YOUR help! It takes a community to make programs like this happen. We've been working with businesses and donors, and we've developed a partnership with West Hills Community College with the goal of making River Camp Firebaugh sustainable in the future. 

Your donation today will mean we can reach our goal of bringing 200 kids to camp this summer. 

This is my friend Omar. He's been coming to camp for two years now. Last year, he taught me everything he knows about pirates. River Camp is his favorite thing about the summer. 

What We Need & What You Get

Our goal for this campaign is $8250, and if we reach that goal we'll be able to provide scholarships for 55 children to join the fun at River Camp Firebaugh. 

  • It costs $150 per child for River Camp Firebaugh. 
  • Each giving level will provide a partial, full, or multiple scholarships for camp. 
  • All funds raised will go towards River Camp scholarships even if we don't reach our fundraising goal. 
  • The more money we raise, the more children we can send to River Camp. 
  • Our perks for this campaign will come from the campers themselves, from hand written thank yous to camp group photos, you will be able to experience a bit of the fun of River Camp. 

The Impact

The small community of Firebaugh is located northwest of Fresno, CA. The population of Firebaugh is 7,946, with a median income of $30,126. 

  • Children in the community of Firebaugh do not have much opportunity to participate in summer programs. 
  • 100% of the children who participate in River Camp Firebaugh receive scholarships to attend. 
  • Without funding for scholarships, these kids miss out on the chance to be part of a positive summer program.
  • The River Camp Firebaugh program provides jobs for college aged youth from Firebaugh and Mendota. Jobs in this rural community are hard to come by meaning youth have to travel 50 miles to Fresno or up Interstate 5 to find work. 
  • This program provides service learning hours for high school students from Firebaugh and Mendota. These students can include their volunteer work on college applications. 

Please help us continue this program and send local kids to camp this summer and make a donation today. You'll have us jumping for joy! 


Other Ways You Can Help

If you aren't able to contribute today, you can still help make the program happen. 

  • You can share this story with your family and friends. Help spread the word about this special program. 
  • Don't forget you can use the Indiegogo sharing tools. 
  • We are also always looking for volunteers, visit www.riverparkway.org to find out more. 

Thank you for your support! 

Sarah Parkes

I have changed my plans and decided that I won't be doing the Sivananda Training this summer. All the current donations will be used for my life journeys. I have the blessings of the two wonderful people who have already donated. Thank you for checking out my page. 

With Gratitude, 

Chris Carmichael

story:
I've been traveling out west with Mike and my bike, but my bike and I need a way to get home.


Upon my return to the great state of Ohio, I will be starting my final year at the University of Akron as an undergraduate anthropology student. 


I really want to get home and finally finish college. All contributions will be greatly appreciated. Be sure to check out the perks! Happy holidays! 

All funds raised will go toward my flight and anything extra will be spent on textbooks.

story:
Integrating Technology is an informal volunteer network that offers free to low-cost professional development workshops for educators on how to integrate technology for active lifelong learners (IT4ALL) via Blended Learning (BL) and Blended Online Learning (BOL) courses, workshops, communities of learning, international collaborative projects, and live online events (webinars).

Dr. Nellie Deutsch, an educational technologist and social networking expert with a doctorate in educational leadership with a specialization in curriculum and  instruction founded Integrating Technology in 2006. The aim of the organization is to provide free online professional development workshops for educators around the world. The community has grown as more and more teachers find value in taking online professional workshops with an international population.
 
In 2009, Integrating Technology changed its name to Integrating Technology for Active Lifelong Learning or IT4ALL for short. Dariem Garces a Moodle developer and computer engineer, who had been supporting Nellie in her work with Moodle since 2005, joined the team as the organization's technology expert. Dariem manages the server and the Moodle websites for IT4ALL.
 
Today, IT4ALL is a huge network with followers and graduates of Moodle for Teacher (M4T) workshops. The members of IT4ALL are the ones contributing to the success of the workshops and the learning community. The workshops at IT4ALL are facilitated by educators for educators. 
 
IT4ALL needs your help to keep the courses free and low-cost. Please spread the word about the organization and where possible contribute in any way you can. The money we raise will go towards paying the teachers for desiging and facilitating the courses. With your generosity, we will be able to pay the tech support team for managing the server, upgrading the Moodle websites, and providing ongoing support for the courses.  
 
Testimonials by Educators Around the Globe

Norbert Boruett, Distant Learning Manager, FUNZOKenya a Project within IntraHealth International, Kenya

“Nellie Deutsch is an amazing person. She is enormous intellect and humanity in equal profession. Nellie is the guru in e learning.Let me support my assertion. I first met Nellie in Wikieducator and the class was big and she tutored us on the robes of wiki and we were able to post content. Her facilitation was learner centered, we did assignment and presented. Constructive feedback was offered. The live sessions were very lively and it was nice to present your material to an audience. Later Nellie introduced me to Moodle. This was very useful to me, since by then my institution was thinking of using Moodle. This training where graduates and I progressed from the beginners, intermediate, advance. The fee was very minimal. The competence that I gained was very useful- I became a consultant in Moodle in my country and not to forget the networks I made in IT4ALL, we are constantly in communication exploring e learning and leveraging on our experiences. Without IT4all the network I have could not have been possible. Later I did an administrative course in Moodle and eventually developed the capacity to host my own site- innovative moodling.org. I think Nellie has changed the World and proved that e learning works. I have never met Nellie face to face, but I know her so well, she has transferred a lot of skills to me, put succinctly, she has transformed me to be an educational technologist from a great distance.

We need to support Nellie and Dariem as they promote open source software chief among them Moodle.” August 21, 2012

J. R. Radney (PhD), Facilitator, Integrating Technology

“When I first started using MOODLE to support my face-to-face courses at Thompson Rivers University, Nellie's course "Moodle for Teachers" was recommended to me. I started in the course and moved to facilitating, so others could get the same sort of help I received. Nellie is a dedicated leader and teacher, who cares deeply about all her students. She is very capable, and she has designed several programs of study to benefit a wide range of people. I love working with her and her team of facilitators.” August 18, 2012

 
Steve Foerster, Community Council Member, WikiEducator

“Nellie is a fantastic force for progress when it comes to teaching educators to make better use of technology. Her pioneering work promoting effective use of learning management systems like Moodle sets her far in front of the pack. Highly recommended.” August 13, 2012

Shelly Terrell, Social Media Community Manager, The Consultants-E

“Dr. Nellie provides quality information and resources that are backed with her unique and vast experiences. In addition to her professionalism she is very helpful and personable in her training. She is continuously giving of her time to ensure those that she teaches and trains feel supported in their learning.” August 13, 2012

Tim Denny, ICT- education advisor, Southeast Asian Ministers of Education Organization, Regional Training Center

“Dr Nellie represents the current potential of what we should all consider the real meaning of organized education by leading a world-wide movement on open online learning potentials. She has inspired me and so many others the world over to give more, do more and be more. IT4all is to me the embodiment of true innovation in cross border education and all other projects of similar nature would do very well to learn from Nellie and IT4all. Sincerely Dr. John T. Denny Southeast Asia” August 11, 2012

Gene Loeb, Director, Founder, Center for Technology and Mental Health

“Dr Deutsch is providing pioneer work in the access to learning in new ways with technology. As the rapidly changing field of information access and learning affects more and more individuals, Dr. Deutsch is a major factor in enabling learning and teaching on an international basis. She enables persons to use new technology and how to use it to learn and to teach others. She is a pioneer and is making major contributions to learning access.” August 12, 2012

Judith Behrens, Mentor/Teacher, IT4ALL

story_txt:
Integrating Technology is an informal volunteer network that offers free to low-cost professional development workshops for educators on how to integrate technology for active lifelong learners (IT4ALL) via Blended Learning (BL) and Blended Online Learning (BOL) courses, workshops, communities of learning, international collaborative projects, and live online events (webinars).
Dr. Nellie Deutsch, an educational technologist and social networking expert with a doctorate in educational leadership with a specialization in curriculum and  instruction founded Integrating Technology in 2006. The aim of the organization is to provide free online professional development workshops for educators around the world. The community has grown as more and more teachers find value in taking online professional workshops with an international population. 
 
In 2009, Integrating Technology changed its name to Integrating Technology for Active Lifelong Learning or IT4ALL for short. Dariem Garces a Moodle developer and computer engineer, who had been supporting Nellie in her work with Moodle since 2005, joined the team as the organization's technology expert. Dariem manages the server and the Moodle websites for IT4ALL. 
 

Today, IT4ALL is a huge network with followers and graduates of Moodle for Teacher (M4T) workshops. The members of IT4ALL are the ones contributing to the success of the workshops and the learning community. The workshops at IT4ALL are facilitated by educators for educators. 
 
IT4ALL needs your help to keep the courses free and low-cost. Please spread the word about the organization and where possible contribute in any way you can. The money we raise will go towards paying the teachers for desiging and facilitating the courses. With your generosity, we will be able to pay the tech support team for managing the server, upgrading the Moodle websites, and providing ongoing support for the courses.

Norbert Boruett, Distant Learning Manager, FUNZOKenya a Project within IntraHealth International, Kenya
“Nellie Deutsch is an amazing person. She is enormous intellect and humanity in equal profession. Nellie is the guru in e learning.Let me support my assertion. Her facilitation was learner centered, we did assignment and presented. Constructive feedback was offered. The live sessions were very lively and it was nice to present your material to an audience. Later Nellie introduced me to Moodle. This was very useful to me, since by then my institution was thinking of using Moodle. This training where graduates and I progressed from the beginners, intermediate, advance. The fee was very minimal. The competence that I gained was very useful- I became a consultant in Moodle in my country and not to forget the networks I made in IT4ALL, we are constantly in communication exploring e learning and leveraging on our experiences. Without IT4all the network I have could not have been possible. Later I did an administrative course in Moodle and eventually developed the capacity to host my own site- innovative moodling.org. I think Nellie has changed the World and proved that e learning works. I have never met Nellie face to face, but I know her so well, she has transferred a lot of skills to me, put succinctly, she has transformed me to be an educational technologist from a great distance.
