Cristina Costa, Learning Technologies Development Officer, University of Salford “Nellie is an outstanding person and teacher. She has what it takes to generate genuine curiosity among learners and promote interesting learning situations. Nellie is (pro)active in her approach, supportive and passionate about her professional activities, and is therefore able to motivate the people surrounding her to enthusiastically engage in innovative learning situations. Nellie has a special gift to bring people together and involve them in pure collaborative and social learning activities, which will bring the best of them and help them achieve their goals. In all, Nellie is a brilliant communicator, a teacher at heart and a very generous individual who truly believes in the power of open communication.” 
Anne Fox, Educational Project consultant, CV2 
“Nellie’s enthusiasm and creativity in what was a very open-ended event gave the session huge momentum. She could be depended on to welcome new members rapidly and in a very warm fashion. Nellie helped to moderate some of the many discussions which were part of the event and was adept in leading online meetings so that the members of the session had regular live events which made the session much more personal.In short Nellie made a significant contribution to the success of this multimedia online event.” 
Doug Symington, Co-Moderator, EVO09 Digifolios 
“Nellie went well beyond the call of duty in her capacity as co-moderator of the EVO09 Digifolios sessions. Indeed, repeatedly over our program, Nellie picked up the slack left by her co-moderators and did the bulk of intake of some 240+ participants. Nellie also hosted a weekly conference that used WizIQ and was always a gracious and inclusive facilitator during these sessions. It is a pleasure to work with Nellie and I look forward to collaborating with her again in the future.” November 8, 2009
Ruth Vilmi, Founder and coordinator, International Writing Exchange (IWE) 
“I’ve known Nellie Deutsch online for several years. She knows a great deal about learning technologies and spends her free time learning more and helping others to learn. She is devoted to her work. I have no reservations about recommending her to any future employer in the field of educational technology.” 
Dr. Wayne Mackintosh, Wayne Top qualities: Great Results, Personable, On Time
“Nellie has supported the WikiEducator community facilitating numerous Learning4Content workshops. She is a highly skilled and professional online facilitator who works tirelessly in sharing her knowledge beyond the call of duty.” 
Nina Lyulkun, Co-moderator of EVO sessions 2007-12, Webheads in Action “It’s a great pleasure to be in the group of peole who endorse this wonderful person, caring friend, professional educator and facilitator, non-stop learner and teacher. Nellie is a fantastic motivator ready to help and share her knowledge with all. I feel happy to be acquainted with her and have been learning from her so much.” 
Jeanine Jenkins, Entrepreneur/Educator, “Nellie Deutsch is an amazing facilitator and manager over the Moodle for Teachers. She hosts outstanding sessions that allows educators to learn and utilize the necessary skills in learning various technical tools. While being new to Moodle platform, Nellie has provided very resourceful resources that have increased my knowledge and understanding to using such an amazing platform as Moodle. She is a great example of an awesome team player and leader within the Moodle for Teachers. I highly recommend Moodle for Teachers course for all levels. It does not matter if you are a beginner to advance if you are willing to learn, be proactive, and have an open mind with technology Moodle for Teachers is a great course to get involved in. Nellie Deutsch is always willing to help and assist anyone who wants learn and receive knowledge with technology. Moodle for Teachers is a course worth investing time in!”

story:
Meet Mr. Puzzles

Hi, my name is Kevin Dunn and I am known to most folks as Mr. Puzzles, the creator of the award-winning Puzzles For Us cultural "edutainment" series. Mr. Puzzles and I are appealing to you at this time for help in raising $12,000 to print 5,000 copies of our exciting puzzle books and to participate in the National Alliance of Black School Educators (NABSE) Conference in November.

With only 30 days left to the NABSE Conference, time is running short, which is why we need your help now.

Several years ago we came up with the idea for a crossword and word search puzzle book series that would use exciting stories, profiles and interesting facts to highlight the ongoing contributions of people and communities of color to the global community.

This groundbreaking idea eventually evolved into the extremely popular Puzzles For Us series which currently consists of four puzzle books and an upcoming coloring book.

        

The titles of the four books and the new coloring book in the series are:

  1. The Crossword Connection - crossword puzzle book for ages 12 to adult
  2. Puzzles For Us Jr. - word search story & activity book for ages 5 & older
  3. In Search of Yourself - word search puzzle book for ages 12 to adult
  4. Piecing It Together - word search story book for ages 10 & older
  5. All About Me - coloring book profiling famous African Americans for ages 3 & older

     

Enjoyed by children and adults of all ages, each of the books feature fascinating stories, narratives, and little known facts about some of the amazing things that people of color have done and are doing around the world.

Whether it's an early 19th century drawing depicting the original Statue of Liberty as a woman of mixed ancestry, or a puzzle spotlighting teenagers who are creating their own businesses, the Puzzles For Us "edutainment" series is designed to make learning an exciting fun experience for children and adults of all ages.

  

"Everyone should treat their children and themselves to your puzzle  books. They don't just entertain, they educate, motivate, inspire. They remind us of the rich legacy we need to reclaim and resurrect."  - Perri Gaffney, Actor

Our exciting line of puzzle books has also received wonderful reviews from a host of educators, parents, administrators, program directors, and people like you around the country who recognize the puzzles as a great resource for increasing literacy, building self-esteem, and for connecting people to information and resources that helps to improve the quality of their lives.

One high school principal in New York had this to say:

"We are particularly interested in this series since it is both educational and fun. It also allows our students the opportunity to be involved in academics with a direct emphasis on their culture and heritage. The books will be a great resource for our staff and in building literacy and implementing multicultural activities." 

While another educator in Colorado said the following:

"I donated the books to a charter school here in Colorado Springs, Colorado.  They were thrilled. I think your books are wonderful."

  

Well, that's a little about us, now here's what we want to do and why we need your help.

What We Want To Do and Why We Need Your Help

Okay, so here's our ultimate goal. We need to print 5,000 puzzle books that will be used to raise funds for various programs in urban areas in the U.S. that are providing educational and other types of support services for children and adults.

One of these programs is the International Youth Leadership Institute (http://www.iyli.org) where high school students get a chance to travel to countries like Brazil, Cuba, Egypt, Ethiopia, Ghana, Israel, Mexico, Morocco, Senegal, South Africa, and Spain . . .

             

while another is The Learning Tree Cultural Preparatory School (http://www.learningtreeprep.org) where along with a rigorous academic regimen students are prepared to be global ambassadors by going on school-sponsored trips to countries such as China, France, Mexico, Ghana, South Africa, Spain/Morocco, Egypt and Kenya.

                     

These are just two of the programs we want to help, and there are literally hundreds of others. That's where the Meet Mr. Puzzles National Book Tour comes in.

As part of the tour, we will travel to several cities over the next several months, beginning with Detroit in November, conducting speaking engagements, hosting puzzle parties, and participating in a number of educational conferences. A portion of the monies raised on the tour from the sale of our books will be donated to a number of educational programs around the country.

Our first stop on the tour is the National Alliance of Black School Educators Conference (NABSE) which takes place in November 2013 at the Cobo Arena in Detroit, Michigan. Schools, organizations and agencies like the two highlighted above will be coming from all over the country to attend this Conference, which is why we are so fired up about being there because it gives us a perfect opportunity to meet with some of the programs we are looking to help, and a chance to tell them about our fundraising tour and how they can apply for donations.

                 

And that's just the start. From this kickoff point, we will move on to bring the Meet Mr. Puzzles National Book Tour to other cities like Philadelphia, Newark, Baltimore, Washington, DC, Atlanta, Chicago, Houston, Los Angeles, and New York.

But first things first. In order to make this all happen we need your help. First, we need to print 5,000 books. Secondly, we need to pay for exhibitor space at the NABSE Conference. Lastly, we need to make sure that our traveling expenses to get to the Conference are covered.

Here's a breakdown of what we need and what it will cost:

  1. To print 4,000 puzzle books (four titles @ 1,000 books each). Cost: $6,800
  2. To print 1,000 copies of new coloring book. Cost: $1,900
  3. Pay for exhibitor booth at NABSE Conference. Cost: $1,525
  4. Shipping fees to transport books to Conference: Cost $385
  5. Travel expenses to NABSE Conference for two team members. Cost: $948

How We Are Making A Difference

Since our puzzle books tell the stories of people, places and events that generally don't get told or talked about, they are a big hit with our readership whose ages range from 5 to 85. Whether it's a puzzle about bullying, African American inventors, or celebrities like tennis greats Venus and Serena Williams, people like the idea that they can learn and be entertained at the same time.

So basically, we are helping to keep people informed, helping them to feel better about themselves, and ultimately getting more youngsters to read, especially boys. And just as important, we are providing an educational resource that teachers, parents and others can use to creatively engage youngsters both inside and outside of the classroom.

 

Finally, through the Meet Mr. Puzzles National Book Tour fundraising efforts we will be providing donations to organizations in support of the work they are doing to improve the quality of life for the people and communities they serve. Learn more.

Where Your $$$ Go And What You Get

Every dollar you donate will be used to cover the printing & shipping costs of 5,000 books (4,000 puzzle books + 1,000 coloring books), and for travel expenses and booth space at the NABSE Conference in Detroit, Michigan where we will kickoff our Meet Mr. Puzzles National Book Tour.   ,

Here are the perks that you get for your donation and support:

$10  -  Personal thank you from Mr. Puzzles and subscription to online newsletter.
$25  -  Choice of one autographed puzzle book or coloring book
$50  -  Children Fun Pack or Adult Fun Pack of 2 autographed puzzle books
$75  -  Family Pack of 3 autographed puzzle books + subscription to online newsletter
$125 - Limited edition tee shirt + Family Pack of 3 autographed puzzle books
$200 - Limited edition tee shirt + Super Deluxe Family Pack of 5 autographed books
$500 - Invitation to Meet Mr. Puzzles National Tour Official 2014 Launch Party + Limited              edition tee shirt + Super Deluxe Family Pack of 5 autographed books
$1,000 - Boxed puzzle book set 24 books + 2 Limited edition tee shirts + Party invite
$2,500 - Boxed puzzle book set 60 books + 5 Limited edition tee shirts + Party invite

                                     

Other Ways You Can Help

Here are a few other ways you can help us reach our goal.

Share This Information
Email it, blog it, post it, tweet it, and talk about it with your friends, family, associates and co-workers.

Follow Us
Follow us on Facebook, LinkedIn, Twitter, YouTube, and sign up for our online newsletter at http://www.puzzlesforus.com


Twitter: https://twitter.com/MrPuzzles2014
YouTube: http://youtu.be/2hC6KdDsh34
Facebook:  https://www.facebook.com/meetmrpuzzles

Have questions? Please direct any questions to meetmrpuzzles@gmail.com.

We thank you so much for your generous support!

story:
THE FELLOWSHIP

A BIG THANK YOU (MURAKOZE CYANE ) TO EVERYBODY WHO CONTRIBUTED, SHARED AND JUST TOOK INTEREST!!

Hi I'm Maria from Rwanda and I have a dream! I applied for a fellowship at the DO school in New York City. (thedoschool.org/)  And get this, I won! 
 
All the way from Rwanda, I have been selected - along with only 19 other people around the world - for a one year program which starts with a 10 week course in New York City at the School, followed by a ten-month phase back home. I received financial assistance for my flight, housing and dinners. I just need to raise $1,700 for breakfast, lunches and public transportation. I received my US visa and my bags are packed. Enable me to realize this once in a lifetime opportunity so that I can multiply its effects when I go back home to Rwanda. You are not just helping me, but contributing to a better future for my country too!!

I’ll be participating in the Sustainable Cup Challenge 2014 which is organized by the DO School in collaboration with the New York City's Office of Long Term Planning and Sustainability. The Sustainable Cup Challenge is about developing and presenting a sustainable to-go-cup, as well as a related infrastructure and campaign in New York City. Why is this so relevant you ask? Millions of plastic and paper cups are used and thrown away- this poses a serious problem to the environment and waste management alike.
 
The DO School serves as a platform for cultivating upcoming social entrepreneurs’ skills through non-formal educational training and mentorship which will enable them to kick-start their social ventures. The fellowship is a yearlong program that takes place in two phases, the ten-week Incubation Phase on campus and the ten-month Implementation phase in the Fellows’ home countries. During the Incubation Phase, Fellows solve a group challenge in order to learn hands-on how to act entrepreneurially and successfully take action. During the 10 month implementation phase in the Fellows home country we use the skills garnered during the incubation phase to begin social ventures.

WHY I NEED TO GO

The social venture idea I applied with is Angaza (please like our page :)); while in university, (I am 23 years old) I started a little enterprise making purses and accessories out of found materials. I would like to multiply my impact on society by providing jobs and promoting environmental awareness in schools in Rwanda! By creating job opportunities mostly for women, school dropouts and other members of society, I hope to empower them so that they can pursue their dreams. I believe that not enough is being done to help kids learn more about their environment in Rwanda: it’s not exciting, sounds too scientific and is not proactive. I want to make environment fun, contagious and unforgettable to a child living in Rwanda. I would like to reinforce children's sense of ownership when it comes to matters involving the environment. So, during the incubation phase, this is what I want to learn more about; turning ideas into action.

OTHER WAYS YOU CAN HELP
Get other people to know about this by SHARING, SHARING AND MORE SHARING!! Check below for sharing tools.

If you are in Rwanda and would like to help, do not hesitate to send me an e-mail on (ahazaza2511@gmail.com)

Thank you for reading this far and for helping me make a difference!!

 Maria

story:
Haiti Mission 

My name is Kyle Payton and this year I have the opportunity to serve on a mission trip to Haiti with some fellow KSU students and the Fellowship of Christian Athletes.  We will be serving at the Idadee Orphanage in Cap Haitian where nearly 30 children under the age of 5 are currently living without a family.  My goal is to join Idadees vision to "Give the poorest of the poor children a hope and a future". 

A Team of Supports

In order to serve on this trip, I need a team of supporters that are willing to join me in the mission and would love your help!  The amount I need to raise is $2,000.00 

The Mission

We will be in Haiti March 21 - 30. During our time there we have a few tasks we want to complete.

Build a Home for a Haitian family in need of shelter

Run a sports clinic for children in the Idadee Orphange

Teach the Haitian children about Christ

Build relationships with nearby Christians encouraging them to continue their work


For more information feel free to contact us at: 

www.ccojubilee.org   www.pittsburghkidsfoundation.org

In the meantime your prayers for God's provision and guideance would be very much appreciated!

story:
Elementary School At Risk for Mudslide - Please Help!

For students in El Salvador, a single drop of rain on the school's tin roof can herald disaster as students rush outside to look up at the sky. In the high elevation coffee forests of El Salvador, local tenant farmers send their young children to school, not knowing if they will survive the day.

The area is designated at highest risk for natural disasters by the European Union and World Geologists and lacks electricity or running water. Children in the school made of scrap metal await a fate that may come to pass this year or maybe next. Although no one knows for sure, in an area where it can rain 4 to 5 inches in single day, and where earthquakes are common, the earth will one day move and could easily bury the children and teachers in this humble school.

The government of El Salvador does not have the money to fix the situation - and so we ask for your help!

Our plan is build a new school in a different location on a safe piece of land which we have obtained. 

We are students at Albert Einstein University in San Salvador, El Salvador, and local volunteers for the Central America Foundation for Rural Education Development (CAFRED). We have designed a new school and have local businesses on board and the land donation.

Won't you please help us fulfill the dreams of 150 local school children and three dedicated teachers who are waiting for a new school at Los Arevalos, Ahuachapan, El Salvador?

We can rescue these kids from imminent danger and provide them with the education they need to succeed in today's world by providing them with a safe school that will have three classrooms, a library, a computer center for 15 computers, a teachers' office, bathrooms for the kids and a sleeping area for the teachers. 

The window of opportunity is short. Between now and the beginning of the next rainy Season, we intend to build a new school with electricity, running water and with all the materials needed for these children to focus on their studies.

Won't you please help us to change their futures.

story:
Hello,

 My name is Michael Snook and I Manage NIMBY, a shared workspace in East Oakland.

Most of us of a certain age grew up with some knowledge of basic trades. Whether we managed to become skilled craftsmen or just kind of learned how to make a towel holder or fishing weights we had a basic introduction on how to make things ourselves. A lot of today’s youth really never gets a hands-on appreciation for the manufacturing that goes into something as simple as a little toolbox; we think they need some help understanding how ideas become reality. It seems most children are living vicariously in a virtual world with little practical experience, so we decided to do something about it. We help kids use tin snips,  notchers,  finger brakes and spot welders as well as  grinding and wire wheels to make their very own toolbox from just two pieces of sheet metal. We didn’t see it coming but it turns out that the kids at Maker Faire really love this and it has gotten to the point where whole families will wait over an hour just to build their own toolbox. Our success has made it hard to continue without your help.

 

In the past we paid for supplies out of our pockets and tricked and cajoled our friends into helping out.  We want to take a small step forward to help this project stand on its own legs. When our fundraiser is successful, we will buy new tin snips for the kids (they just don’t last that long when you haven’t used them before), replace scratched safety glasses, buy small sized gloves, and maybe even lunch for our volunteers and other things like that.  Our volunteers work a really long day or two for each event and they need to be treated like the Gods and Goddesses they are. We would also like to add some printed materials to the project  in order to better inform the good folks as to what we are doing. We have doubled the number of tools we bring to these events and they all need a little love as well as a safe trip to and fro.

 

Of course we aren’t going to give up. We will keep on trucking either way. What we are asking is for you to help us avoid organizer burn out as well as help us expand so that we might touch that many more eager minds. If our fundraiser is super successful, we’ll have enough left over to have build days at other places around the Bay such as at the local East Bay Boxing Association (great youth program!), The Discovery Museum or other groups like them.

 

Why on earth would you want to show kids how to make a tool box? "The mind is not a vessel to be filled, but a fire to be kindled." –Plutarch said this about 2000 years ago and not much has changed.  You have to see the kids’ eyes light up when they realize that they can cut, bend and weld metal making something they can use and take home for free!

 

This will be our fourth build session and we would love to double up the equipment and volunteers this time to see how many kids we can give the opportunity to Make a metal toolbox for themselves.

    

Please put the word out and share this with everyone that might want to help out. Even if you can’t donate money, we’re always looking for another volunteer.

Many thanks
from Snook and the rest of Team NIMBY

Many thanksfrom Snook and the rest of Team NIMBY

story:
Dear Friend,

Are you concerned about how problems affect children in the world particularly in Africa? Do you want the world change to a better one? How and when do you think this change must take place?

I am asking you these questions because I know that you want to see a change happens in the world. I do know that you are always concerned how problems affect children daily anywhere in the world. If you are there for change or wanting to create opportunities for unfortunate children of Africa, then just join me and act now. You and I need to change this world start now. Let us change this world by giving disadvantaged children the opportunities they need. Let us begin with creating a community that free of war, conflicts, poverty and disasters.  This is exactly why I’m running this fundraising campaign. I used to be one of those children who had very unfortunate life, but through people help, I received hope again. Here I am!

 You can imagine that there are millions of children suffer and unfortunately die when they do not meet the needs they DESERVE! Let us not let that happen. I'm very confident that if we work together we can stop such unfortunates to children and we will definitely create a better world. I know there are many places in the world that need urgent help and change. But let us begin changing the world with the world's newest African country, Republic of South Sudan. The country tries to recover from two decades civil wars and in addition to preexisting poverty. Children in this country need very urgent opportunities to survive and meet hope again. One of their very pressing needs is education. They need EDUCATION!

Please consider a donation today.  Every small or large contribution makes a difference in war, genocides, and poverty affected children of Africa. Please visit our website at www.aidandcareforafrica.org  that tells you more about the impact we can all have and the results we have achieved. 

 Below is the project I am involved to raise fund for it. Dont wait! Join this fundraising campaign today. Thank you so much for making in a difference in vulnerable children's lives. 

Project Summary

When remote Makuac village completely destroyed during the two decades civil war in South Sudan has its own school, war orphans and vulnerable children will no longer have to trek eight hours round trip on foot to get an education. One school locates in Mangar Mou village is about 8 hours around trip from Makuac village and has been operated under tree since 2007. This school has many negative problems  and impacts on children such as lack of school buildings, unqualified teachers-who cannot even express themselves in English, lack of school supplies, short term learning ability. It just like of no school at all. Beig operated under trees; it is totally unsafe to children: branches falling, bad weather, animals attack and hungry. Makuach village children urgently need a REALLY SCHOOL!

What is the issue, problem, or challenge?

The only school in Mangar Mou village has to serve several thousand elementary-aged students is an under tree school. Some schools in other villages are small two-room temporary shack made out of twigs. The shack, used for early elementary, has no text books and no pit latrines (giving the school grounds an unpleasant odor). Once children pass their exams to start primary 4, they must trek eight hours round trip on foot through the wild bush to the nearest primary school, which is 70 kilometers away. Almost no families allow their daughters to make this trek.

How will this project solve this problem?

Our Makuach Central School will be committed to providing free primary and secondary education to children in ten villages around Makuch village area. A 32 classroom vision will be built in 4 phases; each phase will have 8 classrooms, 8 teachers’ homes, 2 toilet blocks, a library, an office, and a store.

Potential Long Term Impact

The project gives a new country’s children a ticket out of poverty.  Through Makuach School, educated girls can eventually give their own families a good start in life. Educated boys can escape a family cycle of hard labor. This will ripple to their families and community. Follow Dominic Diing’s vision as the global citizen, children who will attend Makuach Central School will be educated to become stars and contributed citizens of their own countries and the world.

Project Message

Providing housing for teachers is a necessity. Makuach has virtually no educated people, so we have to bring in teachers from outside the area. Few people would come without adequate housing. More importantly, building Makuach Central School for children without education is not Dominic Diing and his friends’ responsibility alone, it is yours as well. So please join us and help us reach out to those who can help us reach our fund raising goal so that we will be able to begin building the school by December 2013.

How you can help

  • You can make a direct donation
  • Create your own fundraising campaign.
  • Host an event in your area and we will send a speaker to motivate and inspire your audience. ----We have former lost boys of Sudan and citizens of a new nation in Africa.
  • Talk to your church, school, workplaces and others to adopt our project or support the cause
  • Volunteer with us! Bring in any thoughts that can help us reach our goals.
  • Join our annual trip to Africa.
  • Produce a documentary about our founder and the people of a new nation, South Sudan
  • Match grants with our project
  • Become our ambassadors in your area

Our Supporters' Benefits

We will not let our supporters go unappreciated! We will do what we do best to appreciate our donors or supporters. Below are a few suggestions our current dontors or supporters recommended us to give for appreciations:

  • Wraist bands
  • Gifts of local materials from Africa
  • Special Recognition at our annual event e.g Acarcia Tree Award.
  • Friends of South Sudan Award.
  • Free t-shirts        
  • Other items

story:
Hi, my name is Natalie and I am a mom, surfer and special education teacher in Northern California.

In recent years, there have been news stories on shows like Nightline about the profound positive effect surfing has on individuals on the autism spectrum.  Although no formal studies have been conducted on the surfing-autism connection, theories range from the “increased blood flow to crucial neurons and the reshaping of abnormal structures in the front brain” to surfing being a “vehicle to an emotional breakthrough, a way of reaching under the mask and perhaps connecting” to these children. (http://thesecondsight.blogspot.com/2006/12/auti...).  One mother told me that she recently took her 6 ½ year old surfing and that his transformation in the water was amazing!  He was comfortable in his own skin, displayed no self-stimulating behavior such as flapping, no aggression, and was smiling and laughing the entire time he spent in the water.  Surfing is an activity out of the realm of services these children typically participate in and is viewed as “normal” activity.  
 
I began researching the idea of a surf camp for children with autism and discovered that there are no week-long camps, from Santa Cruz to the Oregon border, that serve this population.  It made sense that I combine my passion for surfing with my passion for educating and working with children with special needs, specifically autism.
 

A brief description of the program:

Spectrum Surf Camps offer one-week surf camps specifically designed to serve children, ages 5 – 17, on the autism spectrum.  The camp is limited to six (6) students with a 1:1 instructor/student ratio.  Our staff includes highly qualified surf instructors who are expert surfers, have worked with children and adults with disabilities, and are certified in CPR and/or certified in ocean rescue.  In addition to the surf instructors, the staff includes an occupational therapist, behavior specialist, special education teacher, and peer volunteers.

While there is no guarantee that each student will stand up on his/her board, s/he will certainly experience the thrill of riding a wave. 

 

A little bit about me...

 
As I was studying for the California Bar Exam, I took a position as a 1:1 instructional assistant for a student in the 2nd grade.  I found the experience working with children with special needs to be an extremely rewarding one and moved from a 1:1 instructional assistant to a Resource Specialist aide and then went back to school for my California teaching credential as an Education Specialist.  I have been working as a special education teacher since 2003.

In fall of 2000, I paddled out to the surf.  I caught the very first wave I paddled for and was hooked.  I have been surfing ever since. 
 

 

Other Ways You Can Help:

Help spread the word about Spectrum Surf Camps using the share tools on indiegogo.

story:
My name is Tim Byron I am 23 and gay. I come from a very conservative Christian family and knew from a very early age that being gay was never an acceptable lifestyle. I originally came out to my friends and coworkers when I was 19, but my family eventually found out. Once they found off I went to Bible school in Australia as a means of conversion therapy and to repress my homosexual tendencies. During that time I went through multiple 'deliverance' rituals where the demons of homosexuality were supposedly cast out of me. I was gone a total of 8 months. Shortly after I got home from my 'conversion' I told my parents that I still had homosexual tendencies and went to Exodus International ministries in June 2011. I left Exodus more confused. It was only a couple months later that my life would change. I met my now boyfriend in my first year of University and we hit it off immediately. We had been dating for just over a year when my family found out about our relationship. They found out this past January. They forced me to break up with my boyfriend and tried to force me to go to conversion therapy again and wanted me to become heavily involved with church. My heart was completely broken and I have never cried as much as I did that month. After a week of being apart and heart broken, my best friend arranged for my boyfriend and I to talk. We got back together that night. My parents found out a week later and threw me out February 6, 2013. Until that point I did not have to pay rent as I was living at home, and my parents paid my education. Since then I have found a place to live and have had to pay for my education and textbooks, pay rent, and all other costs that come with living on my own. I am struggling to make my payments and have had to start working 2 jobs, while being a full-time student. I am struggling to find time to study and do homework from working 2 jobs and being in school full-time. Last week I was only home to sleep and I am burnt out.


I am not looking for that much money. Just enough to help with schooling costs. If I was to receive the $2000 I am campaigning for, I would put it aside in a Tax Free Savings Account, and save it for my next semester of school. The $2000 would not cover all my school costs, but I do not need all my school costs met, just enough to pay off some current school debt, and help me pay for my next semester.


I am a Psychology Major at Kwantlen Polytechnic University and I want to become a counselor for individuals struggling with their sexual identity. I do not want anyone to go through what I have had to go through and want to make a difference in the LGBTQ youth that I come in contact with as a counselor. I want to bring more awareness to this issue and make sure that young LGBTQ youth know there are people out there willing to help them and support them.

story:
Our Project


How have your travels changed your life?

For me, traveling has bred an incurable curiosity that has changed the way I look at the world. After visiting new places, I find that the history and culture of the place comes alive in texts at school, and knowledge of new peoples grows my empathy and compassion. I see the world is an opportunity for discovery.

As a teacher, I desire to help my students develop this type of enthusiasm for learning. In an era of standardization and high stakes, the challenge of sparking genuine curiosity and inquiry seems greater than ever before. Our goal is therefore to travel with a group students on the trip of a lifetime, to Paris and Barcelona, with the purpose of igniting a passion for discovery.

Hudson High School of Learning Technologies is a Title I school located in Manhattan. The majority of our students receive free lunch, so in order to open the opportunity of a trip such as this to as many students as possible, we are offering a subsidized funding option to interested students. Students were invited to apply for places in the Travel Club, a club organized to involve students in the process of preparing for the trip while fundraising half the trip cost for each member.

The fourteen students selected for the Travel Club have exhibited an exceptional dedication to making their dream of travel come true. They were selected through an interview process, and are currently developing financial plans to save for one half of their own trip cost. The students are also actively involved in fundraising efforts. The goal of the Travel Club is three-fold; to give students the opportunity to see the world while teaching financial responsibility and the benefits of working for a long-term goal. 

Please check out our student-moderated website to meet some of our members: http://hhslttravelclub.wordpress.com/

What We Need & What You Get

We do need your help to fully realize our goal: 

To get every member of the Travel Club to Paris and Barcelona on February 12, 2015, we need to raise $1320 per student to cover half the cost of their trip, a total of $18,900. 

That money goes toward their travel expenses, meals, and entrance to the major sights of the cities we will visit. The goal of this campaign is to raise about half of our anticipated need.

  • With a gift of $330 or more, you will cover a fourth of a student’s trip. You will be connected to an individual student, and as one of their “sponsors” you will hear personally from that student as we prepare for our trip and while we are in Europe!
  • With a gift of $100 - $330, you will be connected to the Travel Club as one of our supporters. We’ll keep you updated on our activity with a quarterly newsletter (just provide your email or physical address) and you’ll hear from one of our members
  • Any gift, be it $5 or $20, puts us closer to our goal. We invite you to support our general trip fund however you can, and stay involved in our journey by checking our website.

Other Ways You Can Help

Preparing for this trip is a marathon; we meet weekly and look forward to our departure even though it is a year away! As many of our students have never travelled, we would love for you to help build enthusiasm and anticipation by sharing your own travel experiences. We would love to get to know who you are, why you want to support a trip, and how traveling has changed your life. These personal stories help students prepare for their own trip! If you have been to Paris or Barcelona, we would particularly love to hear what you enjoyed in those cities. Do you have recommendations? Your experiences inspire and motivate us to continue working for this trip!

Traveling has changed my life, I can imagine it has changed yours, and I expect that it will change the lives of these students. Thank you in advance for your willingness to contribute to the lives of these students. I believe that this single trip has the potential to shape a lifelong disposition toward curiosity and learning that will have a profound impact on their education.


With gratitude,

Halley Anne Curtis and the Hudson Travel Club

They were selected through an interview process, and are currently developing financial plans to save for one half of their own trip cost. The students are also actively involved in fundraising efforts. The goal of the Travel Club is three-fold; to give students the opportunity to see the world while teaching financial responsibility and the benefits of working for a long-term goal. Please check out our student-moderated website to meet some of our members: http://hhslttravelclub.wordpress.com/What We Need & What You GetWe do need your help to fully realize our goal: To get every member of the Travel Club to Paris and Barcelona on February 12, 2015, we need to raise $1320 per student to cover half the cost of their trip, a total of $18,900. That money goes toward their travel expenses, meals, and entrance to the major sights of the cities we will visit. The goal of this campaign is to raise about half of our anticipated need.

With a gift of $330 or more, you will cover a fourth of a student’s trip. You will be connected to an individual student, and as one of their “sponsors” you will hear personally from that student as we prepare for our trip and while we are in Europe!


With a gift of $100 - $330, you will be connected to the Travel Club as one of our supporters. We’ll keep you updated on our activity with a quarterly newsletter (just provide your email or physical address) and you’ll hear from one of our members

Any gift, be it $5 or $20, puts us closer to our goal. We invite you to support our general trip fund however you can, and stay involved in our journey by checking our website.
Other Ways You Can HelpPreparing for this trip is a marathon; we meet weekly and look forward to our departure even though it is a year away! As many of our students have never travelled, we would love for you to help build enthusiasm and anticipation by sharing your own travel experiences. We would love to get to know who you are, why you want to support a trip, and how traveling has changed your life. These personal stories help students prepare for their own trip! If you have been to Paris or Barcelona, we would particularly love to hear what you enjoyed in those cities. Do you have recommendations? Your experiences inspire and motivate us to continue working for this trip!Traveling has changed my life, I can imagine it has changed yours, and I expect that it will change the lives of these students. Thank you in advance for your willingness to contribute to the lives of these students. I believe that this single trip has the potential to shape a lifelong disposition toward curiosity and learning that will have a profound impact on their education.With gratitude,Halley Anne Curtis and the Hudson Travel Club

story:
www.narrativepractice.org

We are a 501c3 non-profit, and your contribution is tax deductible.

Update: 1/21/15

The Center for Narrative Practice is pleased to announce that the 2015-2016 Low Residency Certificate in Narrative Practice will begin on August 24, 2015, and that applications are now being accepted.

The certificate program provides an intensive introduction to the theory, methods, and applications of narrative practice. Students will collaborate with professionals from diverse fields, disciplines, and backgrounds, and will receive practical training that can be incorporated into their lives and careers.

The certificate program requires 80 hours of residency in Boston (one week in August 2015, one week in January 2016), and 80 hours of online study (weekly three-hour online sessions during the 2015 fall and 2016 spring terms).

Please click HERE for more information.
----------------------------------------------------------

We are also honored to announce the first three members of our advisory board: Arthur W. Frank, Mindy Thompson Fullilove, and Thomas R. Cole. 

Arthur W. Frank, Ph.D - Professor emeritus in the Department of Sociology at the University of Calgary, and author of At the Will of the Body: Reflections on Illness, The Wounded Storyteller: Body, Illness and Ethics, and other titles. 

Mindy Thompson Fullilove, M.D.- Professor of clinical psychiatry and public health at Columbia University, author of Urban Alchemy: Restoring Joy in America's Sorted-Out Cities, Root Shock: How Tearing Up City Neighborhoods Hurts America and What We Can Do About It, and other titles.

Thomas R. Cole, Ph.D - Director of the McGovern Center for Humanities and Ethics at The University of Texas Health Science Center, author of The Journey of Life: A Cultural History of Aging, co-author of the textbook, Medical Humanities: An Introduction, and other titles.

We thank Art, Mindy, and Tom for joining our organization, and we know that their counsel and support will help us build the Center for Narrative Practice into a respected and just organization. We will be welcoming more members from diverse fields in the coming months, and look forward to convening our full board as soon as possible.
-----------------------------------------------------------
Coming Up:

Narrative Practice Implementation (Client Sites, Fall 2015) - An extensive on-site introduction to, and implementation of, narrative practice methods and tools custom designed for organizations in healthcare, academia, public health, business, and creative fields.

Workshops (Boston, Spring 2016) - Three-day Narrative Practice workshops will provide an intensive introduction to narrative practice theory and methods

Summer Institute (Boston, Summer 2016) - Annual week-long intensive program coinciding with August certificate residency week

Online Workshops (Online, Spring 2016) - Five-hour online workshop provides an introduction to our mission, methods, and tools

________________________________________________________________

Update: 7/15/14

With your help, we raised $35,000 through indiegogo, and outside contributions. We will take the next few months to design the curriculum, and we'll be in touch with updates soon. Our goal is to announce our academic calendar and offerings by October 15, 2014. 

We are still accepting contributions, and will match your contribution to one of the perks (your contribution is tax deductible). 

The mailing address to send a check is:

Center for Narrative Practice, Inc.
200 Prospect Street
Shrewbury, MA 01545

Click HERE for information on paying by credit card or Paypal:


Thanks again for all your support.

The CNP Team

______________________________________________________________________

Update: Call for Submissions for Evening Paper

The first issue of our printed journal will, accordingly, feature works on the theme "Beginnings." Please submit any creative work on this theme (interpret the theme however you'd like) -- we welcome fiction, poetry, creative non-fiction, and studio art (photography, painting, drawing, or any other visual representations). Scholarly papers will be accepted on all topics related to narrative, storytelling and creative practice.  

Our inaugural issue will feature works by Chris Adrian, Susannah Cahalan, Mary Gordon, and Ben Schwartz.

The deadline is October 15, 2014. Click here for submission form and guidelines . 
______________________________________________________________________

“The understanding of art depends finally upon one's willingness to extend one's humanity and one's knowledge of human life.”   -- Ralph Ellison


Over the last ten years, the team behind the Center for Narrative Practice has been involved in a growing, innovative program at an Ivy League academic medical center that uses narrative in the training of healthcare professionals, bringing humanity back to healthcare practice through close work with stories of all kinds. Our expertise for applying narrative and creativity in the healthcare setting has achieved a global reputation. We have seen, again and again and again, the power of applied work with the arts, and we have come to believe that the next step is to branch out from healthcare.

We want to reach more people; we want to build a movement, and to spread the power of this work to the farthest corners of the world; we want to bring people together from all professions, fields, backgrounds, and interests, and to offer a program for learning that is accessible for as many as possible. The greater the diversity of the cohort, we have learned, the more powerful the result, and the farther the reach.

We are building the Center without start-up support from academia, grants, or foundations--we want to construct it on a solid foundation free of the politics, compromise, and obstacles that will inevitably challenge us as we grow.

To this end, the vision of the Center for Narrative Practice was born, and to this end we ask you to join us.     

SCOTT

is an idea man and organizer, entrepreneur, producer of Tattoo the Earth festivals and a publicly traded messenger company, former Wall Street employee and counselor at an AIDS shelter, stay-at-home-dad turned full throttle engine for the CNP. He understood the power of narrative when he looked at his own story, and the disparate fields and sharp turns his career has taken, and saw the narrative thread that runs through all of his work: a fierce dedication to ideas, design, and results, and a lifelong desire to change the world.https://www.linkedin.com/pub/scott-alderman/46/9a8/970
MAURA

grew up on the Lower East Side of Manhattan, where the streets themselves were storied.  A bookish child, she read Kafka, Baudelaire and Garcia-Marquez on the IRT, and she grew up to teach literature and film.  She has been exploring narrative with students at Columbia University and Barnard College for more than twenty years. She rediscovers the power of narrative every day in the classroom. http://www.linkedin.com/pub/maura-spiegel/8/78/2a7

CRAIG

first fell in love with the art of storytelling on his family’s farm in Minnesota. The farmers of the plains have traditionally been storytellers: Craig's grandparents and parents honored this tradition. Their storytelling was the revelation of this meaning, illuminating the world embraced by their horizon. As an academic director, philosopher, educator, and writer, Craig shares his lifelong love of storytelling with his students, and hopes that he is honoring the tradition of those whose art first inspired him.  http://www.linkedin.com/pub/craig-irvine/b/503/75a

NELLIE

is a Boston-bred novelist. She felt the power of narrative in her life from its very beginning, as her father was a survivor of the Holocaust who remembered very little about what he had been through—the ever-present tug of a story that could not be told. Her first novel was a fictionalized account of her own family’s story, and the process of writing it was life-changing, cementing the understanding of how crafting a story can change the way that it lives in your body and mind. https://twitter.com/NellieGHermann


We are four of the people behind the CNP, and we believe in this work because of what it has already given to us, and what we have seen it give to countless others. 

Everyone has stories, and we want to hear yours.


The Center is launching in its first location in Cambridge, MA, and will begin accepting certificate students in fall 2015. Our goal is to raise $65,000. 

Achieving our goal let's us: 

  • Have greater outreach to recruit our first class through print advertising and roadshow recruitment activities.
  • Strengthens our position as we establish academic partnerships and alliances with other organizations.
  • Gives us flexibility and options as we go about the business of building a world class learning center.

PLEASE NOTE: WE ARE A 501c3 NON-PROFIT CORPORATION, AND YOUR CONTRIBUTION IS TAX DEDUCTIBLE.


At the Center for Narrative Practice we believe that stories are the primordial means through which we make sense of and convey the meaning of our lives. We believe stories can be a tool for healing, for teaching, for sharing and connecting. We believe that creativity can be learned, and practiced, and can change the way persons live in the world. We believe that critical, skilled attention to stories and storytelling in all of its forms is and ought to be recognized as a part of all disciplines, and that narrative practice can and does lead toward openness and healing. 

The Center for Narrative Practice will provide deep critical training in how stories work, both personally and culturally, and in the ability to apply this knowledge to everyday life by using narrative practice, the creative arts, and the study of story as a bridge towards deeper connections in interdisciplinary and inter-professional education. 

The training and education the Center offers will be for professionals, scholars, undergraduates, graduate students, and all those interested in the applications of narrative and creativity in their respective fields. Through traditional programs, low-residency and online programs, and partnerships with other academic institutions and organizations, the Center will broaden the applications for narrative and creative skills locally and internationally.

A registered 501c3 non-profit corporation, the Center will be self-funded and self-sustaining by its range of offerings and activities. Grants, private donors, and fundraising activities will be pursued to augment development, research, and reach.


Certificate of Study in Narrative Practice--Low Residency

  • Equivalent of fifteen credits of coursework, two terms for completion.
  • Low residency component requires 50% of study on-site, 50% online.
  • Foundation is an intensive introduction to narrative theory and methods.
  • Students will be working and studying with people from diverse fields, disciplines, and backgrounds.
  • Certificate scheduled to launch Beginning August 2015.

Institute for Narrative Practice (on-site) 

  • Annual intensive program taking place in the summer.
  • In addition to acting as a starting point for certificate programs, the Institute will also host a three-day workshop (see next), and an annual conference.
  • Credit from attending institute can be applied to future certificate coursework.
  • First Institute scheduled for August 2015.

Workshops (on-site) 

  • Three to four workshops per year on-site (some specialized), as well as workshops/information sessions elsewhere in the U.S. and overseas. 
  • 40 to 60 professionals learn the basics of narrative practice, theory and methods.
  • Credit can be applied to future summer institute, or certificate. 
  • First workshop tentatively scheduled for October 2015.
Web-based Workshops (on-line) 
  • Five-hour web-based course.
  • A brief overview of narrative practice, with an introduction to our vision and methods.
  • Web-based workshops begin March 2016.


The Center believes that the need for narrative and creative training, and the benefit of narrative competency, cross all fields. To that end, in addition to interdisciplinary core training, the Center is designed to provide specialized concentration tracks in areas that we believe are of crucial importance to successful communication and community. Rather than teaching our students a specific discipline, our methods provide a tool kit that will expand, augment, improve, and, ultimately, transform the academic and professional experience.


For almost two decades, the team behind the Center has been at the forefront of developing methods to understand, research, and teach narrative and creativity.  At the core of these methods is the practice of creativity and use of the imagination; the study and creation of literary work, film, theater, graphic novels, and other arts are fundamental threads in all of the tools we have developed, and the application of creativity is common throughout our methods.

Close Reading

Also referred to as “slow reading,” the act of reading something carefully—whether a poem, novel, short story, memoir or a painting, sonata, play—and attending to all aspects of its dimensionality—form, voice, temporality, diction, movement, space, etc.—teaches us to pay closer attention to all aspects of our world, and reveals the ways that attentive looking and listening can engage the complexity of human expression.

Reflective and Creative Writing

This is writing with an eye toward discovery of new meanings and new forms, writing as a tool for expansion of the mind and spirit, and discovery of uncovered aspects of self and connections to colleagues. We will provide training through the discussion of writing in the language of text and constructive criticism. 

Narrative Intervention

In a situation where people are struggling due to perceived ownership of certain deeply held beliefs or concepts related to work environments, the use of narrative – stories that no one “owns” – can allow new elements to be seen and persons to re-connect and loosen their grip on whatever issues are troubling them.

Critical Theory 

Narrative is our primary device for making sense of social action. The “Narrative Turn” in critical thinking takes as its starting point the fact that individuals, institutions, nations and cultures construct their identities by locating themselves within plotted stories. What’s more, drawing forth and attending to stories that have no place among the repertoire of “legitimate” narratives --those of the vulnerable or silenced-- require narrative skill.  

Once we have raised the start-up funds, we begin the work of designing, recruiting and building a world-class center. Key action items include:

Classroom Space
We will rent temporary meeting space for our first two years, with a goal of securing permanent classroom and office space by fall 2017. 

Advisory Board
We will invite and convene an advisory board to meet by spring 2015. The advisory board will be comprised of leaders in the field of narrative theory and practice.

Fellowships
We will offer fellowships beginning in the 2016-2017 school year. The fellowships will be designed to support our graduates in their work.

Projections
The following details our three-year tuition and expense projections:


A diverse group of scholars, artists, teachers and thinkers have come together to create the Center for Narrative Practice. All feel the power and potential of narrative and creativity for affecting change in the world, and believe in the need for an independent center in the service of narrative practice and theory. Spanning disciplines, genres, and interests, the leadership and faculty of the Center bring the unparalleled experience necessary to build a sustainable, world-class entity.

LEADERSHIP

Scott Alderman (Founding Director)
Scott Alderman's career as an entrepreneur and organizer has taken him to the music business (as European road manager for Lionel Hampton, and a producer of festivals that have played at Giants Stadium and Red Rocks), to Wall Street ( Morgan Stanley), and to social services (working as a counselor at a residence for homeless people with AIDS). The common thread throughout these disparate industries and fields is the ability to successfully manage people, process, product, and technology. Since 2010, he has been the administrative director for the Program in Narrative Medicine at the Columbia University College of Physicians and Surgeons. Scott has a BA in literature/writing from Columbia University. 

Nellie Hermann, M.F.A.
Nellie Hermann is creative Director of the Program in Narrative Medicine at Columbia University. She is a graduate of Brown University and the M.F.A. program at Columbia. Her first novel, The Cure for Grief (Scribner: 2008), received national acclaim in such publications as Time Magazine, Elle, The Washington Post, The Boston Globe, and others, and was chosen as a Target “Breakout” book. Hermann's short story "Can We Let the Baby Go?" won first prize in Glimmer Train's 2008 "Family Matters" competition and was published in the Winter, 2010 issue; another story of hers appeared in Glimmer Train in August, 2012. Her non-fiction has appeared in an anthology about siblings, Freud’s Blindspot (Free Press: 2010), as well as in Academic Medicine. Over the last eight years she has taught fiction and narrative medicine to undergraduates, medical students, graduate students, and clinicians of all sorts, and has given conference addresses in Iowa, California, Seoul, Korea, and elsewhere. Her second novel, The Season of Migration, is forthcoming in February 2015 with Farrar, Straus, and Giroux. 

Craig Irvine, Ph.D
Craig Irvine is a founder and Academic Director of the Program in Narrative Medicine at Columbia University, and holds his Ph.D in Philosophy. For more than 15 years, he has been designing and teaching cultural competency, ethics, Narrative Medicine, and Humanities and Medicine curricula for residents, medical students, physicians, nurses, social workers, chaplains, dentists, and other health professionals. He has over 20 years of experience researching the history of philosophy, phenomenology, and narrative ethics, and over 25 years of experience teaching ethics, humanities, the history of philosophy, logic, and narrative medicine at the graduate, undergraduate, and preparatory school levels. He has published articles in the areas of ethics, residency education, and literature and medicine and has presented at numerous national and international conferences on these and other topics. 

Jack Saul, Ph.D
Jack Saul is Assistant Professor of Clinical Population and Family Health at Columbia University’s Mailman School of Public Health, and Founding Director of the International Trauma Studies Program an independent post-graduate training and research institute affiliated with Columbia University. As a psychologist he has created a number of programs for populations in New York City that have endured war, torture, and political violence, including the Bellevue/NYU Program for Survivors of Torture, REFUGE (Refugee Resource Center), Theater Arts Against Political Violence, the Post-9/11 Downtown Community Resource Center, and African Refuge. He consults with organizations on staff welfare in response to trauma-related work and has a private practice in Manhattan. His is the author of the recently published Collective Trauma, Collective Healing: Promoting Community Resilience in the Aftermath of Disaster (Routledge). 

Kristen Slesar, L.C.S.W., M.S.
Kristen Slesar is a bilingual trauma-focused psychotherapist at the Child and Adolescent Witness Support Program and in private practice. She is also an adjunct faculty member of the Narrative Medicine Program at the College of Physicians and Surgeons of Columbia University and a consultant and trainer for the Graduate School of Applied Psychology of New York University and the New York City Alliance Against Sexual Assault. Kristen previously coordinated the Sexual Assault Forensic Examiner and Volunteer Advocate Programs at a major private hospital in New York City and managed a small basic center/shelter for homeless LGBTQ teens and young adults in Harlem. Kristen has a Bachelor's degree in Latin American Studies from Stanford University, a Master's of Social Work from New York University and a Master's of Science in Narrative Medicine from Columbia University. 

Maura Speigel, Ph.D.
Maura Spiegel, Ph.D is Senior Lecturer of English and Comparative Literature at Columbia University, where she teaches courses on fiction and film, and is a founder and Associate Director of the Program in Narrative Medicine. She is the co-author of The Grim Reader: Writings on Death, Dying and Living On (Anchor/Doubleday), The Breast Book: An Intimate and Curious History (Workman), which was a Book-of-the-Month Club Quality Paperbacks selection. She co-edited the journal Literature and Medicine (Johns Hopkins University press) for seven years, has written for The New York Times, and has published essays on the history of the emotions, Charles Dickens, and diamonds in the movies, among many other topics. She is currently writing a book about the life and films of Sidney Lumet for St. Martin’s Press. 

FACULTY AND LECTURERS 

Chris Adrian, M.D., M.Div., M.F.A. has written three novels: Gob's Grief, The Children's Hospital, and The Great Night. In 2008, he published A Better Angel, a collection of short stories. His short fiction has also appeared in The Paris Review, Zoetrope, Ploughshares, McSweeney's, The New Yorker, The Best American Short Stories, and Story. He was one of 11 fiction writers to receive a Guggenheim Fellowship in 2009. He received his M.D. from Eastern Virginia Medical School in 2001, and completed a pediatric residency at the University of California, San Francisco. He received a Master of Divinity at Harvard Divinity School, and is also a graduate of the Iowa Writers' Workshop. 

Paul Lazar is a founding member and co-artistic director, along with Annie-B Parson, of Big Dance Theater. He has co-directed and acted in works for Big Dance since 1991, including commissions from the Brooklyn Academy of Music, The Walker Art Center, Dance Theater Workshop, Classic Stage Company and Japan Society. Paul is an Associate Member of The Wooster Group, acting in Brace Up!, Emperor Jones, North Atlantic and The Hairy Ape. He has acted in over 30 feature films, including The Host, Mickey Blue Eyes, Silence of the Lambs, Beloved, Lorenzo’s Oil, and Philadelphia, and will be in the next film by director Bong Joon Ho (The Host) called Snowpiercer. He currently teaches at New York University. 

David Small, M.F.A. was born and raised in Detroit, and received his MFA from Yale. His drawings have appeared regularly in The New Yorker and The New York Times, and his children’s books have been translated into several languages, and made into animated films and musicals. He is a 3-time Caldecott winner for The Gardener with Sarah Stewart, One Cool Friend with Toni Buzzeo, and So You Want to be President? with Judith St. George; a 2-time recipient of the Christopher Medal; as well as a Society of Illustrators Gold Medal winner. To date he has illustrated over 40 picture books. David’s graphic memoir, Stitches, about his problematic youth, was a New York Times Bestseller and was a finalist for a National Book Award. 

Betsy Sparrow, Ph.D is Assistant Professor of Psychology at Columbia University, and received her Ph.D in social psychology from Harvard University. Since the publication of her article The Google Effect: Consequences of Having Information at our Fingertips (Science, 2011), Betsy has been asking questions about what we are likely to remember when we look up information online. When are we most critical in our evaluation of what we learn online? Under what type of learning situations are we most likely to make creative leaps? Her work has gained her a reputation in academia as one of the important voices in research on the intersection of human cognition and technology She has written a review of the subject for two prestigious journals, and has gained considerable media attention (PBS, MSNBC, BBC, ABC News, the Colbert Report, plus all major international newsprint publications). Her work has drawn the interest of many corporations (Masie’s Learning, Shell, Humera) where she has given keynote addresses and led breakout sessions with people involved with corporate learning and internet technology creation. 



                          The future is in stories. 
               The future is through these doors.
