PLEASE NOTE: WE ARE A 501c3 NON-PROFIT CORPORATION, AND YOUR CONTRIBUTION IS TAX DEDUCTIBLE.At the Center for Narrative Practice we believe that stories are the primordial means through which we make sense of and convey the meaning of our lives. We believe stories can be a tool for healing, for teaching, for sharing and connecting. We believe that creativity can be learned, and practiced, and can change the way persons live in the world. We believe that critical, skilled attention to stories and storytelling in all of its forms is and ought to be recognized as a part of all disciplines, and that narrative practice can and does lead toward openness and healing. The Center for Narrative Practice will provide deep critical training in how stories work, both personally and culturally, and in the ability to apply this knowledge to everyday life by using narrative practice, the creative arts, and the study of story as a bridge towards deeper connections in interdisciplinary and inter-professional education. The training and education the Center offers will be for professionals, scholars, undergraduates, graduate students, and all those interested in the applications of narrative and creativity in their respective fields. Through traditional programs, low-residency and online programs, and partnerships with other academic institutions and organizations, the Center will broaden the applications for narrative and creative skills locally and internationally.A registered 501c3 non-profit corporation, the Center will be self-funded and self-sustaining by its range of offerings and activities. Grants, private donors, and fundraising activities will be pursued to augment development, research, and reach.Certificate of Study in Narrative Practice--Low Residency

Equivalent of fifteen credits of coursework, two terms for completion.


Low residency component requires 50% of study on-site, 50% online.


Foundation is an intensive introduction to narrative theory and methods.


Students will be working and studying with people from diverse fields, disciplines, and backgrounds.


Certificate scheduled to launch Beginning August 2015.

Institute for Narrative Practice (on-site) 
Annual intensive program taking place in the summer.
In addition to acting as a starting point for certificate programs, the Institute will also host a three-day workshop (see next), and an annual conference.
Credit from attending institute can be applied to future certificate coursework.
First Institute scheduled for August 2015.
Workshops (on-site) 

Three to four workshops per year on-site (some specialized), as well as workshops/information sessions elsewhere in the U.S. and overseas. 


40 to 60 professionals learn the basics of narrative practice, theory and methods.


Credit can be applied to future summer institute, or certificate. 


First workshop tentatively scheduled for October 2015.

Web-based Workshops (on-line) 

Five-hour web-based course.


A brief overview of narrative practice, with an introduction to our vision and methods.


Web-based workshops begin March 2016.

The Center believes that the need for narrative and creative training, and the benefit of narrative competency, cross all fields. To that end, in addition to interdisciplinary core training, the Center is designed to provide specialized concentration tracks in areas that we believe are of crucial importance to successful communication and community. Rather than teaching our students a specific discipline, our methods provide a tool kit that will expand, augment, improve, and, ultimately, transform the academic and professional experience.For almost two decades, the team behind the Center has been at the forefront of developing methods to understand, research, and teach narrative and creativity.  At the core of these methods is the practice of creativity and use of the imagination; the study and creation of literary work, film, theater, graphic novels, and other arts are fundamental threads in all of the tools we have developed, and the application of creativity is common throughout our methods.Close ReadingAlso referred to as “slow reading,” the act of reading something carefully—whether a poem, novel, short story, memoir or a painting, sonata, play—and attending to all aspects of its dimensionality—form, voice, temporality, diction, movement, space, etc.—teaches us to pay closer attention to all aspects of our world, and reveals the ways that attentive looking and listening can engage the complexity of human expression.Reflective and Creative WritingThis is writing with an eye toward discovery of new meanings and new forms, writing as a tool for expansion of the mind and spirit, and discovery of uncovered aspects of self and connections to colleagues. We will provide training through the discussion of writing in the language of text and constructive criticism. Narrative InterventionIn a situation where people are struggling due to perceived ownership of certain deeply held beliefs or concepts related to work environments, the use of narrative – stories that no one “owns” – can allow new elements to be seen and persons to re-connect and loosen their grip on whatever issues are troubling them.Critical Theory Narrative is our primary device for making sense of social action. The “Narrative Turn” in critical thinking takes as its starting point the fact that individuals, institutions, nations and cultures construct their identities by locating themselves within plotted stories. What’s more, drawing forth and attending to stories that have no place among the repertoire of “legitimate” narratives --those of the vulnerable or silenced-- require narrative skill.  Once we have raised the start-up funds, we begin the work of designing, recruiting and building a world-class center. Key action items include:Classroom SpaceWe will rent temporary meeting space for our first two years, with a goal of securing permanent classroom and office space by fall 2017. Advisory BoardWe will invite and convene an advisory board to meet by spring 2015. The advisory board will be comprised of leaders in the field of narrative theory and practice.FellowshipsWe will offer fellowships beginning in the 2016-2017 school year. The fellowships will be designed to support our graduates in their work.ProjectionsThe following details our three-year tuition and expense projections:A diverse group of scholars, artists, teachers and thinkers have come together to create the Center for Narrative Practice. All feel the power and potential of narrative and creativity for affecting change in the world, and believe in the need for an independent center in the service of narrative practice and theory. Spanning disciplines, genres, and interests, the leadership and faculty of the Center bring the unparalleled experience necessary to build a sustainable, world-class entity. LEADERSHIP Scott Alderman (Founding Director)Scott Alderman's career as an entrepreneur and organizer has taken him to the music business (as European road manager for Lionel Hampton, and a producer of festivals that have played at Giants Stadium and Red Rocks), to Wall Street ( Morgan Stanley), and to social services (working as a counselor at a residence for homeless people with AIDS). The common thread throughout these disparate industries and fields is the ability to successfully manage people, process, product, and technology. Since 2010, he has been the administrative director for the Program in Narrative Medicine at the Columbia University College of Physicians and Surgeons. Scott has a BA in literature/writing from Columbia University. Nellie Hermann, M.F.A.Nellie Hermann is creative Director of the Program in Narrative Medicine at Columbia University. She is a graduate of Brown University and the M.F.A. program at Columbia. Her first novel, The Cure for Grief (Scribner: 2008), received national acclaim in such publications as Time Magazine, Elle, The Washington Post, The Boston Globe, and others, and was chosen as a Target “Breakout” book. Hermann's short story "Can We Let the Baby Go?" won first prize in Glimmer Train's 2008 "Family Matters" competition and was published in the Winter, 2010 issue; another story of hers appeared in Glimmer Train in August, 2012. Her non-fiction has appeared in an anthology about siblings, Freud’s Blindspot (Free Press: 2010), as well as in Academic Medicine. Over the last eight years she has taught fiction and narrative medicine to undergraduates, medical students, graduate students, and clinicians of all sorts, and has given conference addresses in Iowa, California, Seoul, Korea, and elsewhere. Her second novel, The Season of Migration, is forthcoming in February 2015 with Farrar, Straus, and Giroux. Craig Irvine, Ph.DCraig Irvine is a founder and Academic Director of the Program in Narrative Medicine at Columbia University, and holds his Ph.D in Philosophy. For more than 15 years, he has been designing and teaching cultural competency, ethics, Narrative Medicine, and Humanities and Medicine curricula for residents, medical students, physicians, nurses, social workers, chaplains, dentists, and other health professionals. He has over 20 years of experience researching the history of philosophy, phenomenology, and narrative ethics, and over 25 years of experience teaching ethics, humanities, the history of philosophy, logic, and narrative medicine at the graduate, undergraduate, and preparatory school levels. He has published articles in the areas of ethics, residency education, and literature and medicine and has presented at numerous national and international conferences on these and other topics. Jack Saul, Ph.DJack Saul is Assistant Professor of Clinical Population and Family Health at Columbia University’s Mailman School of Public Health, and Founding Director of the International Trauma Studies Program an independent post-graduate training and research institute affiliated with Columbia University. As a psychologist he has created a number of programs for populations in New York City that have endured war, torture, and political violence, including the Bellevue/NYU Program for Survivors of Torture, REFUGE (Refugee Resource Center), Theater Arts Against Political Violence, the Post-9/11 Downtown Community Resource Center, and African Refuge. He consults with organizations on staff welfare in response to trauma-related work and has a private practice in Manhattan. His is the author of the recently published Collective Trauma, Collective Healing: Promoting Community Resilience in the Aftermath of Disaster (Routledge). Kristen Slesar, L.C.S.W., M.S.Kristen Slesar is a bilingual trauma-focused psychotherapist at the Child and Adolescent Witness Support Program and in private practice. She is also an adjunct faculty member of the Narrative Medicine Program at the College of Physicians and Surgeons of Columbia University and a consultant and trainer for the Graduate School of Applied Psychology of New York University and the New York City Alliance Against Sexual Assault. Kristen previously coordinated the Sexual Assault Forensic Examiner and Volunteer Advocate Programs at a major private hospital in New York City and managed a small basic center/shelter for homeless LGBTQ teens and young adults in Harlem. Kristen has a Bachelor's degree in Latin American Studies from Stanford University, a Master's of Social Work from New York University and a Master's of Science in Narrative Medicine from Columbia University. Maura Speigel, Ph.D.Maura Spiegel, Ph.D is Senior Lecturer of English and Comparative Literature at Columbia University, where she teaches courses on fiction and film, and is a founder and Associate Director of the Program in Narrative Medicine. She is the co-author of The Grim Reader: Writings on Death, Dying and Living On (Anchor/Doubleday), The Breast Book: An Intimate and Curious History (Workman), which was a Book-of-the-Month Club Quality Paperbacks selection. She co-edited the journal Literature and Medicine (Johns Hopkins University press) for seven years, has written for The New York Times, and has published essays on the history of the emotions, Charles Dickens, and diamonds in the movies, among many other topics. She is currently writing a book about the life and films of Sidney Lumet for St. Martin’s Press. FACULTY AND LECTURERS Chris Adrian, M.D., M.Div., M.F.A. has written three novels: Gob's Grief, The Children's Hospital, and The Great Night. In 2008, he published A Better Angel, a collection of short stories. His short fiction has also appeared in The Paris Review, Zoetrope, Ploughshares, McSweeney's, The New Yorker, The Best American Short Stories, and Story. He was one of 11 fiction writers to receive a Guggenheim Fellowship in 2009. He received his M.D. from Eastern Virginia Medical School in 2001, and completed a pediatric residency at the University of California, San Francisco. He received a Master of Divinity at Harvard Divinity School, and is also a graduate of the Iowa Writers' Workshop. Paul Lazar is a founding member and co-artistic director, along with Annie-B Parson, of Big Dance Theater. He has co-directed and acted in works for Big Dance since 1991, including commissions from the Brooklyn Academy of Music, The Walker Art Center, Dance Theater Workshop, Classic Stage Company and Japan Society. Paul is an Associate Member of The Wooster Group, acting in Brace Up!, Emperor Jones, North Atlantic and The Hairy Ape. He has acted in over 30 feature films, including The Host, Mickey Blue Eyes, Silence of the Lambs, Beloved, Lorenzo’s Oil, and Philadelphia, and will be in the next film by director Bong Joon Ho (The Host) called Snowpiercer. He currently teaches at New York University. David Small, M.F.A. was born and raised in Detroit, and received his MFA from Yale. His drawings have appeared regularly in The New Yorker and The New York Times, and his children’s books have been translated into several languages, and made into animated films and musicals. He is a 3-time Caldecott winner for The Gardener with Sarah Stewart, One Cool Friend with Toni Buzzeo, and So You Want to be President? with Judith St. George; a 2-time recipient of the Christopher Medal; as well as a Society of Illustrators Gold Medal winner. To date he has illustrated over 40 picture books. David’s graphic memoir, Stitches, about his problematic youth, was a New York Times Bestseller and was a finalist for a National Book Award. Betsy Sparrow, Ph.D is Assistant Professor of Psychology at Columbia University, and received her Ph.D in social psychology from Harvard University. Since the publication of her article The Google Effect: Consequences of Having Information at our Fingertips (Science, 2011), Betsy has been asking questions about what we are likely to remember when we look up information online. When are we most critical in our evaluation of what we learn online? Under what type of learning situations are we most likely to make creative leaps? Her work has gained her a reputation in academia as one of the important voices in research on the intersection of human cognition and technology She has written a review of the subject for two prestigious journals, and has gained considerable media attention (PBS, MSNBC, BBC, ABC News, the Colbert Report, plus all major international newsprint publications). Her work has drawn the interest of many corporations (Masie’s Learning, Shell, Humera) where she has given keynote addresses and led breakout sessions with people involved with corporate learning and internet technology creation. 
                          The future is in stories.                The future is through these doors.

story:
Coastal Cities: The Baltic Sea 

Polar Plunge Challenge

*******************************
We've met our goal!  With an additional $51 coming in during the January 1 New Year's Day Festivities, we reach $751.00.  Thank you to all who contributed!

*******************************

In spring of 2014, students from Alverno College will study the role of Lake Michigan in shaping urban development in Milwaukee. In May of 2014, Alverno College professors David Brooker and Jodi Eastberg will lead students to Gdansk, Poland, Kalmar and Malmö, Sweden, and Copenhagen, Denmark. The class will meet with local organizations, educational institutions and government entities to study the way these cities have developed and interacted with their coast.

The Coastal Cities POLAR PLUNGE CHALLENGE asks that you support one of our "Polar Bears" in their plunge into Lake Michigan on January 1, 2014. All funds donated will go to providing students additional coastal cities experiences while traveling.


How can you participate?

  1. Make your donation via this Indiegogo website using credit card or PayPal.
  2. When you donate, please make a comment indicating which bear you support
  3. Please also indicate "Plunge" or "Don't Plunge" in your comments.  This will indicate whether you would like David Brooker to participate in his polar bear induction ceremony OR if you'd like to save him from an icy swim.
  4. Stay tuned for New Year's Day revelations on whether David will make the plunge and for Weeathlon results from Jodi and Kyle.


The 2014 Coastal Cities Polar Bears

David Brooker

David is a Florida boy raised on the Gulf of Mexico.He has never seen the need to do the Polar Bear Plunge, even in the summer Lake Michigan is too cold for his Gulf-influenced taste.However, he is willing to give it a try if donors say he should.When you make a donation feel free to say “Plunge” or “Don’t Plunge”.If the “Plunge” donations are greater than the “Don’t Plunge” donations he will do it.


Kyle Cherek

Kyle Cherek was born in Waukesha, WI and raised by sensible, decent and generally pragmatic people.  The concept of willingly doing what was their most acerbic retort ('Go jump in a lake!') on one of the coldest days of the year is about as odd to them as trying to catch a baseball with an oven mitt.  He has never asked anyone to give money to a cause on behalf of his irrational behavior, but based on our current system of funding political office, it seems right in line. On warmer days he enjoys public television, sandals without socks, and longs walks on the beach. This will be his 5th Polar Bear Plunge.


Jodi Eastberg

Jodi is an eight-time "polar bear" and has never thought to ask people to pay her to do something she so enjoys.  She has often wondered what it is that compels her into Lake Michigan each year. In the past it has been the frisson of participating in local ritual, but this year she is "doing it for her students!" She is a native of Kansas and Arizona, but has called Milwaukee home since 1998.  Along with her polar bear plunge posse (pictured above), Jodi established the Weeathlon.  A great Milwaukee tradition, the Weeathlon purports to be the world's shortest triathlon. The event occurs every January 1st with a ride around the block, a run to the lake and a very, very short swim in Lake Michigan.  

Polar Plunge Plan

To participate:

  1. Make your donation via this Indiegogo website using credit card or PayPal.
  2. When you donate, please make a comment indicating which bear you support.
  3. Please also indicate "Plunge" or "Don't Plunge" in your comments.  This will indicate whether you would like David Brooker to participate in his polar bear induction ceremony OR if you'd like to save him from an icy swim.
  4. Stay tuned for New Year's Day revelations on whether David will make the plunge and for Weeathlon results from Jodi and Kyle.

Perks?

Of course!  

Donors at the $25+ level will receive a postcard from the Baltic Region sent during our travels.

Those donating at the $50+ level are invited to join us at Jodi's on January 1 for official Milwaukee Polar Plunge Weeathlon festivities.

If we reach our goal of $750 AND David is forced to plunge, we will send donors media documentation of David's polar bear induction.


Additional Resources

Interested in traveling or learning more about Alverno's Coastal Cities: Baltic Sea Trip?




Coastal Cities: Baltic Sea Telesis Enrollment Information CLICK HERE

story:
UPDATE: We have launched a new fundraising campaign to fund Synfig development for next month. Please check it out here.


Short Summary

Hello, my name is Konstantin Dmitriev. I am running this campaign to fund the development of Synfig - the free and opensource animation software.

I am mentoring a full-time developer Ivan Mahonin, who is working on Synfig code. We have funded his work in previous months by running similar fundraising campaigns for October, November, December and January.

Thanks to success of those campaigns, Ivan have implemented following features for Synfig:

- Frame-by-Frame animation (bitmap)


- Bones tools


See other demonstrations at our YouTube channel...

The success of this campaign will allow Ivan to work full-time for a whole month in February 2014.

Also, this campaign allows our users to directly influence the Synfig development by choosing development priorities. 

How?

Please read below.


"Choose Priority" perk

For a donation of fixed amount (see the perks on the right)  we offer to the donor an exceptional privilege to choose a priority of development.  So, we will spend next month working on the priority you defined. Of course, we can't promise any thing, so please select from the list below:

  • Bones development (continued, see pending tasks)
  • Frame-by-frame bitmap animation support (continued, see current status)
  • Rendering speed optimization
  • Sound support

NOTE: We don't guarantee the feature from a selected priority to be completely finished within a month. Such promises are not compatible with development realities. What we promise is to dedicate no less than 85% of our working time to developing this priority for a full month. Though, one month is a  significant period and such dedication would lead to significant changes in selected direction. Many our users are aware that we used to publish development snapshots regularly, so you will be able to benefit from development results as soon as possible.

EXAMPLE: As result of our earlier fundraising campaign, we got sold the "Choose priority" perk for October. The priority chosen by donor was "Single-window UI". You can see results in this video.

"Development OS" perk

By default we use Linux operation system (OS) for daily development (because we love Linux). As result, the Linux version of Synfig is the most polished, because it goes through daily proof.

But, for a fixed-amount donation (see the perks on the right) you can make us shift to other OS for next month. So, if we will use the OS of your choice in our daily development, then obviously  the Synfig version will be especially polished to work on it: daily proof => more testing => less bugs => better stability.

No worries, this perk doesn't mean we drop support for other operation systems. It's just a question of choosing the OS for daily development.

At the moment the only OS available for choice is Windows.

Other perks

We understand that there are people who would like to support our efforts by other means. Specially for them we prepared other perks to express our gratitude:

  • Synfig Training Package. You can get our Synfig training course at exclusively low price. Comparing to regular "pay-what-you-want" download, you get a direct assistance from the course instructors and all future updates are also included. We will ship a coupon code for you which you can use to access the training by yourself or present as a gift to someone.  The package is available in English and Russian.
  • Tutorial video. A tutorial video about Synfig for ANY given theme. Length is limited to 5 minutes.  Languages can be English or Russian. Video will be publicly available for everyone. The tutorial video will be produced by Nikolai Mamashev, who was in charge for producing Synfig Training Package.
  • Report sponsor. You can track the progress of the development by reading my weekly reports. If you claim this perk, then one of my weekly reports will be indicated as sponsored by you with an (optional) link to your website. The mention will look as "This report is sponsored by: ..." text at the top of the report text.
  • Sponsor logo. Your logo displayed for one month at the front page of Synfig website.

Who is behind this campaign

Konstantin Dmitriev. This is me. I am the person who is responsible for distributing collected funds and  mentoring the development process. I am an open-source activist with a special profile for animation. The range of my activities include expertize, development and popularization of free software animation solutions.


You can see following my works made as animator purely with free software:

  • Morevna Project: Demo
  • “Persona” Tomato Paste commercial
  • Morevna Project: Production Cuts

Also I have a profile in education by teaching animation to kids using libre and opensource tools. Here are some of the works made by my students:

  • The Adventures of Boris Munchausen
  • Amazing Sentence

The sources for many of the works above are freely available under the Creative Commons license.

Ivan Mahonin. He is a professional C/C++ developer, hired to work on Synfig code. You can track current Ivan's contributions to Synfig on this page.

Nikolai Mamashev. He is a "wizard of Synfig", awesome artist who use free software only. If you are user Synfig, then you know at least one his work - the current splash screen is created by him. He is known as lead artist in Morevna Project: Demo, also it worths to look at his portfolio. Nikolai is in charge for providing artistic support for us, proof testing and tutorials production.

The Impact

With this campaign we would like to provide a way to control the direction of development and support vitality of Synfig development at the same time.  Users can choose the priorities and all collected funds will go to support further sustainable development of Synfig. It's fair and benefit is for everyone - we all get better free animation software.

You can track the results of our work by reading my weekly reports.

Also, we are open to consider other models of funding for Synfig. If you are would like to sponsor the implementation of particular feature - please contact us (see the comments tab at the top).

Other ways you can help

For the people, who would like to give as direct and regular support there is an option to subscribe. Please check out this page for details - http://www.synfig.org/cms/en/news/taking-one-step-away-from-crowdfunding/.

Thank you!

development and popularization of free software animation solutions. You can see following my works made as animator purely with free software:

Morevna Project: Demo
“Persona” Tomato Paste commercial
Morevna Project: Production Cuts
Also I have a profile in education by teaching animation to kids 
using libre and opensource tools. Here are some of the works made by my 
students:

The Adventures of Boris Munchausen
Amazing Sentence
The sources
 for many of the works above are freely available under the Creative Commons license.
Ivan Mahonin. He is a professional C/C++ developer, hired to work on Synfig code. You can track current Ivan's contributions to Synfig on this page.
Nikolai Mamashev. He is a "wizard of Synfig", awesome artist 
who use free software only. If you are user Synfig, then you know at 
least one his work - the current splash screen is created by him. He is known as lead artist in Morevna Project: Demo, also it worths to look at his portfolio. Nikolai is in charge for providing artistic support for us, proof testing and tutorials production.The ImpactWith this campaign we would like to provide a way to control the direction of development and support vitality of Synfig development at the same time.  Users can choose the priorities and all collected funds will go to support further sustainable development of Synfig. It's fair and benefit is for everyone - we all get better free animation software.You can track the results of our work by reading my weekly reports.Also, we are open to consider other models of funding for Synfig. If you are would like to sponsor the implementation of particular feature - please contact us (see the comments tab at the top).Other ways you can helpFor the people, who would like to give as direct and regular support there is an option to subscribe. Please check out this page for 
details - http://www.synfig.org/cms/en/news/taking-one-step-away-from-crowdfunding/.Thank you!

story:
Who am I?

I am currently on a gap year before heading to university. I have always planned to have a 'useful' gap year, and so I am heading overseas later in 2014 to undertake a number of voluntary internships in the law and human rights field, interspersed with learning experiences that I have chosen to take myself out of my comfort zone, such as martial arts and meditation training, and a small amount of travel. 

I am working multiple jobs to save money for my dream adventure, but sometimes it feels like there aren't enough hours in the day to earn the full amount! Any contribution that you make brings me closer to fulfilling my goals, and will be greatly appreciated!

What will I be doing?

I'm heading to China, Thailand, Sri Lanka, Greece, Ghana, and Spain this year - help me get there!

I'm really excited to head to China, given my ambitions to speak fluent mandarin! The first part of my dream gap year is focused on trying things that I never would have considered previously. In line with this, I plan to spend time studying mandarin and martial arts in Zhenjiang, China, arranged through realgap.

In Thailand I'll be continuing on that theme of things I had never considered before! I plan to spend 10 days on a strict Vipassana meditation retreat in Kanchanaburi. I can't imagine a more intense and (hopefully) fascinating experience, and am both excited and a little apprehensive at the idea.

In Sri Lanka, I will be volunteering in a law firm in Negombo, shadowing local lawyers and magistrates, editing and proofreading legal documents and generally assisting in the legal practice. I am really excited to assist in the Godfrey Cooray and Associates Law firm and learn from them.
This work experience internship has been arranged through Travellers Worldwide, and more information can be accessed here.

Greece, it's mythology, history and culture, has fascinated me for as long as I can remember. This part of the trip is the most purely 'travel-based', as I plan on joining a tour that will take me from Athens to Delphi, Olympia, Meteora and Santorini. 

And from Greece to Ghana, where it's back to volunteering. This time, I'll be working as a Law and Human Rights intern (here's the program) with Projects Abroad. The more I read about Ghana, the more intrigued I become. It's one of the most stable and democratic countries on the African continent, with from what I can see an incredibly vibrant culture that I can't wait to experience.


This time, returning to Spain after my exchange year in Navarra two years ago, I'm going South instead of North, to the beautiful city of Seville. I'll be doing anintensive Spanish for Business course, as I am trying to brush up on my Spanish skills and ensure that they are relevant to a professional context. There are so many places I want to visit in and around Seville, so I am beyond excited to spend some time there!

I have left Spain until last so that if by some miracle I have some extra cash at the end of my trip, I can use it to hang out here!

What I Need & What You Get

The total cost for my gap year will be more than $15,000, and so my goal is to supplement the money I earn in my two jobs as much as possible!

  • Any funding I receive will go towards covering the costs of the programs in Sri Lanka, Ghana and Spain, as well as flights
  • Contributors can claim rewards based on my travels, including access to my 'famous' email blog, personalised postcards, surprise presents, homecooked food, and much much more!

Other Ways You Can Help

Even if you can't contribute, you can still help me out! You could:

  • Share my campaign with friends, family and colleagues
  • Send me your love and luck! Heading overseas by myself is going to be intimidating, challenging and exhilarating, all well-wishing is appreciated!

Thank you!

story:
Who I am

I was born and raised as the second child to a family belonging to the Bhutia tribe in Mussoorie, a small town in the Himalayas, India. In childhood I grew up in a family that was struggling to make ends meet but knew how to celebrate life king-size, we always had great music! Being inspired by the music and dance at a very young age, I knew that I wanted to live my life on a stage, and that creating, performing and telling stories was my true calling. I would seize every opportunity to perform and entertain. I was a member of my school and college rock band and had created a contemporary dance society in my school and university with which I got a chance to travel and perform all over India. In India, there are not many schools that offer a holistic education in the field of dance( ballet/contemporary) and dance alone is not encouraged as a sole profession to pursue.

I graduated from my high school in 2004 and moved to capital city- New Delhi to pursue my college education. It was here that it started becoming clear to me that I would do whatever it takes to fulfill my childhood dream.

After singing in bars on the weekends and working in a dance company 7days a week in New Delhi for over six years where I performed, choreographed and taught jazz dance, I decided to take my educational and professional pursuits to the next level. As I educated myself about the works of world famous artists and companies and recognized the potential of art to make a global impact, I knew that I had to find a way to train myself on an international level and perform and collaborate with artists from diverse backgrounds professionally I did my part to facilitate this vision, I auditioned and got selected into a professional dance and music training program at Peridance Capezio Centre and with the love and support of my family I came to New York City in 2012.

As I began training in a rigorous schedule of ballet, modern and contemporary dance classes, to further develop my artistic voice I simultaneously engaged in a five-month Choreographic Investigation Course from Dance New Amsterdam NYC. In the past two years I have been fortunate enough to work with some brilliant artists and have performed on some of the prime stages in New York, such as Lincoln Centre, Manhattan Movement and Arts Centre, Ellen Stewart Theatre LaMaMa, Peridance Capezio Theatre, St Marks Church, City Centre Studios, Dance New Amsterdam Theatre. I have also received a full scholarship at the Sheppard Academy of Vocal Arts NYC directed by Bettina Sheppard. As a student I have had exceptional luck with finding the right teachers and mentors who have taught and guided me so generously. Currently, I am enjoying being part of ChristinaNoel & The Creature Company, General Mischief Dance Theatre, TNSP and Overground Arts Allliance. When I look back at myself as a child belting away to the songs of Dylan,U2, Bruce Springsteen, Nusrat Fateh Ali Khan to name a few, imitating the dance moves of all the TV stars or sitting in the small room of my first music teacher, singing indian raagas as she played the harmonium... I feel like no dream is impossible no matter where you come from, as long as its consistently and fearlessly pursued.

My Goal

1-My artistic goal is to create work using the elements of musical theatre in a contemporary context and compose my own music for the same. I desire to tell stories of true life experiences and take my audience on an emotional, intellectual and holistic journey. I would then travel with my repertoire and perform on stages all over the world sharing my work and creation with as many people as I can. 

2-I will also create a dance school in India through which I shall share my learning and my craft with my students. Also I wish to develop dance educational programs and introduce them to schools and universities that are open to the idea of incorporating the value of dance and creativity in every level of education. My school will provide a nurturing environment where people can discover, express and create freely and fearlessly. 

3-I shall host Artist Residencies in my hometown where indigenous artists, artists from the cities and international artists can collaborate and create, learn and teach workshops and in turn promote cultural exchange. I’d like to name this residency “The Artist Pit-stop". There shall be weekly/ monthly shows in this space where local artists(dancers, musicians, poets,writers,film makers, etc) can share their work and talent with the people of their hometown.

4-These artists will then travel together all over India(and eventually abroad) with their works created in "The Artist Pit-stop" workshops and perform on various platforms. This way the international visitors would't  just come to India to one small town,but also get to travel and absorb the indian experience ;-)! 

5- Dance is also a very powerful means of healing and self discovery. Therefore, I plan to work with expressive arts therapists/dance movement therapists/ body work specialists and ask them to join forces with me to promote and educate on the possibilities of the maturing field of expressive art therapies.

The Impact of your Contribution-

 With your help and support I shall be able to put myself through school and acquire the qualification, knowledge and experience that it takes to create the kind of work that I want to and share it with my audience, other artists and my students in India. Your contribution will help me build the network and support that I would much need for my artistic endeavor and spread the seeds of dance and creativity around the world. The MFA from Hollins University will also teach me how to fund, promote and efficiently shape my ideas for my work, my vision for my school and the artist residency and a deeper understanding what goes into making a successful organization. I also get a chance to go to Frankfurt and work with the William Forsythe Company and the University of Music and Performing Arts this summer! Form my experience in New York, I have learnt that many dancers, teachers, choreographers and facilitators wish to visit India to share their work and also learn the Indian art forms. Whereas in India, young dancers are becoming more aware of the new forms of contemporary dance practices, mind body approaches and improvisational methods of collaborating and creating but don't really have proper means to receive such education and training and can only rely on the internet for information. Through my school and the artist residencies, the young aspiring dancers and artists of India can widen their exposure by receiving first hand education and training from these International artists and teachers and in return share their artistry with them. As an artist in todays’ world, I believe that one has to be very open minded and be willing to learn from different art forms and cultures of the world. I am a strong believer in cultural exchange and have always been interested in all the nuances and colors of all art forms and cultures, which is also one of the main reasons why I chose the city of New York. You can be from any part of the world and find yourself at home in this city because of its diversity.

To give you a brief idea, this is the link to the courses I will be taking in my MFA.

http://www.hollins.edu/grad/dance/documents/dance.pdf

Current Situation-

My MFA begins this summer 6th of June 2014. It is a one year 60 credit course that would cost me  $50,520 US dollars. It is divided into four semesters costing about $13,500 each.

I have been fortunate enough to be granted a fellowship of $13005, which will be divided into four equal parts for all four semesters.

I'm taking it as a good sign from the universe and doing the best that I can to listen, believe and follow.

Other Ways You Can Help

1.    You can ask your friends or family folks who you think could contribute by getting the word out and sharing or posting the link to my campaign on your FB pages/twitter/email.

2.    You can write to me at gautamnemo@hotmail.com and send me your wishes, your positive energy and your love.

3.    Every little contribution counts!! I have about 45 whole days and even if you choose to donate a $ everyday it will amount to 45$ at the end of it and if its 10$...450$!! J

story:
Short Summary

Four years ago, anti-sex traffic worker and Buddhist monk Waha Long decided he was tired of seeing the subsistence rice farmers of  Sambat Village miss out on Cambodia's economic growth simply because they could not speak English. Determined to offer a better future to Sambat's children, Waha built the Cambodian Underprivileged School to offer free English lessons to the village's children. Working with a small number of textbooks and the few English-speaking tourists he could convince to come to Sambat for a day or two at a time, Waha strives to teach the children enough English to find employment in Cambodia's booming tourist industry.

Now, Waha is dreaming bigger. He wants to build a 5-computer room to expedite English-language acquisition through videos, interactive teaching tools, and independently paced lessons. As anybody who has ever learned a foreign language knows, these are vital tools in language acquisition. For Waha's students, the difference they could make might be that between a life in the rice fields and one of the many jobs available for English speakers in the tourist industry. 

What We Need & What You Get

Waha needs $4,000 to build the computer room. This includes material and labor for the actual building itself, and five used computers. If fewer funds are raised, Waha will:

-Build the room with fewer computers ($3,000)

-Hire a second English teacher for however many months the funds raised allow ($150/month)

All contributors will receive a thank-you email and picture from the schoolchilren, sent from the computers you've helped to fund! Those who contribute $49 can watch the English of one of the students improve through bi-monthly email updates. Donors of $250+ will have their names or the name of their choice written on the building. 

Other Ways You Can Help

For those unable to contribute, you can still help!

-Spread the word through social media and email to those who can!

-Write to Lonely Planet Cambodia and tell them to list the Cambodia Underpriveleged School as a worthwhile day-trip from Siem Reap

My Background

Because of he has irregular access to the internet and difficulty navigating it, I have set this page up for Waha (who you can email at  sambatvillage@gmail.com, but response times may vary). As for me, I am a 21-year old college student who spent three wonderful days teaching (and learning!) at the Underprivileged School in August 2012, and have assorted human rights experience from environmental to  LGBT to anti-torture advocacy. 

Unfortunately the camera I was working with died while I was trying to make a video of the school, so none is uploaded here. I have lots of pictures of the school and surrounding area if you'd like to see!

story:
The Cause

Primary school in much of the developing world is free; secondary school is not. Every year, thousands of 7th grade students pass the exam qualifying them for secondary school, but are unable to complete their education due to school fees which average around $150/year.

We are a group of students from New York City hoping to help out. We became invested in this cause when Udacity.com, a free online education website, initiated a challenge among members to recruit as many new users to the site as possible. Our recruitment team is called Team NYC (click the link to join our team for free and help us achieve our goal), and we are striving to have an impact beyond just increased awareness for free, quality educational opportunities online.

For every class unit a Team NYC member completes on Udacity, we are raising money from sponsors across the world to help qualifying but underfinanced students in the developing world afford an education. That means you can also help us raise funding without donating yourself, by signing up for Udacity, joining our team and completing as many units as you can. There are currently free courses with ranging difficulty taught by world-class professors about Computer Science, Science, and Mathematics. 

But funding from these sponsors alone may not be enough to hit our goal: financing a year's worth of education for 15 deserving students who can't afford the ~$150 tuition. To truly make a difference, we need your help.

What We Need

We need roughly $2,250 to be able to pay the tuition fees of 15 students in need. We are working with The School Fund to select truly outstanding students who are in desperate need of your help. All of the money we raise will go directly to these students (please note that upon donating, IndieGogo charges a small fee of their own).

The Impact

Here is an example of the type of student you will be helping by donating to our cause:

Shangwe is a student at Lugalo Secondary School graduating in 2011. He lives with his aunt and uncle because his mother died in 1998 and his father couldn't take care of him. Shangwe is an incredible student who enjoys all subjects, but he is mainly interested in physics and chemistry. Along with his best friend Yasini, Shangwe hopes to become a doctor in order to help the thousands in Tanzania who are sick and don't have access to medical help. Shangwe and Yasini do all their homework together, and put studying as their absolute top priority.

Other Ways You Can Help

Even if you can't afford to contribute, there are other ways to help! The single most beneficial alternative step you can take is joining Team NYC on Udacity and competing as many units as possible. This earns us funding from sponsors we have found who are donating on a per-unit-completed basis, so you will effectively be donating without paying any money yourself (and you will also be learning some pretty fascinating things in an course of your choosing along the way). If you are already a member of Udacity and on a different team, you can still join Team NYC; there will be a button to leave your current team and join a new one when you follow the link above.

After / apart from joining the team yourself, you can also share this IndieGogo campaign and our team sign-up link (www.tinyurl.com/udacitynyc) with your friends and family. The more people who join or donate, the more students whose lives we can change.

Let's make a difference together

The future of these students is in your hands. Help us help them, and donate to our cause / sign up for Team NYC today.
story_txt:
The Cause
Primary school in much of the developing world is free; secondary school is not. Every year, thousands of 7th grade students pass the exam qualifying them for secondary school, but are unable to complete their education due to school fees which average around $150/year.
We are a group of students from New York City hoping to help out. We became invested in this cause when Udacity.com, a free online education website, initiated a challenge among members to recruit as many new users to the site as possible. Our recruitment team is called Team NYC (click the link to join our team for free and help us achieve our goal), and we are striving to have an impact beyond just increased awareness for free, quality educational opportunities online.
For every class unit a Team NYC member completes on Udacity, we are raising money from sponsors across the world to help qualifying but underfinanced students in the developing world afford an education. That means you can also help us raise funding without donating yourself, by signing up for Udacity, joining our team and completing as many units as you can. There are currently free courses with ranging difficulty taught by world-class professors about Computer Science, Science, and Mathematics. 
But funding from these sponsors alone may not be enough to hit our goal: financing a year's worth of education for 15 deserving students who can't afford the ~$150 tuition. To truly make a difference, we need your help.


What We Need
We need roughly $2,250 to be able to pay the tuition fees of 15 students in need. We are working with The School Fund to select truly outstanding students who are in desperate need of your help. All of the money we raise will go directly to these students (please note that upon donating, IndieGogo charges a small fee of their own).


The Impact
Here is an example of the type of student you will be helping by donating to our cause:
Shangwe is a student at Lugalo Secondary School graduating in 2011. He lives with his aunt and uncle because his mother died in 1998 and his father couldn't take care of him. Shangwe is an incredible student who enjoys all subjects, but he is mainly interested in physics and chemistry. Along with his best friend Yasini, Shangwe hopes to become a doctor in order to help the thousands in Tanzania who are sick and don't have access to medical help. Shangwe and Yasini do all their homework together, and put studying as their absolute top priority.


Other Ways You Can Help
Even if you can't afford to contribute, there are other ways to help! The single most beneficial alternative step you can take is joining Team NYC on Udacity and competing as many units as possible. This earns us funding from sponsors we have found who are donating on a per-unit-completed basis, so you will effectively be donating without paying any money yourself (and you will also be learning some pretty fascinating things in an course of your choosing along the way). If you are already a member of Udacity and on a different team, you can still join Team NYC; there will be a button to leave your current team and join a new one when you follow the link above.
After / apart from joining the team yourself, you can also share this IndieGogo campaign and our team sign-up link (www.tinyurl.com/udacitynyc) with your friends and family. The more people who join or donate, the more students whose lives we can change.
Let's make a difference together
The future of these students is in your hands. Help us help them, and donate to our cause / sign up for Team NYC today.

story:
We will make and give away Custom Hand Made Hula Hoops to girls in domestic violence shelters. We know how it feels to be in a shelter during the holiday season but we were fortunate enough to find a vise that made us smile- hula hoops. We now hoop for Health, Happiness, Fitness and Fun.

This is the first cause my children are spearheading themselves. I am encouraging them to be humanitarians- thus being of service to others, making a difference in other peoples lives, giving without expecting anything back in return and this helps them stay humble while also cultivating compassion and sensitivity in them at an early age.

 

What we need and what you get    

  My children's goal isn't to raise a one-time sum of $500 to purchase the needed equipment and materials to make the hula hoops and other perks; the ULTIMATE goal is to get a customer base to support their business by purchasing their products and using 10% of the profits to make more gifts for less  privileged children.                   

 

There's a unique perk for each contribution.

$1 contribution;

You will receive a Certificate of Appreciation naming you as a Financial Contributor to the Operastion Smile. It's downloadable, printable and suitble for framing.

$5 contribution;

You will get a small sample jar of Our Special Handmade Blend Honey Whipped Body Butter!

$17 contribution;

We'll send you Our special blend handmade 4oz. Body Meringue and Our 4 oz. All Natural Honey Whipped Body Butter. (essential oil scents; Patchouli, Cinnamon, Vanilla, Ginger. Mandarin, Peppermint, Lavender. Please indicate which scent you want.)

$20 contribution;

You will get an Interchangeable Magnet Bottle Cap Necklace with Ten Glass Inserts.

$25 contribution;

We will send you Any ONE flavor COOKIE MIX in a reusable and resealable 16 oz Kerr brand wide mouth mason jar. All you have to do is add 2 eggs and bake for 7-8 minutes! Makes up to 48 two inch cookies bake as much as you like and store the rest all for just $25 (that includes shipping)! 

$30 contribution;

We will send you our homemade disks of Creamy Sugar Cookie Dough enrobed in a Dark Chocolate coating and adorned with a rainbow of colored sprinkles. (eggless)

$45 contribution;

We'll send you our handmade special blend 8 oz. Foaming Bath Butter and Our 8 oz. All Natural Honey Whipped Body Butter with a Body Pouf. (essential oil scents; Patchouli, Cinnamon, Vanilla, Ginger. Mandarin, Peppermint, Lavender. Please indicate which scent you want.)

$75 contribution;

An EMBOSSED/PARCHMENT Certificate Of Appreciation naming you as a Financial Contributor to the Operation Smile with a GOLD SEAL mailed to you. A Decorative Commemorative Pin honoring your prticipation. And a downloadable digital copy of "The Making of the Hula Hoops for Operation Smiles" with your name in the credits.

 

** My children are youth entrepreneurs, they will be making the hula hoops, cookie dough, bath & body butters, and magnet bottle top necklaces by hand. (to read testimonials on their products please visit their facebook page by cicking on StarShineOrganics)

 

What is Hoopdancing Good For?

My youth entrepreneurs want to get more involved with the community. They want to also be the cause of a smile. With your contributions they will be able to do just that. While we were in a shelter we lerned these facts about hula hooping- most of it from experience.

Spiritual and Physical Benefits;

  • More reviving than a short nap,

  • Relieves stress.

  • Clears and calms the mind,

  • Uplifts and elevates mood upon use,

  • Helps one achieve deep feelings of empowerment, beauty and grace,

  • Enhances functional movement, muscle tone and flexibility.

  • Strengthens and Tones major muscles including abdomen, thighs, buttocks and upper body such as upper arms and back,
  • Stimulates heart rate, increases circulation, blood flow, and cerebral spinal fluid movement,

  • Creates a sense of balance in the body.

  • Improves posture by elongating muscles and stretching the spine,

  • Increases mobility, stability, balance and postural strength,

  • Slows the degeneration of the musculoskeletal system,

  • Reduces stress, tension, anxiety and pain in the body,

  • Reduce and prevent back pain,

  • Improves your coordination,

  • One of the easiest and most fun methods of weight loss,  

  • Helps increase the flow of blood to the brain.


We have had a table at the Saturday Market for the past two summers selling our body butters, hula hoops, sweet treats, and more.
Our body butters have been selling online for the past month and we will also have them in local stores.
Please help my children make a difference in the lives of other children.

Other Ways You Can Help

Some people just can’t contribute, but that doesn’t mean you can’t help:

Help us get the word out and make some noise about our campaign.

Use the Indiegogo share tools!

And that’s all there is to it. Let's help make them smile.

story:
Octavia Sydnor is a young, accomplished African American student-musician from St. Louis, Missouri whose instrument of choice is the violin.  Though she comes from a disadvantaged upbringing and background, Octavia has worked hard for her entire life, practicing daily in the hope of earning her college degree.

Recently, she auditioned for and was accepted to the prestigious New York University Steinhardt School of Music for Fall 2012, but all could be for naught if Octavia is unable to find the money in time to fund her education.  Please help me get her to school by making whatever contribution you can to help this deserving young person meet her very urgent financial need.

We need the village to help.  Thank you, in advance for any assistance you can provide Octavia, and for spreading the word. 

Sincerely,

Ronald E. Childs

story:
The P.I. Museum

The P.I. Museum is the world’s only museum dedicated to locating, acquiring, preserving, researching and sharing historic treasures from P.I. History.  www.pimuseum.org   Private Investigator Ben Harroll has, for over 40 years, collected a vast number of historic treasures and artifacts representing the investigative profession.

Conceived in the Spring of 1978, the P.I. Museum began when Ben first opened Gaslamp Quarter Investigations in San Diego, CA.  The original office for his investigative firm held period décor from three eras: 1890’s, the 1940’s and contemporary.

In collecting items for these offices, Ben began a lifetime endeavor toward collecting items of historical significance and authenticity from these three eras.

The P.I. Museum On Wheels

The P.I. Museum On Wheels is a special project of the P.I. Museum.  Among the purposes of this project is to inform, educate and entertain those who would ordinarily not have the opportunity to visit the P.I. Museum in person.  To achieve this goal, the PI Museum On Wheels will travel with selected items from the museum's vast collection of P.I. History memorabilia to major cities across America.

The P.I. Museum On Wheels was designed to travel to private investigator conferences around the country, displaying a select number of the museum's historic treasures and artifacts on the sides of the vehicle.  In addition, industry sponsors of the P.I. Museum On Wheels are presented on the back of the vehicle.  The entire rear window is capable of being rendered into a flat-screen television for the purpose of presenting informative and entertaining content about P.I. History.

Boston 2012 – International Investigation and Security Professionals Symposium

The P.I. Museum On Wheels will be traveling from San Diego to Boston, making stops in many major cities along the way, for an unprecedented private investigative conference taking place in September 2012.  Investigators and security professionals from around the world, from two major associations, are converging in Boston.  Here is a link to the website for the conference:  http://www.wad-conference.com.  A perfect place to share P.I. history, as well as on the road driving from town to town, along this country’s highways.

You will be making a positive contribution to the P.I. Museum and the P.I. Museum On Wheels by becoming a sponsoring member.  By selecting the membership category of your choice, you not only become a supporting member of the museum, but are helping to fund the P.I. Museum On Wheels U.S.A. Tour.

Support P.I. Museum On Wheels and Together We'll Make P.I. History

The P.I. Museum On Wheels has budgeted approximately $10,000 to fund its roundtrip travel between San Diego, CA and Boston, MA.  Specifically, these funds go toward fuel, occasional lodging, food, maintenance, and the costs associated with attending the conference.  In addition, the P.I. Museum is always on the lookout for additional historically important artifacts and treasures to add to its extensive, 40 year collection.

Each P.I. Museum membership entitles the recipient to a P.I. Museum Membership Certificate, a personal telephone call from private investigator Ben Harroll, and an increasing number of special gifts with the Duffy and Vidocq memberships.

Many dream of living the life of a private investigator, emulating Jim Rockford, Magnum and Sherlock Holmes, while following in the footsteps of Eugene Vidocq, Allan Pinkerton, and William J. Burns.  It’s quite an honor to be a member of the profession, but for those who have chosen other careers, or for those still discovering their dreams, this is a great way to support this honorable profession, while your name is placed alongside the many private detective legends of P.I. History.

 

Current Sponsors - As seen on the P.I. Museum On Wheels

P.I. Magazine - http://www.pimagazine.com

P.I. Gear - http://www.pigear.com

P.I. Book Store - http://www.pistore.com/

CALI - California Association of Licensed Investigators - http://www.cali-pi.org

NCISS - National Council of Investigation & Security Services - http://www.nciss.org/

Merlin Information Services - http://www.merlindata.com

SIU - Special Investigative University - http://www.siuniv.com/

World Association of Detectives - http://www.wad.net

 

Video created by Jimmie Mesis, Editor-in-Chief & Publisher of P.I. Magazine

story:
Campaign Summary

Hello and thanks for visiting our campaign.  We are Alison Schofield and Francesca McGeary-educational consultants with a big idea to create a new technology-based learning platform that will provide a new model for K-12 education. 

Our world has become collaborative and interactive.  New technologies are shaping the way that we communicate, learn and share ideas.  We now have the ability to create amazing impact in the world by harnessing technology to personalize education, distribute it openly and allow equal access for everyone.  In order to spread this learning innovation and allow it to be adopted easily and quickly, we believe that it needs to be free for all users. 

This project is a not-for-profit initiative.  It will see us hire a team of experts to help develop the web-based platform and create the content. The platform will be highly flexible in that it can be incorporated into traditional schools (public, private), village communities, homeschooling families and even NGO’s.  As long as there is Internet availability, the platform can be accessed. 

Both of us come from teaching backgrounds and have worked with diverse groups of students:  those with disabilities, gifted and talented, language-learners, children affected by war or trauma as well as mainstream students from kindergarten to high-school.  We are also entrepreneurs with our own consulting company, IngeniousEd., and have managed several challenging projects and teams of people.   

We’ve been working on the plans and framework for this project over the last year.  We’re now ready to get the project off the ground and start funding it.  With your support and contributions, we will be able to turn our vision into a reality.  Our goal is to have a working model up-and-running after one year. 

 

What we Need:

Phase 1:

  • We need to raise $1,000,000 to develop this project on a large-scale in order to meet the goal of having a working model ready for use in one year.  We want to do it in 30 days for the maximum impact!
  • We need supporters to contribute and share this campaign with their friends, colleagues and networks.
  • We need to spread the word about this campaign across the international media and press to build awareness.  If you can help us to do this, we would greatly appreciate it.

 

Phase 2:

  • We will create a registered, non-profit entity in order to continue to build on the project as well as create a transparent and structured framework.
  • We will develop an open-translation component where volunteers will translate content into various languages.
  • We will manage a team of volunteers to act as virtual “facilitators” to support students in their learning.
  • We will continue to explore and implement fundraising initiatives as well as look at implementing revenue models for long-term sustainability. 

 

Impact of the Project

Last year, we gave a presentation to a group of educators and asked the question, “What do great organizations like Google ‘grow’?”  People were quick to identify “talent”, “product excellence” and “culture of innovation”.  When we posed the next question, “What do schools grow?” people went quiet.  They could immediately recognize that schools (as-a-whole) are not talent-growing organizations, nor do they breed a “culture of innovation”.  Schools grow “test scores” but they don’t do it very effectively if you just have a look at the statistics. 

We whole-heartedly believe that our schools and education systems could be much better.  We know that children are multi-dimensional people who should not be reduced to “test scores”.  Everyone has inherent talents and interests that need to be nurtured.  As Sir Ken Robinson said:

“We have to recognize that human flourishing is not a mechanical process; it's an organic process. And you cannot predict the outcome of human development. All you can do, like a farmer, is create the conditions under which they will begin to flourish.” 

Through our EdTech platform, we want each child to uncover their talents and flourish.  We want them to find their niche in the world and develop a love for the process of learning, not only the end result.  Once children have completed their K-12 learning, they will have come to understand a great deal about themselves:  their strengths, their weaknesses and where their true interests lie.  They will also have explored several types of careers first-hand through their project work and even work-placements.

Even children with special learning needs will be able to use our platform because it will allow them to learn at their own pace and in a way that they learn best.  Every child will have a place because we will not force “square pegs” into “round holes”.  We recognize that everyone has something to contribute to the world in their own unique way.

Students will learn through interesting projects that have real-world applications.  They will set their own learning paths and define their goals and outcomes.  They will use all of the technologies available to help them research, discover, create and design.  Imagine the impact on learning where one child in the USA conferences with another child in Kenya through Skype, to find out about “endangered species”.  The task of “comparing and contrasting” will take on a whole new meaning for those children.  Students will also be able to share their ideas and work with others through our built-in social network.  Their work will be assessed and monitored with the platform analytics as well as through self-assessment, peer assessment and even experts in their community.  

Our platform will also allow others to contribute projects.  For example, we might have a marine biologist create and submit a project about “marine biodiversity”.  With their expertise in the field, students will gain a valuable experience while the biologist also gains social value from having contributed to the education of young people.

We are committed to making this project happen.  With the support of like-minded people, we know that great things can happen! Please help us achieve our goal by donating whatever you can and by sharing this campaign with all of your contacts.  You can also join our Facebook page and Twitter for daily updates and more information about this Project.  Thank you for your support! 

Find the profiles of Alison and Francesca here:  http://bit.ly/Xih9mG
