We will develop an open-translation component where volunteers will translate content into various languages.
We will manage a team of volunteers to act as virtual “facilitators” to support students in their learning.
We will continue to explore and implement fundraising initiatives as well as look at implementing revenue models for long-term sustainability. 
 
Impact of the Project
Last year, we gave a presentation to a group of educators and asked the question, “What do great organizations like Google ‘grow’?”  People were quick to identify “talent”, “product excellence” and “culture of innovation”.  When we posed the next question, “What do schools grow?” people went quiet.  They could immediately recognize that schools (as-a-whole) are not talent-growing organizations, nor do they breed a “culture of innovation”.  Schools grow “test scores” but they don’t do it very effectively if you just have a look at the statistics. 
We whole-heartedly believe that our schools and education systems could be much better.  We know that children are multi-dimensional people who should not be reduced to “test scores”.  Everyone has inherent talents and interests that need to be nurtured.  As Sir Ken Robinson said:
“We have to recognize that human flourishing is not a mechanical process; it's an organic process. And you cannot predict the outcome of human development. All you can do, like a farmer, is create the conditions under which they will begin to flourish.” 
Through our EdTech platform, we want each child to uncover their talents and flourish.  We want them to find their niche in the world and develop a love for the process of learning, not only the end result.  Once children have completed their K-12 learning, they will have come to understand a great deal about themselves:  their strengths, their weaknesses and where their true interests lie.  They will also have explored several types of careers first-hand through their project work and even work-placements.
Even children with special learning needs will be able to use our platform because it will allow them to learn at their own pace and in a way that they learn best.  Every child will have a place because we will not force “square pegs” into “round holes”.  We recognize that everyone has something to contribute to the world in their own unique way.
Students will learn through interesting projects that have real-world applications.  They will set their own learning paths and define their goals and outcomes.  They will use all of the technologies available to help them research, discover, create and design.  Imagine the impact on learning where one child in the USA conferences with another child in Kenya through Skype, to find out about “endangered species”.  The task of “comparing and contrasting” will take on a whole new meaning for those children.  Students will also be able to share their ideas and work with others through our built-in social network.  Their work will be assessed and monitored with the platform analytics as well as through self-assessment, peer assessment and even experts in their community.  
Our platform will also allow others to contribute projects.  For example, we might have a marine biologist create and submit a project about “marine biodiversity”.  With their expertise in the field, students will gain a valuable experience while the biologist also gains social value from having contributed to the education of young people.
We are committed to making this project happen.  With the support of like-minded people, we know that great things can happen! Please help us achieve our goal by donating whatever you can and by sharing this campaign with all of your contacts.  You can also join our Facebook page and Twitter for daily updates and more information about this Project.  Thank you for your support! 
Find the profiles of Alison and Francesca here:  http://bit.ly/Xih9mG

story:
We're Continuing our Campaign at Global Giving

Thanks to all of you who have visited this page, we completed the Indiegogo campaign with a good head-start to keep AAE schools open.  These schools are reaching Afghan women, girls and boys who otherwise would have no chance of education.  They are truly life-changing schools as the 1007 graduates can attest.

Our initial $10,000 goal funds one school of 300 students for a month.  Over a period of 10 years, we have built 13 schools and a year-around curriculum, so you can see that more fund raising is required to keep all 13 schools open.  Visit our new campaign at http://www.globalgiving.org/14518 to fund all 13 schools to assure education, rebuilding of Afghanistan and freedom from terrorism.  

We must keep all 13 schools open and make up for the lack of funding as a result of cut-backs in USAID into Afghanistan.  This requires much more than the initial $10,000 mentioned in this starting goal.  This campaign is only the beginning and a very important start for rebuilding peace and stabilizing Afghanistan. 

Please visit our new campaign and become a champion by referring others to the new campaign.  When 25 people donate to the Global Giving campaign and refer another to donate through the share button at Global Giving, we receive an additional $500 from global Giving.  Please be one of these champions.  Visit there now.

Protect the Sacrifices Made to Stop Terrorism.

Under the current education system in Afghanistan, if a boy is 10 years old and uneducated, his future is bleak and hopeless.  There are millions of such boys in Afghanistan and they struggle to survive.  They can either sell potatoes on the streets or join the militants and become suicide bombers. 

A bleak fate also awaits an uneducated girl.  She doesn’t have the option of selling potatoes, however.  She faces marriage to a much older man and a life of hardship and abuse.

The only real hope for millions of Afghan boys and girls is education.

                                     

Who We Are

Aid Afghanistan for Education, www.aidafghanistanforeducation.org, has developed an accelerated education program, where students who missed years of education due to wars, can go through primary and secondary education and earn their high school diploma within 8 years.  Neither the current government system nor any other non-profit organizations offer such program for this unfortunate sector of the population. 

In operation since 2003, AAE is providing high-quality education for 3000 female and 104 male students. AAE uses the government curriculum as a requirement for university exam,

My name is Hassina Sherjan. I am an Afghan woman who decided to take the education I received in the United States back to Afghanistan to help rebuild my home country. With this idea in my mind and heart, I founded Aid Afghanistan for Education (AAE) in 1999, establishing five clandestine schools for young women during a time of extreme oppression.  You may learn more about me through my TedX talk, included in the media tab for this campaign, and you can hear me speak in depth at the Wilson Center on CSPAN at http://www.c-spanvideo.org/program/308928-1.

Why We Need Your Help

Since March 17, 2013, AAE has not received any funding and is faces closure. More than 250 teachers have not been paid for the past three months. Worse, many students are losing hope that they can have better lives through education.

If AAE’s programs are forced to close, millions of people in Afghanistan will suffer. All of the 3000 students attending classes are connected to families and communities in nine provinces, meaning millions more will have no hope for a better life. 

If AAE is forced to close, it will mean the waste of 12 years of work that is just starting to bear fruit.  But worse, it will threaten stability and peace in Afghanistan and throughout the world.

Unless high-quality education is provided for all Afghans, with emphasis on educating mothers, Afghanistan will not survive.

This is not only a problem for Afghanistan; this is a global crisis.  World peace can only be achieved by ensuring people throughout the world are educated and can live productive lives.

It doesn’t take much to make a difference.  For only $360, you can support one student for a year and help provide hope to a family, to a community, to a nation and to our world.  By saving one life, we really can save the world.

                                         

We need your help now.  Our funding from USAID, since 2007, ended March 17, 2013.   We are fervently working with Ministry of Education to include this program, for the marginalized Afghans, within the Ministry, but it is time consuming and it will take, at least one or two years.

In the meantime, we have teachers who would rather keep teaching without pay than stop, but this cannot continue.  We must get support from people who see how important education is to stabilizing Afghanistan and protecting the progress that has been made at great expense in lives and money.  

Please look at the contribution levels and stretch to give and keep peace in Afghanistan.

Our Accomplishments To Date.

Today, AAE has grown to operate 13 schools for girls and women throughout Afghanistan.  We have over 3000 students, and recently started a school for boys.  The boys need education, too, to build hope and strength that prevents vulnerability to extremism. 

Through this growth, the goal of AAE remains the same; to educate young Afghan females who have no other access to education, so they can improve their lives, and the lives of their families. I need your assistance today because our 13 schools are threatened with closure.

As I write to you, Afghanistan is still one of the poorest countries on earth. Despite gains, 72% of the Afghan population is illiterate, polio still exists though it is eradicated in almost every other country, and a woman dies every two hours from a pregnancy-related issue.

Our work here is still direly needed. However, international aid to Afghanistan is declining, and USAID, who has been funding AAE since 2007, is no longer able to renew our grant.

                                

We Are Building Sustainability Along with Our Country.

Our organization is on its way to becoming self-sustainable, but we need more time.  We are creating a sponsorship system, an individual donor database, reaching out to local Afghans, to Ministries, and a variety of foundations.  Though we are well on the path towards being sustainable, this work does not happen quickly.

On March 17, if we do not have $486,000 to get us through the next six months, we will have to shut down our 13 schools, closing doors on our 3,104 students who are not allowed in any other school.

These students are barred from formal education for multiple reasons; they may be “overage.” (There is nothing under the Ministry of Education for a 10 year old, who have not had access to education. Due to 30 years of war, there are millions of Afghans who had not had access to education.) They may be one of Afghanistan’s 5.7 million returned refugees, many of whom have no paperwork, or they may be married females. (Ministry does not allow married women to be attending high school and there are millions of young mothers, who would love to earn their high school degree.)

                              

One of Our Students

They may be like Mastura, once a cook in our school, not educated during the time of the Taliban, too old to join government schools today. Mastura enrolled in AAE, received her diploma, and is now teaching math in the same school where she was once a cook. She now supports her family and the young women in her classroom in a way she couldn't have chosen to do without AAE.

It is essential to educate this group. These girls, mostly in their teens and early twenties, are already young mothers, or most likely soon will be. A woman with education will have less children than a woman who is uneducated, and is likely to provide those she has – Afghanistan’s next generation– with greater opportunities.

We need to go on.  For these girls and women, education is life-saving. It means a chance at income, the ability to read their rights, the ability to make reproductive choices, and the chance to choose a future different from the one society handed them-- different for themselves, and different for their children.

                     

Will you work with us? Will you help us save our schools?  

...And help stabilize Afghanistan through education? 

Leave a comment if you can help spread the word in your community among friends and family.  We will email you a letter that can be forwarded.

story:
Dear Citizen of the World,

On behalf of the Mayan Elders of the K’iche’ Community of Santo Tomas de Chichicastenango Guatemala, we invite you to join us as they share their message with humanity, October 23rd to 31st, 2012.

Thousands of years ago, Mayan astronomers foresaw in 2012 a unique alignment of the cosmos which occurs once every 64,000 years. Because they knew that all aspects of life are governed by the movement of the heavens, ushering a new cycle is a huge celebration for the Maya. 

Recently, in preparation for this celebration, the K'iche' Elders expressed the desire to come to New York City, to deliver their ancestors' message to the broadest cross cultural community possible.

The group is led by Don Tomás Calvo, the highest moral authority of the Maya. He is head of the Order of the Mayan Lords - keepers of the Popol Vuh (the Mayan Book of Community). He has been described as the Mayan Pope.

With your help we can make their journey possible and provide them with the utmost care. Join us as the K'iche' Elders mark five iconic places in New York (four representing the cardinal points and one the center) with blessings, ceremonies and talks. These include The United Nations, Central Park, NYU, Sanctuary NYC, and The Nicholas Roerich Museum. 

As a follow up to the Elders’ visit we’re organizing a trip to Chichicastenango to experience the celebration of the 13th Baktun in the capital of the Kʼicheʼ kingdom; and launching an Online Design Competition to create a collection of market worthy products using the Elders’ message as inspiration. Stay tuned...

 

Sincerely,

HAND/EYE Magazine and The Maya Now Team

www.mayanow.org 
www.handeyemagazine.com

story:
Background

I was born and raised in Simcoe, Ontario.  I moved to British Columbia at the age of 19 to attend school.  However the course I selected was not for me. But I wanted to stay in BC to continue to work towards getting my Pilot License.  

In June 2011 I was able to start my Private Pilot License however I had to pull myself out of school due to medical reasons.   I was diagnosed with an eye disease called Keratoconus.   I was required to get two Cornea Transplants or go blind.   I was blessed to get on a short term wait list and was able to have both operations in 4 months after being put on the transplant list.  This was a very testing time for me but it taught me that I needed to put my faith and trust in God and He provided for me.  Now that my vision is corrected my goal is to continue my education and dream of being a commercial pilot.

I am normally not someone who would ask for donations however I have no idea where else I can turn.   I want to be able to achieve my dream of being a Pilot.   I am willing to do what I need to in order to make my dream come true.   With your help this can become possible.

Why a Pilot?

The reason that becoming a Pilot is such a strong passion for me is because ever since I was a child I have had a fascination with flying.   This has been my dream for years, I have been thrown road blocks however have been able to overcome those and continue to push towards my ultimate goal to be a Pilot.

The School

The School I have decided to go to is British Columbia Institute of Technology (BCIT).   The course is 64 weeks long and starts May 2013 Here is a link to the program that I will be attending.  http://www.bcit.ca/study/programs/1005dipts#overview

With this program I will get not only my Commercial License but I will also get my Multi-Engine Rating, Instrument Rating all things that are required to get a job as a Commercial Pilot.

What I Need

Here is a breakdown of what I need:

BCIT Tutition      -    $10,000

Flying Hours        -   $50,000

Living Expense    -   $12,000

Total                             $72,000


I am able to get some money from the government as a student loan.

Government Student Loan $21,000

Bank Student Loan           $20,000 (based on a 2 year course)

Total                               $41,000

So after the loans I have available to me I still need to come up with another $31,000 before January 2013.

If I am unable to raise enough money to get into the program for 2013 I will continue to work for a year to raise the rest of the money and go to school in 2014.    

 

The Impact

What your contributions mean to me:

Even if it is only a $5.00 donation anything will help bring me closer to my goal of being able to afford school. 

I have overcome hurdles in my life with the grace of God.   I strongly believe that God will provide for me in this avenue as He has done in the rest of the areas of my life.

I thank you for looking at this page and wish you the best.

God Bless,

Kory

Other Ways You Can Help

If you want to help me but cannot afford to help here are some ways that  you can help.

You can share my campaign with your friends and family.

If you do not feel comfortable donating online but still want to help out you can e-mail me at koryjacobs@gmail.com and I can provide you with my address.   

If you have any questions or concerns you can e-mail me directly at koryjacobs@gmail.com,

Thank you for taking the time to look at my cause,

Kory Jacobs

story:
Hi! At The Heritage School, we are running our annual band fundraiser. Last year, band met a few days a week after-school with 10 members and no new instruments. This year our band has grown to 30 students! We have trumpets, trombones, pianos, and drums. We’ve already performed at several basketball games and school functions, and were such a hit that more students joined after seeing us perform and have taken every available instrument.


Next year we would like to buy music stands and bring in 30 more instruments. With shrinking school budgets we need private funding to keep running. This year our goal of $6,000 will cover maintaining the 30 instruments we have as well as renting 30 new ones. For all of our donors we are proud to offer promotional gifts including signed band photos, dedicated compositions, and “Friend of the Band” status. Your support will enable a school in an under-served neighborhood to feel proud of both its own music and its youth. Thank you!

story:
Be a part of Seattle’s 2013 Art as Social Action Event!

Our Mission:

Our mission is to financially support educational opportunities for Tibetan refugee youth in India and expand cultural competency for a national audience of art therapists. We will do this by sponsoring the creation of a stunning Tibetan Sand Mandala at the American Art Therapy Association’s 44th annual conference in June of 2013. By presenting culturally diverse programming at this national conference, we will educate a spectrum of helping professionals about art as a form of social action, increase their cultural competency, and share an incredible and ephemeral sacred art form with a wide audience in the name of creating educational opportunities for refugee youth. 

Here’s how we’re doing it: 

The Evergreen Art Therapy Association (EATA) of Washington State has invited a Tibetan monk, the Venerable Ngawang Chojor, from the Tibetan Children’s Educational Foundation (TCEF) to create a sand mandala in support of TCEF’s programs in India since 1998.

Through collaboration and grassroots efforts, both organizations have worked tirelessly to bring a Tibetan Sand Mandala to the 44th Annual AATA conference, with the support of the American Art Therapy Association. The mandala will be created and ritually destroyed over a 3-day period, and witnessed by more than 1,000 helping professionals. All proceeds will benefit TCEF's programming.

Who are TCEF and EATA?

TCEF provides educational infrastructure, individual sponsorship, and cultural preservation efforts for refugee communities in India. Through service learning and study abroad trips to India and national US tours for Tibetan artists, TCEF raises awareness and empowers individuals through the power and magnetism of cultural art.  EATA exists to support continuing educational opportunities for art therapists by providing communities access to art-making, professional development, and participation in art focused experiences in Washington State. Both EATA and TCEF have 501(c)3 non-profit status.

How did this project develop?

In the fall of 2011, Alyssa Griskiewicz, TCEF Board Member and Antioch Art Therapy Master's candidate completed an ambitious and totally radical Master's Project, entitled: Art as Social Action in the Preservation of Tibetan Culture: Creating Positive Social Change through Global Leadership and Service Learning . 

This project was developed to integrate aspects of art, social action, cultural competency, and community involvement at Antioch University Seattle. Specifically, the project coordinator sought to use emic displays of Tibetan cultural art to broaden the scope and visibility of Tibetan Children’s Education Foundation. A four day consortium was held at Antioch University Seattle and was offered free to the public. The event included the creation and destruction of a Tibetan sand mandala, artist workshops and demonstrations, lectures and a panel discussion, exhibitions, fundraisers, community art-making opportunities, and dramatic performances. The event was successful in benefitting a number of populations and organizations, and raising awareness about a grave and serious social-justice issue through the dynamic and healing power of art. A model for replication of art-based social action was developed for ease of replication of similar events. The consortium was successful in raising more than $7,000 for TCEF’s national and international programming.

When the 2013 AATA conference came around to Seattle, organizers approached Alyssa, with the support of EATA, to replicate the event for a national audience. Boom.

Importance of our campaign: 

TCEF is the premiere education based non-profit organization in the United States for Tibetan youth, providing a spectrum of services to refugee communities in India and service learning opportunities to its network of supporters and volunteers. TCEF’s work has been recognized and supported by His Holiness the 14th Dalai Lama. 

Some of TCEF’s projects include: individual educational sponsorships for youth, a monastic school lunch program providing 34 lunches to school-children six days a week; building educational infrastructure in refugee communities, a grandparent sponsorship program for Tibetan elders, and service learning and study abroad trips in India.  

 

What We Need & What You Get

Let's break it on down:

Our initial budget of $8,500 includes: artists' fees for our monastic artisans, transnational travel expenses, four days room and board in Seattle for the Tibetan monk, and organizational fees for TCEF support staff, postage for sending out our unforgettable thank you mementos, and costs associated with presenting a master class at the conference by Harvard Fulbright Scholar Karma Tensum. 

Through various grassroots efforts and generous anonymous donations, and direct sponsorship from EATA and Antioch University, we have chipped away at our goal, but we need your support! We are anticipating a fabulous turnout and addtional funds from a Mandala Auction on May 19, 2013.

Purchase tickets for the Mandala Auction here: http://www.brownpapertickets.com/event/372390

We have already secured more than $6,500 towards our goal through contributions from student fundraising, EATA, Antioch University Seattle, AATA, and individual donors, but we need your support to make this all of our efforts a success!

All anticipated funds will directly benefit TCEF and their efforts to provide educational opportunities to refugee youth, preserve Tibetan culture, and improve educational infrastructure in refugee communities. By presenting this event at a national conference, the funds will help to create a more sustainable and far reaching network of TCEF supporters and raise awareness about the important work we do.

Our creative community is providing MAJOR PERKS to show our gratitude and investment in your support. From images of the completed mandala, to one-of-a-kind artwork, to actual grains of sand from the 2013 mandala, your cash donations will be reciprocated with our heartfelt gratitude and super-awesome artwork. 

All donations beyond our goal will support associated conference costs for EATA volunteer support staff and direct funding of TCEF's programming in India.

The Impact

This campaign is valuable to individuals around the world, on a number of different levels.

TCEF has been committed to education and cultural preservation since 1998 through grassroots campaigning and individual sponsorship. By taking Tibetan artisans on national tours, TCEF has successfully raised funds, awareness, and increased the visibility of a compassionate and endangered culture.

For AATA conference participants, the Seattle Art as Social Action event will provide an opportunity to bear witness to and learn about an authentic, sacred, healing art form from an incredible cultural tradition. This experience will promote growth as compassionate professionals and directly support efforts towards healing and empowerment in communities across the globe.  

This will be the FIRST TIME TCEF presents its incredible work and the ritual creation and destruction of a sacred sand mandala at a national conference. Please be a part of this momentous event. 

To learn more about TCEF please visit: 

Tibetan Children's Education Foundation (TCEF), www.tibetchild.org

Art therapy resources:

Evergreen Art Therapy Association (EATA) www.evergreenarttherapy.org

American Art Therapy Association (AATA) www.arttherapy.org

Other Ways You Can Help

Some people just can’t contribute a lot of dough, but that doesn’t mean you can’t help:

No donation is too small, remember, just $4.32 will feed 34 children a hearty meal through TCEF's monastic school lunch program. Small amounts make a big difference!

Seattle Supporters: Check the EATA Facebook Page for information on our Mandala Auction and Mandala Art Therapy Workshops to be held in Seattle this spring. More info coming soon!

Please help us spread the word and make some noise about our campaign. Tell you rich Uncle Smithers, or your generous Aunty Jo!

Use the Indiegogo share tools to spread the word through Facebook, Twitter, and send emails to your family and friends. 

And that’s all there is to it. It's called collaboration, yo. We're all in this together!

story:
Hello Friends and Family,

I am raising funds to help support Thai Freedom House, a wonderful organization that I am volunteering for here in Chiang Mai, Thailand. Thai Freedom House is a non-government, not-for-profit, language and arts community learning center in Northern Thailand dedicated to assisting families and individuals who are refugees from Burma and members of minority groups of Thailand. As a result of severe military oppression, many Burmese people have fled to Thailand to seek asylum. But they are far from free once they cross over the border, as they are met only with work exploitation, gang violence, and police harassment. With limited rights, and severe negative social perceptions, these refugees are often forced to accept low-paying, dangerous jobs, that provide inadequate financial support. The result is a viscous cycle of poverty for the refugees and their families. Education is certainly a key to breaking free from these poor living conditions, but unfortunately the Thai government makes it increasingly difficult for Burmese citizens to receive a proper education.

That is where Thai Freedom House steps in, offering hope in the form of sanctuary and education. It is a place that strives to give the children of these refugees a fair shot at a positive future. With classes in English, Thai, Shan, Burmese, Chinese, and the arts, these children can realistically acquire the skills and resources needed to progress beyond unskilled labor. In addition to language and arts classes, refugees are taught how to interact in Thai society, to reduce instances of discrimination and trouble with police. It also serves as a transportation hub for supplies and clothing to be distributed to Burmese construction camps throughout Northern Thailand. But really, Thai Freedom House serves as a place of peace and happiness for refugees who face tremendous hardship on a daily basis. It is a place where they can simply just have fun, be who they are, and not have to worry about the troubles of life. I have been here two weeks, and can already see the magnitude of its positive influence on these wonderful people's lives.

For the month of March, I will be volunteering at the Thai Freedom House helping out wherever I am needed. It has already been quite busy for me, but the reward has been worth every second of my time. I have helped teach English, Art, and Geography. I have worked with some of the Burmese students-turned-faculty on developing their computer skills. I have done at least 10,000 dishes (or at least it feels like it!) to help out in their fund raising restaurant, the Free Bird Cafe. And my biggest contribution to date, has been planning a 'Sports Day' for the kids to get out and enjoy the structure, teamwork, and thrill, that comes with organized sports. In order to make events like Sports Day a possibility, Thai Freedom House needs funding. As noted above, it is a non-government organization, which means funding comes primarily from donations, as well as the recently set-up free bird cafe. That is why I am setting up this page, to help raise as much money as possible to see that a great organization is not slowed down by lack of finances. Any amount you can afford to give, will go a very long way. Your donation will go towards providing school supplies, art supplies, meals for children, and the sporting equipment necessary to make Sports Day, and future Sports Days, a huge success. Thank you in advance for all of your time and help.


-Danny Monckton

story:
Get Nzambi the medical help she needs before it is too late

Nzambi is a little girl like many others in the world, who are small, female and therefore expandable. In 2011, she was brutally raped and had her leg broken by her mother’s boyfriend after which they both hid her in their house for three weeks before the Grandmother and Aunts broke in to find her.

She was taken to the hospital where she received minimal treatment and released because there is not health care system in Kenya and they had no money to pay.

So for three years she has been crippled with a poorly set broken leg, she has open weeping sores and she cannot walk without crutches. The perpetrator has walked free and is free to this day.

Here is Aunty Jane, Nzambi, and a visitor, Rev. John Muli

Since her story broke in early May, much has happened. The Red Cross brought her to Kenyatta National Hospital and while they are paying for the care she is not getting, they have not checked on her. No one has been to visit her. And daily, her condition worsens.

She has swollen glands in her neck which may indicate that she may be contracting Osteomyelitis, a life threatening illness that will kill her if it is not dealt with aggressively and immediately.

A group of us are trying very hard to get her moved to Nairobi Women’s hospital where they specialize in treating women who are raped and injured. We initially raised $1700 to help rehabilitate her once she is out of hospital, but she may never get out of hospital without urgent attention.

When I learned that Esther the Wonderpig Sanctuary raised almost a half a million dollars I was appalled that the world would mobilize to save a pig but I could barely raise two thousand to save the life of a dying little girl.

So please join with us and donate what you can. Surely, her life is as important as a Wonder Pig.

story:
Who We Are

Oxford Students for Life is part of a new wave of pro-life activism on British campuses. We are a group of pro-life students with different backgrounds, united in our desire to defend human life from conception to natural death. OSFL was reformed in 2013 and has grown in strength over the academic year thanks to the work of the committee and members. 

Last year's committee with Lord David Alton and our senior member Dr. Michael Ward


We’ve been changing the conversation about life issues by putting on events, organising workshops, and running a popular blog. We were awarded ‘Society of the Year’ by the Alliance of Pro-Life Students, and we’ve recently made the news in Finland, Poland and on both sides of the Atlantic.


Some of our committee members receiving the Society of the Year Award in London at the APS meeting


Rarely have life issues been in such need of debate. Every day in the UK, 550 abortions are carried out, sometimes because the child is female or has a disability. The Falconer Bill on assisted suicide, which puts many vulnerable lives at risk, is currently being debated in parliament. Elsewhere in Europe, almost half of Belgium’s euthanasia nurses admit to killing without consent – yet earlier this year, Belgium extended euthanasia to children. This is what can happen when a society forgets the value of human life.

We believe our generation needs to break the silence which too often surrounds these issues. Student pro-life activism is needed now more than ever; your support is needed now more than ever.

Oxford is one of the world’s top universities, where future leaders from all over the world come to study. This is a place where issues are debated and opinions are formed. It is crucial that the pro-life voice be heard loud and clear. With your help, we hope to secure the future of OSFL.

  • We’re planning to put on big events, like last year’s packed-out debates;

The committee with speakers Ann Furedi and Sara De Nordwall after our debate which you can watch on our YouTube Channel


  • To change the culture on campus, by offering practical support to student parents;
  • To spread the pro-life message, running information stalls and workshops.


What We Need & What You Get

All of this needs resources. Oxford Students for Life is entirely run through hundreds of volunteer hours, but it still costs money. To put on a single event can easily cost around £150, including paying for speakers, refreshments and advertising. To have a stall at Freshers’ Fair, where we will meet most of our new members, will cost well over £100, once we have booked tables and printed material.

Our stall at Freshers Fair last year - hopefully next year with your help we can make it even bigger!

We are fundraising now to put OSFL on a strong foundation for the next few years – a time when the case for human life will need to be made ever more forcefully and determinedly.

Your money will help us:

  • to attract the best speakers and put on high-profile talks and debates;
  • to set up street stalls offering information about the start of life;
  • to help student parents, by organising events and practical support like ‘nappy drives’;
  • to get the pro-life message out by publishing material and maintaining a website.

Please give whatever you can to invest in the future of the pro-life movement.

Even if you aren’t able to donate, do please share this campaign and tell people about it.

If you can give £25, you’ll receive a special thank-you card from the committee.

If you can give £75, you’ll receive a personal thank you video from OSFL committee

If you can give £150, you’ll receive a special thank-you card, a t-shirt and a personal video from OSFL to express our gratitude. 

Our t-shirt at the march for life in Washington DC this year!

Pro-life groups face many challenges. The culture on campus is often an unfriendly one. Last year a motion threatening our freedom of expression was put forward at the Students Union. We got organised, and the motion failed by a margin of three votes. It underlined the challenges we face to keep the pro-life voice alive; and the fact that, if we come together, we will be able to meet those challenges. With your support, we can build a culture that protects and cherishes human life. 

Thank you so much for your support - The 2014/2015 Executive Committee outside the Radcliffe Camera Library

story:
Update as of August 18, 2014:  

I would like to thank those who have already contributed to the campaign and we will be contacting you soon to refund your contribution.  We would also like to tell any new, would-be contributors to please withhold their donation to "this" campaign.

If you would still like to help, there are two more "turtleback" cars that are slated to be discarded if they do not find a home.  Our friends at the North Texas Historic Transportation and Traction Company are trying to raise funds to save these other two cars.  They are also the same organization that acquired the car we were trying to save.  Here is a link to their campaign:

https://www.facebook.com/savetheturtlebacks/timeline  

Our goal was to save a rare historic trolley that ran in Dallas, Texas and we were working with the McKinney Avenue Transit Authority in Dallas to acquire the car.  To our surprise, they found a local historical group in the Dallas area to save and restore the car.  It is great news that the car will be saved and it is also fortunate that the car is going to stay in the area where it has historical ties.  Unfortunately for us, we need to end our campaign to collect contributions to save this car.  Again, thank you to all who have contributed and shared our campaign with your friends and associates.


Best Regards,

Nathan Wells




Campaign as it was:


Seeking funds to acquire and save historic Car 323, a rare "stretched turtleback" trolley that ran on the streets of Dallas, Texas. 

 


Car 323 is the last known surviving car of its kind in the world!   Car 323 is a 13-window "turtleback" streetcar manufactured by the American Car Company for Stone and Webster   to run on its Dallas streetcar system.  The "turtleback" trolley derives its name from its unique appearance of looking like a turtle with its head sticking out of its shell.  The standard "turtleback" trolleys were built with 10 side windows.  Car 323 is one of the few "stretched turtleback"  streetcars built with 13 windows per side.  The "stretched turtleback" was built to handle a higher capacity of passengers.  It is the "stretched" or 13 windows that makes Car 323 so rare that it is the only known surviving "stretched turtleback" trolley in the world!

Originally, McKinney Avenue Transit Authority   (MATA), a heritage streetcar company based in Dallas, TX,  rescued Car 323 and preserved it for future restoration.  MATA has decided it no longer requires the car.  They are offering the streetcar to our group if we can move it before the beginning of September 2014. The streetcar is currently sitting on a lot that has been sold to a third party.  If Car 323 is not moved by September, Car 323 may be scrapped along with its 100 year history and status as the last known surviving "stretched turtleback" streetcar in the world!  

We are seeking $10,000 to pay for the shipping of Car 323 from Dallas, TX to Charlotte, NC.  

If you would like to help save Car 323, contribute $$ AND share our campaign with your friends.

Thank You for Your Support!


More about Car 323 from McKinney Avenue Transit Authority:

Car 323 was built in 1915 as part of an order for 26 such cars for Northern Texas Traction (NTT).  NTT operated local streetcar service between Oak Cliff, TX and Dallas using these "300" class cars. NTT was later purchased by the Texas Electric Railway.  In 1934,Texas Electric sold the Oak Cliff lines and all rolling stock to the Dallas Railway Company, which continued to operate the "300" class cars until 1952 when they were retired and "all" were scrapped.  Car 323 survived as a ticket office and souvenir shop at the now defunct "Old Abilene Town" in Abilene, Texas.


Who We Are:

We are the "restoration committee" of the heritage rail group Charlotte Trolley, Inc.   ,  a 501c(3) non-profit based in Charlotte, NC.  Charlotte Trolley was responsible for restoring and running one of Charlotte's original streetcars in a historic industrial district of Charlotte for more than a decade before being displaced by Charlotte's light rail system.  Among the members of our "restoration committee" are two of the gentlemen responsible for the restoration of Charlotte's historic streetcar, Charlotte Trolley's president, a former motorman, a track expert and some other impassioned trolley lovers.  We hope this will serve as a launching pad to acquire and save other southern streetcars before they are forever lost to rot, demolition or development and eventually lead to their restoration, operation and display in a museum.  

The $10,000 to ship Car 323 to Charlotte includes:  the trucking freight ($4700), permitting and escort ($2300), rigging and cranes to lift and secure the car on and off the trailer ($3000).  This figure does not include the cost of restoration which will require many thousands of additional dollars.  Our immediate goal is to save the car.  If contributions exceed what we have requested, we will use the additional funds to either acquire and save another endangered streetcar body, or we will apply the extra proceeds to the restoration of Car 323.  

This is a volunteer effort from a group of passionate trolley enthusiasts.  No money will be used for personal benefit to any member nor be wasted on administrative overhead.

Our group is also working towards the establishment of a heritage streetcar operation in Belmont, NC with a sister 501c(3) non-profit organization, Belmont Trolley, Inc.,  where we  plan to run and showcase the cars we restore.

We hope saving Car 323 is another important step towards saving other endangered Southern trolleys and in the possible establishment of the South's first dedicated streetcar museum.

story:
Welcome everyone!!

I am Jen. My lovely daughter Bethany is here to raise some money!  Bethany has just started Kindergarten at the most amazing school and we are taking part in the 2nd annual fun run to raise funds to purchase some amazing technology for all the kids in her school.  We're talking laptops baby!!

What We Need

We would like to raise enough to get a laptop in every students hands. Teach those wonderful kids how to use technology right.  Maybe even show them that there is more online then just hilarious cat videos and Zack Scott...perhaps that's just my kid.  We are looking for donations of any size. Even if its just a dollar. All the money will go to the school.

The Impact

The kids will gain so much more knowledge when they learn to use technology at a younger age.  Bethany wants to be a Neurosurgeon Easter Bunny... That cant happen without technology. Well, technology and the ability to manipulate genes.  All of these kids deserve every chance to succeed and become successful adults. Remember, they will be the ones running our nursing homes when we get older. Lets get on their good side!

Other Ways You Can Help

Some people just can't contribute, but that doesn't mean you can't help:

  • Help get the word out and make some noise about our campaign.
  • Use the Indiegogo share tools! Spread this around Facebook like the common cold in an office building.

Thank you for any help you can give!.

story:
The youth ministry of Campus Crusade for Christ International. The Key to a Thriving Youth Ministry is to intentional engage and ignite  them in the Win (evangelism) Build  (Training) and  Send ( making them multiplying disciples) approach. The  "Gateway Conference" in Cameroon is  aimed at  bringing together 150 key student leaders in the North West Region from the 22th to the 29th of June.  Raising more labourers is key and more strategic in Cameroon to reach the growing young population  with 50% of the entire population  below 18 years. 75% easily give their lives to Christ before the age 20.

Many trained students leaders have a great proven track record of ministry success on campus. For instance Alfred is operating more than 5 action discipleship group on campus. When there are trained and nurture, there will be no doubt that many campuses will be reach for Christ with a clear gospel.This conference will train 150 young university and high school leaders.

Philip  Nkaimbzi is the  National director of Student Venture of Campus Crusade for  Christ Cameroon.

Details of the budget

1.  Training materials for young African Christian leaders: Training cost for 150 students: 150 x $10= $1500

2.  Cost for publicity: 1000 flyers x $0.4 =$400

3.  Lodging: Rents for the Venue for 6 days -lump sum= $1300

4.  Feeding of 150 students for 6days

5.  Breakfast  $1 x150 leaders x 6days= $900

6.  Lunch $2x 150 leaders x 6days  = $1800 

7.  Supper $2x150 leaders x 6days = $1800

8.  Transportation: Hired bust for 7 days X 80= $560

9.  Communication, lump sum:  = $200 (92.000 cfa)

  $25 will help you train and send a missionary in a new campus.

   It should go to Harbour Center Cameroon if all the money is not raised.

.
Expectations:-This campaign will help  to start  ministry in 20 new campuses through Christ-Centered Disciples.
-Create 150 action discipleship groups on campuses.
 -Expand ministry in the region through the connection of the Lost to Christ.

story:
What you are funding? 

Learning & leadership for indigenous youth who participate in...  
Unlocking Silent Histories!  

Who we are

Unlocking Silent Histories (USH) is a non-profit organization  that began working with indigenous youth in the Lake Atitlán region of Guatemala. Our organization is dedicated to cultivating educational spaces for indigenous youth to express their ideas and identities through the creation of documentary shorts. Through the art of filmmaking, the students capture aspects of their cultures that they identify as most important to examine, document, and share with local and global communities. Since our start in December 2012, 22 students participating in the Maya Traditions education program, completed documentary shorts.  Four of these students became program leaders and now teach and help envision the  future of USH.  

Why?   To support indigenous youth learning opportunities that lead to critical and creative media expression, amplifying their voices and identities, and honoring their cultural and linguistic heritages.


The Benefits for Indigenous Youth & Its Importance

  • Critical thinking skills: limited in formalized schooling in these villages
  • Technology skills: learning critical 21st Century Skills
  • Youth empowerment: youth direct their learning & take on leadership roles

The voices of indigenous peoples continue to be absent from the escalating digital landscape. Having youth broadcast their perspectives through digital documentaries is an effort to close this gap. By self-directing their inquiry and deciding how they choose to participate in a digital world, our students develop a sense of identify, self-awareness and community leadership.

Where does your funding go?  

  • Cameras and audio recorders:  Our focus is on evidence-based storytelling in visual forms.   In the first level, we buy a camera for every student and allow them to keep them upon completion of their stories.  We've collectively learned the importance of good sound quality and purchase audio recorders that are shared within communities.  In the second level, the students work with more advanced equipment in production teams, led by our youth leaders.  
  • Computers: The students are enjoying learning technology, yet we don't have enough computers.  We need computer resources so that our students can continue to explore creative and editing software and learn new skills.  With computers and software we can provide participants with editing kits accessible for both first and second level students.  
  • Youth Leader Salaries: As youth "graduate" from their first level experience with making documentaries, they apply to become leaders.  These leaders then teach and support new groups of students.  Giving youth stipend apprenticeships supports local responsibility, leadership, and project ownership.
  • Cultural Excursions: We have cultural excursions at least 4 times a year that aim to strengthen cultural awareness and inter-community connectedness. In July, we traveled to Quiche, Guatemala, where the youth heard the history of their migration and participated in a Maya Ceremony prepared by a respected elder in the community. More excursions are planned to deepen youth's connection to their cultures, and they'll be documented through youth video.
  • Workshops and Travel: With our youth leaders, we conduct local workshops in each community as well as conjoint workshops that gather all the youth together.  We pay for their travel, lodging, supervision and food so that they can travel to work together with youth across communities.  

How do we work? 

Partnerships! USH works in partnership with existing organizations that have similar goals of facilitating local leadership and local sustainability. These established organizations have worked tirelessly to create trusting relationships with families and youth, which is essential to the success of this work.

Maya Traditions Chapter: We began this work in partnership with Maya Traditions Foundation (MTF). Maya Traditions Foundation works to empower and improve the quality of life for Maya women artisans and their families through facilitating international market access and through educational social programs. Our partnership is entitled Unlocking Silent Histories: Maya Traditions Chapter.  The youth currently participating in and assisting in creating the growth of USH are also participants in MTF’s Youth Education Program and many are children of MTF's partner artisans.  MTF also supports the program through its material and human resources.

ADECCAP Chapter:  USH is in the final stages of solidifying a partnership with ADECCAP, an organization under indigenous Maya leadership in Santiago Atitlán. The purpose of ADECCAP is to strengthen spaces for youth participation, promoting processes of formation and capacity-building to give opportunities to young people in their social, economic, political and cultural development, in order to exercise responsible and critical citizenship, with gender equity and cultural relevance, within a framework of environmental risk management for a holistic approach to community development. 

Our Successes

  • Documentaries: Four Communities and 18 films
  • Youth Leadership: We have hired four youth leaders to direct the Maya Traditions Chapter 
  • Youth Growth: Our students have shown great personal and leadership development through participation in our program: the once shy Emilio is now class president; Carmen changed her focus of study from farming to community building; Youth are traveling outside their communities for the first time and being introduced to Maya cultural practices that they had before not experienced.  
  • Presentations: The films have been presented in Guatemala (Youth communities and Panajachel) and in the US (including the Austin Film Society)
  • Spreading the word: Our youth leaders have presented USH to other youth groups in surrounding communities such as Santiago Atitlán and Nebaj.  
  • Invitations to Film: The technological skills and unique perspectives of our youth are opening new doors for them. One of our youth leaders was invited to document a Tribal Gathering in Panama.  
  • Cultural Connection:  In addition to learning more about various connections between the history and the present, a Maya Spiritual Guide and Historian led our excisions to Quiche (to provide the youth with their first historical lesson about the migration of their ancestors from Quiche to Lake Atitlán) and to Iximche (to hear the history of the colonization from an indigenous perspective).  


Awards

  • Adobe Youth Voices: The youth have been invited to participate in  competition, and are learning deeper critical, technical, and production skills.
  • Pollination Project:  USH received a small grant from the Pollination Project to begin our youth leaders program!
  • GOOD INC:  USH was recognized in GOODInc. as one of the top 100 "Do Good" project of 2014.   

Other Ways you Can Help

We understand that financial contributions are often difficult. There are other ways that you can help us:

  • Share this with your friends
  • Donate old computers, cameras,and software (We use GE DV1s, Sony Alpha a5000, Macs, and Adobe Products)
  • Connect with USH and our participants via Facebook
  • Utilize the Indiegogo share tools.

Risks and Challenges

We are excited about what we are doing and its recent successes.  At the same time, we have experienced the risks and challenges that accompany this work. Spending a considerable amount of time in these  indigenous communities, one quickly recognizes the complexity of the work.  Youth juggle many responsibilities within their families, schools, and communities.  

What we've been watching closely includes:

  • Maintaining Youth Local Stories and Voices: It is much easier to tell students what to say and think than it is to support their own ideas and expressions.  We are constantly monitoring ourselves and our process to ensure that we don't put our ideas and voices into the stories of our youth.
  • Learning new technologies: Many of these youth have never touched a camera or a computer.  Realizing that this process will take both time and patience to ensure that their hands do all the work, is something that we remind ourselves.  
  • New Style of Learning: Youth in underrepresented communities are used to being told when and how to do things.  Learning can become frustrating when they are asked to make their own decisions.  Yet, we support them as they: a) learn new technologies; b) become comfortable directing their own learning; c) embrace critical and creative expression (overcoming hierarchical learning); d) come to learn how to coherently tell a story in their own creative way.
  • Competing with local responsibilities and lack of resources:  The youth here in these communities are juggling a lot of family and social responsibilities.  Being flexible with their time and providing support and encouragement as they navigate these projects with limited resources is an ongoing focus. 

We strive to create learning experiences that:

  • Amplify the voices and identities of indigenous youth and their communities by supporting them to direct and produce their own documentaries.  
  • Invite youth to explore personally meaningful curiosities and concerns in order to connect learning to their lives.  
  • Value and encourage using their local languages and draw on local knowledge to tell their stories and learn with their peers.  
  • Share films with peers within and across communities to deconstruct visual expression and its local and historical meaning.
  • Develop local youth leadership to ensure sustainability of the project(s) 
Our work is motivated by the arguments that:

  • Historically, foreigners have created media representations of indigenous peoples to construct and perpetuate stereotypes about them and their lives.    
  • Current educational practices are culturally distanced from indigenous cultures, inhibiting them from critically and creatively expressing themselves.  
  • Languages are being lost at a rate of one language every two weeks, and this threat is acutely felt by indigenous peoples.  
  • Indigenous youth have limited opportunities to engage in educational experiences that honor their cultural and linguistic heritage.

GOOD INC:  USH was recognized in GOODInc. as one of the top 100 "Do Good" project of 2014.   

Other Ways you Can Help
We understand that financial contributions are often difficult. There are other ways that you can help us:



Share this with your friends

Donate old computers, cameras,and software (We use GE DV1s, Sony Alpha a5000, Macs, and Adobe Products)
Connect with USH and our participants via Facebook
Utilize the Indiegogo share tools.


 
Risks and Challenges

We are excited about what we are doing and its recent successes.  At the same time, we have experienced the risks and challenges that accompany this work. Spending a considerable amount of time in these  indigenous communities, one quickly recognizes the complexity of the work.  Youth juggle many responsibilities within their families, schools, and communities.  
What we've been watching closely includes:



Maintaining Youth Local Stories and Voices: It is much easier to tell students what to say and think than it is to support their own ideas and expressions.  We are constantly monitoring ourselves and our process to ensure that we don't put our ideas and voices into the stories of our youth.

Learning new technologies: Many of these youth have never touched a camera or a computer.  Realizing that this process will take both time and patience to ensure that their hands do all the work, is something that we remind ourselves.  

New Style of Learning: Youth in underrepresented communities are used to being told when and how to do things.  Learning can become frustrating when they are asked to make their own decisions.  Yet, we support them as they: a) learn new technologies; b) become comfortable directing their own learning; c) embrace critical and creative expression (overcoming hierarchical learning); d) come to learn how to coherently tell a story in their own creative way.

Competing with local responsibilities and lack of resources:  The youth here in these communities are juggling a lot of family and social responsibilities.  Being flexible with their time and providing support and encouragement as they navigate these projects with limited resources is an ongoing focus. 



We strive to create learning
experiences that:





Amplify the voices and identities of
indigenous youth and their communities by supporting them to direct and produce
their own documentaries.  


Invite youth to explore personally
meaningful curiosities and concerns in order to connect learning
to their lives.  


Value and encourage using their local
languages and draw on local knowledge to tell their stories and learn with
their peers.  


Share films with peers within
and across communities to deconstruct visual expression and its local and
historical meaning.

Develop local youth leadership to
ensure sustainability of the project(s) 

Our work is motivated by the
arguments that:



Historically, foreigners have created
media representations of indigenous peoples to construct and perpetuate
stereotypes about them and their lives.    


Current educational practices are
culturally distanced from indigenous cultures, inhibiting them from critically
and creatively expressing themselves.  


Languages are being lost at a rate of
one language every two weeks, and this threat is acutely felt by indigenous
peoples.  


Indigenous youth have limited
opportunities to engage in educational experiences that honor their cultural
and linguistic heritage.
campaign_city: Lake Atitlán and the Highlands, Guatemala

story:
Raise Uganda Now  is a 501(c)(3) registered nonprofit that oversees Raise Uganda Now Orphanage and Academy in Nabweru, Uganda. Help us create an international learning community in which all children have the opportunity to go to school. 

Making A Difference

25 orphans and 75 local, disadvantaged students depend on Raise Uganda Now as a safe place to learn and grow. With the generous help of our donors, we have:
  • Moved to a safer, cleaner home
  • Provided every child with his/her own bed
  • Refurnished the classrooms with desks and chalkboards

We have made amazing progress, but we are far from done with helping these adorable children. That's why we need your help.


Our 25 Day Campaign

We are hoping to raise over $2,500 over a span of 25 days, and with your help, we believe we can do it! We genuinely appreciate every dollar donated to helping the children, and we want to thank you for your support in a variety of ways:

  • For donating $25, we will send a personalized thank you e-card. If you choose to make a gift on someone else's behalf, we can send an e-card to him/her directly to let them know that a donation has been made in his/her name.
  • For donating $50, a member of the Board of Directors will send a thank-you postcard addressed to the donor, or if you would like to donate as a gift in someone else's name, we will send that person a postcard directly.
  • For donating $100, your name will be added to a banner of "Gold Supporter" donors, which will hanging in the orphanage, and you will also receive a personalized note and photo once the banner is hung from a member of the Board of Directors.
  • For donating $250 or more, your name will hang above one of our classrooms at RUN Academy for the year of 2016. We will also send a photo and hand-written thank you, and if you would like to give on someone else's behalf, we can send that person the postcard and photo directly.

Every Donation Makes A Difference

Every dollar you can contribute goes a long way to help these children.

$1 can buy one new exercise book for a student at RUN Academy. 

$10 can buy a full set of bedding for one of the orphans. 

$50 can buy a set of desks for a classroom. 

$200 can pay for electricity, water, and food for the orphanage for one month.

$500 could pay for a new swing set and playground for the children. 



Other Ways You Can Help

If you are able to make a contribution, we greatly appreciate your support! Beyond this, another way you can truly make a difference is to share this page, our Facebook page , and our website with anyone you know who might be interested in what we do!

story:
Who Am I

I am an undergraduate from the University of Oxford. In the summer of 2015, I travelled to Bulgaria as a member of Oxford Aid to the Balkans (OXAB) and worked in two refugee camps alongside six other team members. I taught the English language, art and music to children within the camps.   

Over the course of a few weeks, I worked and spoke with many of the refugees and asylum-seekers living within the camps. I had many conversations with them over many cups of tea. They shared with me about the lives they had led before, and how none of them had anticipated this change in their lives. They shared about their lives in the camps, and how being patient and prayerful was the only way they could respond to their circumstances. And they shared about their dreams and aspirations for the future, aspirations not unlike those of yours and mine. I witnessed moments of sadness and disappointment, but also moments of contentment, laughter, gratitude, and joy. 


The Project and its Motivations

Interacting with the refugees and asylum-seekers and listening to their stories helped me to understand the common humanity between us. Their stories revealed to me perspectives that I had not and could not have obtained from news outlets and their commentaries.  These stories weren't stories of 'the Other', but intimate and poignant portraits of human lives, just like our own. 

Through their stories, we can come closer to a greater understanding of the common humanity that we share, and to hold other people closer to our hearts. This is why I hope to publish a photo book to raise awareness about the real-life experiences and journeys of refugees and asylum-seekers. 


The Common Humanity Scholarship

The sales of the books will be used to establish a scholarship for refugee students in Bulgaria who want to pursue or continue their university education. The scholarship will go a long way in subsidising the costs of compulsory English or Bulgarian language courses and degree courses within Bulgarian universities.


The Goal

The goal of this fundraising campaign is to raise 1600 GBP. The funds raised will be used to publish and distribute 2000 books.

 

Your Support

You can support this project by donating money and you can help by spreading the word. Tell your friends about this project, share this post on your social media platforms, and talk about the refugee crises in your conversations with the people around you. You may also want to visit the 'For Whom The Bell Tolls' Facebook page to get updates on the fundraising and details about the book release. This is a serious issue that demands more thought and action, and your actions can make a difference.

Thank you, from us.

story:
Thank you for helping us get to AES!

 

We are so humbled by the incredible generosity we've witnessed from our friends and supporters like you over the past week. We have already made it to 99% of our goal to send WAM staff and interns to the Audio Engineering Society Convention in Los Angeles! Thanks to you, we will be able to connect with women in audio from all over the world next month.

The work doesn't stop there. Help us surpass our original goal so that we can sponsor underserved girls (93% low income, 30-40% high school drop out rate) in our Girl's on the Mic program this semester. $1,000 will provide a free semester of training for 10 middle school girls in the Girls on the Mic program. Can you help sponsor one of these girls? Any donation amount will help create new opportunities and career/education paths for the girls that need it the most.

As always, thank you for believing in WAM!

 

Did you know that women make up less than 5% of audio professionals? 

Help send WAM to the 141st Audio Engineering Society Convention (AES) to represent and recruit awesome women in audio!

 

What is WAM?

Women's Audio Mission is a San Francisco-based, non-profit organization dedicated to the advancement of women in music production and the recording arts. In a field where women are critically under-represented (less than 5%), WAM is "changing the face of sound" by training over 1,200 women and girls in a year in music technology and media production in the only professional recording studio built and run entirely by women and girls. WAM believes that women's mastery of music technology and inclusion in the production process will expand the vision and voice of media and popular culture.

Why Send WAM to AES?

The Audio Engineering Society Convention (AES) is the largest gathering of audio professionals in the world, with over 18,000 attendees, uniting engineers, creative artists, scientists and students worldwide. 

It's also the most important event of the year for WAM. WAM reaches the largest number of women in audio at AES, from new students to industry veterans. AES allows WAM to connect women to our programs and help them with networking, internships, jobs, and more!

 WAM has attended the conference every year since 2004. AES generously donates a booth to us every year, so we can provide a place for women to connect, network, and get hooked into WAM's programs and services. But first we need to get our WAM team to Los Angeles!

 

Why WAM Needs to be at AES This Year

 

  • The WAM Booth provides a critical "homebase" for women attendees to meet, connect, and network with other women and industry professionals;
  • AES is the best event for us to reach the largest amount of women in audio and get them involved in WAM's programs and services, increasing their chances of graduating from audio programs and getting into audio careers;
  • WAM provides students with a gateway into the conference, offering student-tailored guides, tips, career/educational guidance, and encouragement;
  • WAM recruits new interns from all over the country at the AES conference (in the past, interns from the UK, Thailand, Indiana, Georgia, and more!)
  • 25,000+ WAM supporters, members, and women in audio will be connected to the 141st AES Convention through WAM's social media channels full of updates, videos, and tech coverage from the conference!

What We Need & What You Get

WAM is raising funds to cover travel, accommodation and booth expenses. 

WAM is a small nonprofit with a small budget, any help at all that you can provide would be appreciated immensely! Here's what we need to get there:

Hotel Accommodations for 7 people for 4 days: $2,200

Booth Staff: $2,400

Airfare and Transportation: $2,000

Booth Furniture/Electrical Costs: $400

Total: $7,000

Our AMAZING perks include:

  • Full and half-day recording sessions at WAM's professional studio
  • Exhibits-Plus Badges to AES
  • WAM t-shirts, sunglasses and watches
  • Dedicated Social Media Blasts (over 25,000 subscribers) and a spot in our quarterly newsletter (4,200+ subscribers)
  • Logo Placement on our Booth Banner
  • And more!

story:
The Project

Keith Moilanen, Zach Thomas, and Lukas Rieke are Senior Mechanical Engineering students at Northwest Nazarene University. We are competing in a Basic Utility Vehicle competition to fulfill our senior project. The competition is centered on the goal of designing a cheap, reproducible vehicle that could serve multiple purposes for a community in a third-world nation. Once the competition has ended, the vehicles that complete the competition are donated to a country in Africa or Latin America. Your donations will go towards designing the vehicle and funding the travel expenses for the team to travel to Ohio for the competition. 

Our goal is to raise $5000 to ensure that we can successfully build a prototype of our BUV and travel to Ohio as a team to compete. The goal for the competition is to design a Basic Utility Vehicle that can be used for agriculture or community-based needs and can be reproduced for less than $2500. The prototype will be built in the next few months. Following the build, we will travel as a team to Ohio to participate in the competition to prove that our vehicle can perform the required actions, such as carrying water and traveling over challenging terrain. If we are successful in the competition, our vehicle will be donated to a community in Africa or Latin America. 
This competition is put on by the Institute for Affordable Transportation. They produce their design of the Basic Utility Vehicle and ship them to countries throughout Africa and Latin America. The purpose for the competition is two fold: to inspire university students to work towards helping others and to push for new ideas to improve their BUV design. Each competition is structured around the innovations the competing teams bring with their designs. Your donations will enable us to design the fuel-efficient and simplistic design that we are striving towards. 
This project is filled with risks. We have less than three months to build and test our prototype. We have to travel to Ohio and endure multiple tests including a 8 and 1/2 hour race to complete as many laps of the course as possible, while loading and unloading water regularly. We will design a vehicle that will be able to endure these challenges and it will be finished by the competition date on April 17.

And that's all there is to it.

Please spread the word to friends and family!

story:
Parkview Riding Centre is a wonderful riding school run by a wonderful lady by the name of Steph Lancefield. It offers riding lessons for everyone and on everything you could imagine you could do on a horse. It has been running under Steph's steam for the last year and it has truly blossomed and created so many happy experiences for both young and older riders.

I was saddened to hear that Steph and the team at Parkview had the sudden news that their lease wasn't going to be renewed after only a year into setting up the business. 
Steph and her team have worked so hard in the last year to establish themselves and in turn inspire and help so many riders, both young and old within our community to achieve their horse dreams. 

Upon taking on Parkview less than a year ago Steph and her team have transformed the business but more so transformed hundreds of riders with their enthusiasm and amazing experiences on offer. 

Steph had initiated programs such as the Wrangler Club for those western enthusiasts. She hosted clinics to inspire us to try reining, dressage, Showjumping, ground work, roping.  She hosted seminars on everything from getting that competitive edge, equine nutrition, horse dentistry, saddle fitting to simply managing your new horse. 

We could see her passion & drive was to open doors for all of us horse lovers to see what was out there -what was possible,  if we gave it a go. 

To have achieved so much in such a small time is remarkable, to have to shut it down so suddenly is heartbreaking for all she has helped. 
Steph needs to relocate and set up her business in a new location which is such a huge undertaking for an equine business such as Parkview. It is so difficult to run a small business, let alone relocate and start again. And when it is an equine related business it is 100 times more difficult and financially extensive. 

I want to help Steph to continue to inspire riders, young and old to give it a go and I know she has many supporters who would agree with me. 

So please show that support and donate. Whether it's $10 or $100 we can help her back "in the saddle" sooner so she can relocate and get back into the job of  helping others.

*PLEASE NOTE the currency on the campaign is in USD, and I am unable to change that for any Aussie contributors so please take that into consideration when choosing your donation amount. Sorry for any inconvenience but please don't let that stop you donating! :)
