We empower at-risk girls and boys through quality early education, dramatically increasing their likelihood of graduating from high school and college and living good, healthy, productive lives. 
Did you know that early childhood education for low-income children is the most powerful job training tool? And, did you know that every $1 invested in early education for at-risk kids today results in $16 savings tomorrow in lower prison costs, less crime and other consequences of low educational achievement?
We are the oldest early childhood provider in the entire Midwest and having operated in just two facilities for 128 years, we are building a new school!  The foundation is poured, the walls are up, and the roof is on.  The only thing missing is the kid’s furniture! 
We’ve got 10 classrooms to fill; five for precious infants and toddlers and five for rambunctious pre-schoolers.  Cubbies, chairs, dramatic play materials, water tables, books, mini-kitchens and cozy cubes will create a great atmosphere of learning for 148 children.
Please help the girls and boys of SouthSide find their furniture by making a gift today.  A child’s environment impacts their expectations of life, so you can raise their sights by helping us furnish their new classrooms. 
All gifts are tax deductible, plus you get a cool gift in return!  Most importantly, every mastered letter of the alphabet, every word scribbled in crayon, every shriek of laughter of these special girls and boys will be made possible because you cared.  Thank you.

The SouthSide StoryFor 128 years, SouthSide Early Chidhood Center has nurtured, educated and inspired boys and girls from low-income working families in the City of St. Louis. Our exceptionally high-quality early childhood program nurtures and educates children, building a strong foundation for school and life success. Through early education, intervention for disabilities and mental health challenges, and parent support and engagement, we close the achievement gap for our children before kindergarten.This summer, we are moving from our 60-year old building to a beautiful new early childhood center where we can serve even more children, expanding from 98 to 148, ages six weeks to pre-kindergarten.This campaign will enable us to fill our beautiful new classrooms with the new furniture and learning materials that our children deserve. With your help we will continue to enrich the lives of young children in need. Your investment in our children will pay great dividends in their lives, setting the stage for success.Let's Spread the Word!
Got friends? Please tell them what SouthSide is doing to make a difference in the lives of children that may have been born into disadvantage, but with our help and their parents' support, are on their way to a much brighter future!
Please get the word out on your social networks - use the great Indiegogo share tools to give everyone you know a chance to learn about what we do and invest in our children.

 
PERKS!
For a $50 donation, you will receive an attractive coffee mug with the SouthSide logo!  

 A $100 donation delivers a sturdy water bottle to your door, just in time for summer!


If you choose to invest $250 in our project, we will send you both the coffee cup and water bottle, as well as a selection of delicious chocolates made by our neighbor, Kakao Chocolate.
Our top perks will commemorate your gift with your own inscribed brick, placed in our sidewalk along the front of our building. If you choose this level, we will be in touch to confirm your choice of inscription.

story:
Short Summary

Hi! I'm Jasmine and I'm a scholarship student, in my junior year at the Columbus School for Girls. If I raise enough money, I can join my classmates on a service trip to Guatemala. While we're there we are going to help build a house for a single mom and her kids, teach English to schoolchildren, make and serve food to kids and their families at an after-school program, provide translation services, and even learn from a local artist.

I'm an artist and I love learning and speaking Spanish.

When I was 10 years old I took a month long trip to the Yucatan peninsula in Mexico. Despite the stress of travel, intense heat, mosquitoes, giant cockroaches and occasional illness, I realized on that trip that I love to experience new places and culture. Ever since then I've been longing to go back to Central America. I practice my Spanish all the time! This year my school has given me, and other Spanish students, the opportunity to visit Guatemala, to learn, to help, to grow. 

I will be staying in San Pedro La Laguna with a host family. One of the members of the host family is a kindergarten teacher so we will be working in the school, giving micro-lessons in English, helping to paint classrooms and preparing and serving food in an after school program. We also will be helping to build one or two homes for families of the school. 

  

This trip would give me the opportunity to improve my Spanish, inspire my creativity, promote my global literacy, and provide service for people who need it.

What I Need & What You Get

I need $2,625. This money funds my airfare, transportation in Guatemala, meals, lodging and costs for host family. It also pays for some of the classroom crafts, paint, donation to help the school, and building materials for the homes we will help build. 

The perks! 

The minimum donation that receives a perk is $15, for which one will receive a watercolor or an ink and watercolor combination postcard, along with a handwritten poem. For $25 dollars the perk is the same, but you get a set of three! This changes at $50 dollars, for which I will send a black and white photo print that I took and printed myself (8x11). For $100+ I will send two of these prints.

                                          

Other Ways You Can Help

I understand many of you just plain can't contribute and that's fine! But spread the word! Alert others! This means the world to me and if you can't help monetarily feel free to use the Indiegogo share tools and make some noise!

story:
Parent of CFTOR 2013 participant:

By participating in this project, 
Miles developed the confidence to talk to, and question, and thus genuinely appreciate the perspectives of people very different than himself. Upon his return, the depth of the connections he had made enabled him to effortlessly articulate aspects of the journey that he found poignant. Empowering teens in this way is bound to have a positive impact how they approach and tackle these challenging issues in their future. 



Find out more about our program,

View CFTOR 2013 SHORTS,

Read What STUDENTS AND PARENTS ARE SAYING about their experience.


http://www.conversationsfromtheopenroad.com


TAX DEDUCTIBLE DONATIONS CAN BE MADE, via postal service, TO OUR FISCAL SPONSOR:

Vermont Folklife Center

88 Main Street, Middlebury, VT 05753

ATTENTION: Conversations From the Open Road

story:
Dear Lovely People!!

Well, I have reached the end of my fundraising campaign and have raised an amazing £1455! What a fantastic journey it has been.

Words are not enough to describe my gratitude towards each and every one of you, it has meant the world to me and will make a big difference to my life (and hopefully to the life of others when I qualify).  This experience has shown me the kindness and generosity that exists in others hearts, and that is a treasure in itself.

£1455 is nearly two months instalment fees, so I am ON THE COURSE no matter what. I also will be starting a new job late September as a brain injury case manager, and once my case load is up and running I will be in a better position to manage my fees.

I am making my final batch of cards, wishes, brooches and bags over the next two weeks. So sorry for delays, I always under estimate how long it takes me to make things! But rest assured they are on their way. Also, in a few weeks time I will be selling brooches on my Etsy page (I will post link later) so if you wished to purchase more, you know where to go! (cheeky plug).

I sincerely promise to pay forward the kindness I have received from you all. And I will keep you updated with how my course is going.

Thank you all so much again.

Lots of love and hugs

Xxx Emma

 

 

The whys and whats of it all:

Thank you so much for your time in reading about my campaign to raise funding towards the first year of my masters in arts psychotherapy.

Unfortunately government funding does not exist for this part time masters (I am studying part time as need to continue working throughout), and I am unable to get a bank loan to pay my fees.... Although I am able to able save a small part of my salary towards funding this I will be not be able to raise all the funds independently. That is why I have started this fund raising campaign.

I understand this is a big ask, but I am trying every possible avenue to secure funding. Any amount, no matter how large or small you might be able to donate towards the funding my course would be so greatly appreciated.

A bit of background for you:

There are two main reasons I feel so passionate about wishing to train as an art psychotherapist. Firstly, I have been through my own personal journey with depression and art was an integral part of my recovery. Because of this I strongly believe I can contribute to others recovery by working as an art psychotherapist.

Secondly, I currently work as an occupational therapist and undertake rehabilitation with individuals recovering from the devastating impact of stroke. I have observed that in traditional settings stroke patient’s psychological needs are frequently unmet, even though they are often experiencing great trauma and loss. I believe that art therapy would be a ‘way in’ with this client group to help them explore psychological difficulties they may be going through and allow emotional expression through non-verbal means. This is especially important for individuals experiencing language or cognitive impairment, which is so common after stroke. I feel very passionate about this and believe that I could make a difference to individuals recovering from stroke using art therapy as a medium.

It is because of these two reasons that I am desperately trying to get together funding for the first year of my masters in art psychotherapy, which I will be studying at Goldsmiths University.

If you would like to know more about me or my art please see my blog and my flickr portfolio:

http://miss-stitch-therapy.blogspot.co.uk/

http://www.flickr.com/photos/stitch-therapy/sets/72157633449100106/

What I Needs & What You Gets:

What I needs...

The cost of the masters is £4240 a year and in total £12,720 over three years (gulp).

In addition to fees and living costs I have to pay for personal therapy every week (a course requirement).

What you gets...

Well by contributing you get some amazing perks as you can see (!), but seriously, I wish I could give more back to you.  All I can say is that I will sincerely commit to this course and doing meaningful and healing work with people who seek art therapy.

The Impact:

Getting the fees for the first year of this course would make an amazing difference to my life and give me an opportunity to do something I am 100% passionate about and believe is my life mission. 

When qualified I will commit to giving back to my local community and ensuring that art psychotherapy will be available for those on low income.

Other Ways You Can Help:

If you can't contribute with money there are others ways you can help:

1. please do share my campaign with your friends, family and on your social networking sites.

2. send as many positive thoughts, prayers and magic pixies my way as possible. 

Thank you so much x

story:
Africanwire is an artificial-leg start up manufacturing company based in Kenya, East Africa.It is the idea of of enterpreneur and experienced industrial designer,Andrew Muriuki, working with a small team of artisans. Our mission is to locally produce low-cost artificial legs to assist the hundreds of amputees who loose their limbs through car accidents, disease and conflict injuries. Their choices today are either heavy, uncomfortable wooden appendages,metal crutches or expensive imported prosthesis (artificial limbs) whose prices start at $5,000 to $80,000!There is no local manufacturer in the region because of a shortage of specialized design skills as well as the perception that this is non-profitable business and which is better suited to not-for-profit social enterprise. Many investors therefore remain uninterested, ignoring a business opportunity that will create employment and also impact many amputees, enabling them to reintegrate back into society.We are asking for your help to get started.

We need to raise $90,000 (the cost of just ONE high-end prosthesis!) to build and equip a workshop here in Kenya with the equipement that will enable us to profitably make simple,functional artificial legs that will have a sale price of no more than $50.
At the moment, the single biggest design and manufactering impediment is that each prosthesis must be an exact fit on the the victims amputed limb to avoid discomfort by the wearer. By using 3D scanner and 3D printer technology,we will revolutionize the manufacturing method, so that it is quicker, accurate, more effect and cheaper.The other components will be made from steel tubes, epoxy resin and polyurethane rubber, all available locally.
Now we are turning to you to ask for contributions to provide the seed money to purchase this equipment, build a workshop, along with basic workshop equipment (welders, grinders, drill etc) and raw the materials to make this possible. In exchange,and in addition to our heartfelt gratitude, we will reward our supporters with an awesome range of limited edition, african-inspired jewelry and desktop ornaments created by master craftsmen from Africa.

We need to get this project moving quickly because of the large number of people in need. Kenya has the 6th highest rate of car accidents in the world - over 4,000 fatalities a year and tens of thousands injured. Statistics on leg amputations is scanty, but we can surmise that the number is growing rapidly.Most victims are young and have no medical insurance cover. We are inspired by similar initiatives in other countries, such as India who developed their inexpensive Jaipur Foot over 20 years ago to the benefit of thousands.The high costs of freight and import duties means that local manufacture remains the only viable solution.With your support and contributions we will all make a real difference to very many lives.

story:
Short Summary

I'm heading to Kenya to mentor students in their efforts to implement a Community Health project. I graduated with my Bachelor's degree in Public Health with an emphasis in Global Health. I have always had a deep desire to do humanitarian work in Africa and have been given this opportunity. I am raising money for the rest of the amount I need for my portion and to raise money for purchasing of supplies from the community to build the school that we are going to be building this year. 

In each of our sites, Youthlinc gathers information in advance about the most pressing medical and health needs. From that information, the Community Health committees work to organize health fairs, raise funds, and bring medical equipment to each community. Youthlinc does not operate open clinics at its international sites. Holding ‘come one, come all’ clinics is not sustainable.  Knowledge and understanding is sustainable.  Clinic work is only done within the area of expertise of the medical professional we bring, and in concert and under the direction of village health professionals. Opportunities for professional exchange, within the village and in local medical facilities are part of the Youthlinc international experience.

This is your opportunity to help those in Africa. All money raised will go to the trip and supplies/donations. Every dollar counts and helps!

What We Need & What You Get

Donations to support a variety of quality of life improvements in the villages we serve in developing countries. 

All the PERKS include a print of your choice (All photos were taken by me). The following are your options:

Option 1:

story:
This is A Means To Function!

After an automobile accident in 2007, I opened up, to a variety of healing techniques and therapies.  In 2008, I discovered the Nia Technique, a sensory-based movement platform.  For the past several years, I have danced Nia, and now I am preparing to take the next step in my training, which is the first level teacher certification.

The reason I feel so passionate about this work, is it has healed some deep rooted pains in my emotional, psychological and physical self.  The trauma of my accident was the direct repercussion of choices I was making in my life.  I am here to be a teacher and a healer, and to be of service to my community! 

Nia is - the next step - as a conduit for greater healing.  I work with a variety of children with special needs, learning disabilities, processing variances and the Autism Spectrum.  And, I am excited to integrate this technique into my process! 

Your Means will help me Function! 

This funding ensures certified training with the NIA Technique.  The first level White Belt training is scheduled for March 19-25, 2011 in Portland, Oregon.  The cost will include the course training, travel expenses and teacher certification.  Cost breakdown:  Intensive ($1600) + Hotel ($700) + Flight ($570) + Certification ($520) + Transportation ($180) + Service Fees ($180). 

Please email: gabi.bliss@gmail.com with questions or comments of interest.

How A Means To Function will be of service:

By April 2011, I will integrate the Nia Technique into my mobile program, serving individuals with special needs, learning disabilities, processing variances and the Autism Spectrum.  By June 2011, I will introduce summer Intensives for teen girls ages 13-17.  I also want to be teaching regular Nia classes to the public.  I see myself one day taking Nia into centers of healing.  With further education and training, I want to help people with trauma, let go and heal.

Alternative Means to Function: 

There are many ways you can help!  If appropriate and available, please spread the word about my campaign.  Post the website address www.indiegogo/Means-To-Function on your favorite social network and send it out to your community.  Even donating a $2 good service tip will make an impact! 

You may also send gift cards for Whole Foods, as there is a kitchenette in the studio apartment where I am staying, during the week of my certification training.


Thank You for Everything You Are and for Supporting me with A Means To Function!  Love, Gabrielle

story:
Artificial Intelligence bots in an epic battle of StarCraft

In 2011 we started a tournament of AI bots that battle one another in probably the most popular strategy video game: StarCraft. These bots are made in programming language C++ by students worldwide. It teaches them all the advanced methods of artificial intelligence.

Tournament webpage: http://bwapiproject.netii.net/

YouTube channel: http://www.youtube.com/user/certicky/

My bot will kick your bot's ass! (Educational impact)

The tournament is extremely competitive, and it's exactly how it should be. After all, the best motivation is always beating everyone else in what you do. Students enjoy spending most of their free time by learning the AI techniques and programming, just to beat their friends in a game. Everybody gains some hands-on experience, and winners have a nice entry in their resumes before finishing school. This is what I call a progressive education!

What We Need

2011 year of the tournament had 50 participants! While this number is quite high, we hope to get even more in the following years. We also want to offer some interesting prizes for the winners. Help is needed with a couple of things:

  • Financial and/or material support for: prize money & trophies (obviously), domains & hosting, referees (there are hundreds of games to be played and watched), advertisement & PR services (ads and posters are not free, and we want every IT student to know about this)
  • Help with promotion: Make some noise about this! We want to see the tournament in newspapers, forums, school classes, web portals, twitter, facebook - simply anywhere. We will gladly return the favor by linking back to you or mentioning your name.
  • Ideas and support in gaming community: We would love to work with some StarCraft commentators and casters, gaming portals, etc. Any new ideas are most welcome.

What You Get

Tournament's website has a significant number of visitors consisting of programmers, AI researchers and students of various IT specialisations. Videos on our YouTube channel have quite high view count. We're also planning some presentations on lead IT conferences. By contributing, you can get a cheap targeted advertisement in the IT and AI community, and some cool bonuses. Check out the perks (right side of the page) for details.
story_txt:
Artificial Intelligence bots in an epic battle of StarCraft

In 2011 we started a tournament of AI bots that battle one another in probably the most popular strategy video game: StarCraft. These bots are made in programming language C++ by students worldwide. It teaches them all the advanced methods of artificial intelligence. 

Tournament webpage: http://bwapiproject.netii.net/
YouTube channel: http://www.youtube.com/user/certicky/
My bot will kick your bot's ass! (Educational impact)

The tournament is extremely competitive, and it's exactly how it should be. After all, the best motivation is always beating everyone else in what you do. Students enjoy spending most of their free time by learning the AI techniques and programming, just to beat their friends in a game. Everybody gains some hands-on experience, and winners have a nice entry in their resumes before finishing school. This is what I call a progressive education!

What We Need
2011 year of the tournament had 50 participants! While this number is quite high, we hope to get even more in the following years. We also want to offer some interesting prizes for the winners. Help is needed with a couple of things:


Financial and/or material support for: prize money & trophies (obviously), domains & hosting, referees (there are hundreds of games to be played and watched), advertisement & PR services (ads and posters are not free, and we want every IT student to know about this)


Help with promotion: Make some noise about this! We want to see the tournament in newspapers, forums, school classes, web portals, twitter, facebook - simply anywhere. We will gladly return the favor by linking back to you or mentioning your name.

story:
Help Launch Maui's Hawaiian Voyaging Canoe,  The Mo’okiha o Pi’ilani

A Living Classroom - where our youth, residents, and visitors will learn voyaging arts of Polynesian ancestors who sailed across oceans using only the stars. They came to Maui and sustained an entire culture with plants and animals brought aboard their canoe… Help us preserve this knowledge and pass it on…

  • We are the Hui o Wa'a Kaulua “Assembly of the Double-Hull Canoe,” a 501(c) 3 non-profit, 100% volunteer organization formed in 1975 to practice, perpetuate and educate the Maui community on Hawaiian canoe building, wayfinding and Hawaiian voyaging arts.

  • Our campaign will raise $10K to launch Mo'okiha o Pi'ilani, a 62-foot Hawaiian trans-oceanic voyaging canoe. Excess funds will buy educational materials for 24 workshops scheduled for 2014.

  • As a supporter you are gifting the world and specifically our youth with knowledge that sustained a culture for millennia. Ancient Hawaiians followed familiar stars across vast oceans. In the canoe was everything needed for the journey building a new community.

  • Your gift puts Mo’okiha o Pi’ilani in the water so we can teach children these timeless skills: Celestial Navigation; Wayfinding by using winds, currents, and clues from flora and fauna; Sailing skills; Ocean Safety Procedures; Sustainability.

We need funds to launch this voyaging canoe and preserve Hawaiian culture for generations to come…  

Pass it On... Share it with your friends!

  • People who love Hawai’i: Click and make a donation.

  • Teachers: Excite your science class with the ocean and stars by following Mo’okiha’s launch.

  • Sailors: Learn what makes the Hawaiian voyaging canoe so unique. Travelers: Come to Maui and visit the canoe you helped launch!

Maui Residents, Parents, Kids, Maui Visitors...
We want to offer you some incredible incentives

  • Put this magnificent canoe in the water! The first $10K helps buy the last pieces of Marine emergency equipment.

  • Push us out beyond our goal! Everything over $10K goes to educational materials for our maiden voyage to 7 ports of call in the Hawaiian Islands.

  • Earn a Perk! Our incentives include Hawaiian canoe plant gardens, Star Compasses, Sailing aboard the Mo'olele, and Mo'okiha o Pi'ilani. Give generously and receive our Assembly of Double Hull Canoes T-shirts, a Limited Edition Logo Sticker, Loren Adams Posters, or Fine Art Prints.

The Impact! How you are making a difference

  • Our original $60,000 goal started early this summer with resurgence of our educational programs and goal to launch in December.

  • We hosted 24 educational programs, educated thousands of youth, built an onsite star compass, an educational Canoe Plant Garden, and have raised nearly $50,000.

  • THIS IS REAL! We are so close! Every $10 donation counts!

  • Our launch date is set for January 17th 2014! Less than two months away

  • Don’t delay --  we need you to accomplish this.

Other Ways You Can Help
Some people just can’t contribute, but that doesn’t mean you can’t help:

  • Please contact info@huiowaa.org to help us spread the news of this campaign

  • On Maui? Volunteer at our Dry Dock at 525 Front Street – Monday through Saturday – be a part of the launch team.

  • Volunteer in our Office or as staff for the Launch Event.

  • Click here to use the  easy Indiegogo share tools online!

We can not thank you enough for supporting this GOAL!

Mahalo from our family to yours.

story:
Hey guys! I have created this crowdfunding website in hopes to follow a dream of mine to travel to Italy this summer, 2014. For starters, my name is Adam Crew. I am from Birmingham, AL, where I have lived for the majority of my life. I have, in the past year, been tossing around this idea in my head of escaping America and traveling to Italy for part of my summer. I have also, in the past year, realized that paying for such a trip is turning out nearly impossible. I have been working full time, but I have also been in school and paying for school so the money that I have saved has not added up. I understand that my struggle is a common one, and I am not on here looking for sympathy. This is just a last ditch effort of sorts. With summer already here and the window for my trip a month away, I am calling on people that may have chased similar dreams before, or just had a dream like this, that may can relate to my story. I am sending this out to the people I love, and potentially to people that I have never met before, asking for help to pay for my plane ticket. I have some money saved up, but it just is not enough unfortunately. The past two years of my life have been a complete whirlwind experience. They have been filled with plenty of sorrow, but a lot of joy recently as well. A range of emotions and being fed up with pondering ideas, and watching my close friends traveling around the world has led me here to this site. I have two close friends that flew to Italy yesterday, and they are staying there the whole summer. If I were able to get to Italy I would have a free place to stay with them, which is a special opportunity. To be able to explore another country with people that I love is beyond my imagination, and I know it would change my life forever. I do not expect anyone who reads this to donate money, but if you do feel like helping me, my gratitude to you will be infinite. If I do not raise enough money on my own/through this site, to get to Italy, all of the donated money will be returned. Thank you so much for taking the time to read this.  

Also, since I am using this site to raise money strictly for my travel, if you have any frequent flyer miles that you may not use, those would also be greatly appreciated. Thanks!

story:
Short Summary

My name is Mario Rodriguez. I am a husband, and father of 3. I served in the U.S. Navy from 2002 to 2006. I made many friends in the service from all branches and continue to meet many others who have served or are currently serving our country. I,  like many veterans suffer mentally from the transition back to civilian life. I am personally invested in bettering the situation for underserved veterans across the nation. My mission is for every veteran to return to a sustainable future. I want to break the cycle of helplessness. I believe all veterans can experience positive lifestyles knowing they have resources to help guide their success. I believe veterans can be the most productive citizens in the world, able to overcome all barriers with the right help. 

With your help we can bring the 7.3% unemployment rate for veterans down. We can ensure the 1 in 3 veterans that return home with some form of mental health issues has support and guidance to ease the already big burden they have been put through. We can coach them in resume writing and interview skills to help them succeed in transfering their military experience into the civilian job market.

What We Need & What You Get

We need $4000 to get this start up going. That will secure a lawyer for legalities, get office equipment, and allow us to file all paperwork necessary on the state and government levels. We work hard to get resources to help through the transitioning process, and ask for donations of interview attire for those that may not be able to purchase their own. We have many resources who are veterans themselves and can relate to the effort needed to get help for these issues.

Other ways you can help

We are always looking for volunteers for fundraising. We also would love for you to offer your professional exprience if you can help in our cause. None of this is would be availiable without you. The biggest help can also be through word of mouth. So please join us to make a better transition for those who selflessly served to protect us.

story:
Be Part of the Transformation

Your gift to The Art of Practicing Institute will help musicians who are struggling with tension, injury, and debilitating stage fright, break through to a new level of performance, become who they're meant to be, and bring more vibrant and compelling performances to their audiences.

Did you know that The New York Times reported that almost all classical musicians now rely on drugs known as beta-blockers to reduce the physical symptoms of stage fright? And that 75% of musicians develop injuries from practicing with excess tension?

The Art of Practicing Institute (also known as Golden Key Music Institute) is a non-profit organization founded by pianist Madeline Bruser, author of the internationally acclaimed book The Art of Practicing: A Guide to Making Music from the Heart. Rooted in the book's principles of mindfulness, healthy movement, sensory awareness, and rhythmic coherence and vitality, the institute offers a unique, comprehensive, cutting-edge training that helps musicians release tension, prevent and recover from practice-related injuries, stop relying on drugs to combat stage fright, transmit greater wisdom to their students, and perform with profound ease, confidence, and communicative power.

We invite you to join us. Together, we can change the lives of musicians today and in future generations.

What Musicians Say

"The work of The Art of Practicing Institute changed my life. It has enabled me to raise the level of my playing to an astonishing degree and has provided an oasis for my musical struggles."

Timothy Mueller, pianist, graduate of Eastman School of Music

"This work is magical. I have better tone and a kind of clarity that is beyond anything I ever imagined. I didn't realize that I could still make this kind of transformation and progress."

Tang-mei Shieh, pianist, graduate of Manhattan School of Music

"Practicing this way cuts to the core rather than working on the surface. I have much more ease in playing; tension is falling away."

Cathy Baerg, flutist, Faculty, Carleton University, Ottawa

"I began working with the approach of The Art of Practicing Institute after a performance-related injury. Almost immediately, my whole physical approach to the piano became lighter and freer, and I could play again without aggravating tyne injury. Even more importantly, my mental and emotional attitudes have improved--I have been enjoying practicing again."

Cathy Corcoran, accompanist and teacher, New York City

“Doing the three-step technique before each performance quite honestly transformed my experience of performing. I actually found myself enjoying the moment, and feeling like I could lose my ego to some extent and just 'give' the music to the audience. It's just turned my way of thinking around about what performance is actually about. ”

Felicity Corrie, cellist, Alumna, Cambridge University 

"I played tremendously better while practicing, with more energy and way less physical tension. The world needs this."

Roger Farwell, classical guitarist, Master of Music, Peabody Conservatory of Music


Your support can help us reach more musicians through the following important projects:

  • Scholarships for worthy musicians to attend our 2014 summer program 
  • Hiring a director and professional video crew to complete the shooting for a short video documentary about our work and a long educational video showing how the training described in the book The Art of Practicing actually looks, sounds, and works. (Please see our Videos page to get several glimpses of the unique training we offer in body mechanics, listening techniques, and developing the mind and heart.) 
  • Producing an audio of our unique and potent technique The Fearless Performing Exercise, which helps musicians gain access to their deepest communicative power and transform stage fright into generosity.  
  • Website development                   

Other Ways You Can Help

Invite friends and family to become part of the transformation.  Spread the word on social media. Tell everyone you know about our campaign. Send us your heart energy to help increase awareness of our work and of why it is important for musicians and their audiences--today, and in future generations.

story:
A New Radio Series Project

from The 


I'm Thomas Hampson, founder and director of The Hampsong Foundation.  I started Hampsong because I believe that classic song serves as a kind of diary of the history of various cultures.  Despite the excitement of the art form of opera, composers--and poets as well--continually try to tell the stories of our lives through song.  I want to celebrate the exciting art form of song that is built from the symbols of poetry inspiring the language of music, and to celebrate especially through new media projects.  I am excited to announce my foundation's next major project: Song: Mirror of the World radio series--and we need your help!

Built upon the Hampsong Foundation's highly successful 13-week Song of America radio series, Song: Mirror of the World presents and explores classic song, defined as poetry set to music, as a global identifier of the culture from which it came.  The series takes a broad, humanities-based approach to the role of song in society and its relationship to cultural movements, historical events, and the human experience, with a special focus on cross-cultural dialogues throughout the European continent, and between Europe and the United States.  

Song: Mirror of the World is a 13-week series which views classic song as the prism of a particular time, refracting and illuminating currents in politics, society, artistic creation, and intellectual thought.  

Like Song of America, Song: Mirror of the World is a project of the Hampsong Foundation and co-produced by the WFMT Radio Network.  

WITH YOUR HELP, Song: Mirror of the World 

will begin airing on WFMT Chicago in October 2014! 

(And, no matter where you are in the world, 

you can listen to WFMT live online at https://www.wfmt.com/!)

You can listen to the entire Song of America radio series here for free, on the website of The Hampsong Foundation.  The Hampsong Foundation will make programs from Song: Mirror of the World available for free online one year after the original airing on WFMT, and we plan to create curricular materials for a range of classroom situations, as well as a new website to support those materials, after the entire radio series is completed.

What We Need

Putting together a high-quality educational radio series is expensive, and we need your support to bring this series to hundreds of thousands of listeners!

Your support is crucial as we move forward with Song: Mirror of the World.  Through private donors, we raised funding for the first half of the costs, and we need your help with the second half.  The total cost of the 13-program series Song: Mirror of the World is $86,738, and we still need to raise half of that amount ($43,369).  

We are asking for you, the Hampsong community, to help us raise one fourth of the total amount: $21,685.  We have set-up a matching campaign with a private donor so that every dollar that you donate to help us fund Song: Mirror of the World will be matched by a private donation.  

If we reach our goal by May 31, 2014, we will be able to proceed with the creation of Song: Mirror of the World on schedule.  If we exceed our goal, the extra funds will be put toward the building and dissemination of teaching materials with these radio programs.  Stay tuned!

 Your donation supports:

  • our script writers, who so far have included leading musicologists in the field like Dr. Susan Youens (University of Notre Dame), Dr. Benjamin Binder (Duquesne University), Dr. Scott Burnham (Princeton University), Jeff Lunden (freelance arts reporter and producer for NPR), Sheila Gaffney (screenwriter), Dr. Heather Platt (Ball State University), Dr. Stephen Rodgers (University of Oregon), Dr. Morten Solvik (IES Abroad Vienna), and Dr. Laura Tunbridge (University of Manchester), among others;

  • our coordinating producer Miriam Lewin (Lavine Production Group), who unifies the tone and language of the entire series, and our editor Carolyn Paulin at WFMT, who creates the actual programs from the raw audio materials;

  • production fees, meaning costs for both studio recording sessions for the narrative and the physical editing of the programs;

  • research and material costs.

What You Get

We have some wonderful "perks" to thank you for your donation, including an official thank you on our website and digital downloads.  You can read about them on the right sidebar.  Most importantly, you receive the thanks of hundreds of thousands of people who have a chance to explore the world of classical music and history through these programs.

Project Impact

Creating a radio series that tells the history of culture through classic song is a lifelong goal of mine.  With the international success of The Hampsong Foundation's first radio series project, Song of America, we knew that we had opened an important dialogue about the narration of cultural history through song.

The Song of America radio series aired on over 300 radio stations and 9 out of the top 10 markets in the United States.  According to data gathered by the WFMT Radio Network, Song of America reached a cumulative number of 5.3 million listeners in the United States and was one of the WFMT Radio Network’s most successful series. Song of America was also made available by the European Broadcasting Union to its 48 member stations in 2012 and reached another 3.1 million listeners abroad.  Stations outside of the United States, which aired the series, included Raidió Teilifís Éireann (Ireland's National Public Service Broadcaster), New Zealand Public Radio (NZPR), and public radio stations in Croatia, Romania, Denmark, Latvia, Serbia, the Czech Republic, and Germany, among others.  Since the series is now available online for free (on the website of the Hampsong Foundation), Song of America has reached listeners worldwide on all continents.

We plan to bring Song: Mirror of the World to an even broader radio community and to use the series as the backbone for a new Hampsong Foundation website with even deeper resources about song, as well as curricular materials for students of all ages.

Other Ways You Can Help

Any donation, no matter how small, is helpful to us in the creation of Song: Mirror of the World, and we are thankful for your support.  Even if you can't give a donation, you can still support the creation of Song: Mirror of the World if you:

  • Share our campaign through social media, such as Facebook and Twitter!
  • Like us on Facebook, follow us on Twitter, or sign-up for our newsletter.
  • Spread the word about The Hampsong Foundation's open-source online resources, including invaluable audio resources like the Song of America radio series and the Singers on Singing: Great Artists in Conversation archive.  Visit our website at http://hampsongfoundation.org.

About The Hampsong Foundation

The Hampsong Foundation is a 501(c)(3) non-profit organization founded in 2003 by American baritone Thomas Hampson and achieving non-profit status in 2005. 

The Hampsong Foundation, in its short existence and in collaboration with key academic and cultural partners, has created diverse platforms for the study and proliferation of the art of classic song--defined as poetry set to music--as an identifier of cultures through their arts and humanities.

As we witness the continued pressure on the liberal arts in general across the world, as well as the specific dismantling of arts and humanities classes both in America and abroad, the Hampsong Foundation is in a unique position to provide, through new media and interactive databases, curricular support and eventually direct curricular materials to classroom teachers at all levels.  The specific agenda of the Hampsong Foundation to teach cultural history through the eyes of poets and the ears of composers in civics, history, music and humanities classes enriches the understanding of one’s own culture in relationship to others and encourages students to engage their knowledge of a cultural historic perspective through the arts. 

In carrying out its mission, the Hampsong Foundation’s primary operating environment is the exciting new world of educational technologies.  

Visit our website http://hampsongfoundation.org for more information and to view our multimedia projects.
story_txt:
A New Radio Series Projectfrom The 
I'm Thomas Hampson, founder and director of The Hampsong Foundation.  I started Hampsong because I believe that classic song serves as a kind of diary of the history of various cultures.  Despite the excitement of the art form of opera, composers--and poets as well--continually try to tell the stories of our lives through song.  I want to celebrate the exciting art form of song that is built from the symbols of poetry inspiring the language of music, and to celebrate especially through new media projects.  I am excited to announce my foundation's next major project: Song: Mirror of the World radio series--and we need your help!Built upon the Hampsong Foundation's highly successful 13-week Song of America radio series, Song: Mirror of the World presents and explores classic song, defined as poetry set to music, as a global identifier of the culture from which it came.  The series takes a broad, humanities-based approach to the role of song in society and its relationship to cultural movements, historical events, and the human experience, with a special focus on cross-cultural dialogues throughout the European continent, and between Europe and the United States.  Song: Mirror of the World is a 13-week series which views classic song as the prism of a particular time, refracting and illuminating currents in politics, society, artistic creation, and intellectual thought.  Like Song of America, Song: Mirror of the World is a project of the Hampsong Foundation and co-produced by the WFMT Radio Network.  WITH YOUR HELP, Song: Mirror of the World will begin airing on WFMT Chicago in October 2014! (And, no matter where you are in the world, you can listen to WFMT live online at https://www.wfmt.com/!)You can listen to the entire Song of America radio series here for free, on the website of The Hampsong Foundation.  The Hampsong Foundation will make programs from Song: Mirror of the World available for free online one year after the original airing on WFMT, and we plan to create curricular materials for a range of classroom situations, as well as a new website to support those materials, after the entire radio series is completed.What We NeedPutting together a high-quality educational radio series is expensive, and we need your support to bring this series to hundreds of thousands of listeners!Your support is crucial as we move forward with Song: Mirror of the World.  Through private donors, we raised funding for the first half of the costs, and we need your help with the second half.  The total cost of the 13-program series Song: Mirror of the World is $86,738, and we still need to raise half of that amount ($43,369).  We are asking for you, the Hampsong community, to help us raise one fourth of the total amount: $21,685.  We have set-up a matching campaign with a private donor so that every dollar that you donate to help us fund Song: Mirror of the World will be matched by a private donation.  If we reach our goal by May 31, 2014, we will be able to proceed with the creation of Song: Mirror of the World on schedule.  If we exceed our goal, the extra funds will be put toward the building and dissemination of teaching materials with these radio programs.  Stay tuned! Your donation supports:
our script writers, who so far have included leading musicologists in the field like Dr. Susan Youens (University of Notre Dame), Dr. Benjamin Binder (Duquesne University), Dr. Scott Burnham (Princeton University), Jeff Lunden (freelance arts reporter and producer for NPR), Sheila Gaffney (screenwriter), Dr. Heather Platt (Ball State University), Dr. Stephen Rodgers (University of Oregon), Dr. Morten Solvik (IES Abroad Vienna), and Dr. Laura Tunbridge (University of Manchester), among others;
our coordinating producer Miriam Lewin (Lavine Production Group), who unifies the tone and language of the entire series, and our editor Carolyn Paulin at WFMT, who creates the actual programs from the raw audio materials;
production fees, meaning costs for both studio recording sessions for the narrative and the physical editing of the programs;
research and material costs.
What You GetWe have some wonderful "perks" to thank you for your donation, including an official thank you on our website and digital downloads.  You can read about them on the right sidebar.  Most importantly, you receive the thanks of hundreds of thousands of people who have a chance to explore the world of classical music and history through these programs.Project ImpactCreating a radio series that tells the history of culture through classic song is a lifelong goal of mine.  With the international success of The Hampsong Foundation's first radio series project, Song of America, we knew that we had opened an important dialogue about the narration of cultural history through song.The Song of America radio series aired on over 300 radio stations and 9 out of the top 10 markets in the United States.  According to data gathered by the WFMT Radio Network, Song of America reached a cumulative number of 5.3 million listeners in the United States and was one of the WFMT Radio Network’s most successful series. Song of America was also made available by the European Broadcasting Union to its 48 member stations in 2012 and reached another 3.1 million listeners abroad.  Stations outside of the United States, which aired the series, included Raidió Teilifís Éireann (Ireland's National Public Service Broadcaster), New Zealand Public Radio (NZPR), and public radio stations in Croatia, Romania, Denmark, Latvia, Serbia, the Czech Republic, and Germany, among others.  Since the series is now available online for free (on the website of the Hampsong Foundation), Song of America has reached listeners worldwide on all continents.We plan to bring Song: Mirror of the World to an even broader radio community and to use the series as the backbone for a new Hampsong Foundation website with even deeper resources about song, as well as curricular materials for students of all ages.Other Ways You Can HelpAny donation, no matter how small, is helpful to us in the creation of Song: Mirror of the World, and we are thankful for your support.  Even if you can't give a donation, you can still support the creation of Song: Mirror of the World if you:
Share our campaign through social media, such as Facebook and Twitter!
Like us on Facebook, follow us on Twitter, or sign-up for our newsletter.
Spread the word about The Hampsong Foundation's open-source online resources, including invaluable audio resources like the Song of America radio series and the Singers on Singing: Great Artists in Conversation archive.  Visit our website at http://hampsongfoundation.org.
About The Hampsong FoundationThe Hampsong Foundation is a 501(c)(3) non-profit organization founded in 2003 by American baritone Thomas Hampson and achieving non-profit status in 2005. The Hampsong Foundation, in its short existence and in collaboration with key academic and cultural partners, has created diverse platforms for the study and proliferation of the art of classic song--defined as poetry set to music--as an identifier of cultures through their arts and humanities.As we witness the continued pressure on the liberal arts in general across the world, as well as the specific dismantling of arts and humanities classes both in America and abroad, the Hampsong Foundation is in a unique position to provide, through new media and interactive databases, curricular support and eventually direct curricular materials to classroom teachers at all levels.  The specific agenda of the Hampsong Foundation to teach cultural history through the eyes of poets and the ears of composers in civics, history, music and humanities classes enriches the understanding of one’s own culture in relationship to others and encourages students to engage their knowledge of a cultural historic perspective through the arts. In carrying out its mission, the Hampsong Foundation’s primary operating environment is the exciting new world of educational technologies.  Visit our website http://hampsongfoundation.org for more information and to view our multimedia projects.

story:
Update 7th August:
Hi everyone! Check out these articles talking about our project.
Engineers Without Borders
Brightest Young Minds

One of the biggest problems facing young South Africans today is getting a decent education. Pupils in overcrowded classrooms have to share desks and chairs, and if they even get textbooks, they must share those as well.
It is common to see a class with 40 to 50 pupils with only one teacher. In a class like this individual attention for struggling students becomes almost impossible.

We hope to change all that.

Our Idea
We want to build a low-cost, energy efficient Raspberry Pi computer Lab for a school in Cosmo City. We also know that helping just one school isn't going to change the country, so the most important feature of our design is Scalability. This means that anyone, anywhere will be able to build the same computer lab for the same cost.
This means a standard model, and while there are many cheap computers out there, we've chosen the Raspberry Pi.

What We've Got
Thanks to the many generous people we have met along the way, we have a great deal lined up and ready to go. These include:
  • A Prefabricated classroom suitable to build this lab in
  • Training for Two Teachers
  • Free and Open Source learning software
  • A complete design for the lab and the solar fittings

What's Inside
More important than the hardware however is the content available on the computers. We will load various programs that are specifically designed to enhance the learners' education through multimedia, tutorials and tests. This includes programs such as:
  • Khan Academy
  • Numeric
  • RACHEL (thousands of eBooks, videos and Wikipedia pages)
  • Scratch

Where we need Your Help
All we need to build our first LAN is $10,500.
This will get us all the Raspberry Pi computers, monitors, keyboards, mouses and all the rest of the hardware.

(Update: If you choose any of the perks, please send us your Twitter or Facebook details to info info@solarpoweredlearning.com so we can send you a message)

Powered by The Sun
Solar Power is one of the leading forms of sustainable energy solutions. For this reason, we would love to power every lab this way.
Unfortunately, it is expensive.
If we are able to raise an additional $12,000, we will be able to power the computer lab using solar power, making it a sustainable solution for the school.

Collaborators
This project has been made possible thanks to the generous input of:
  • Engineers Without Borders
  • Siyafunda

About United Twenty-13
The Solar Powered Raspberry Pi School project is being run under the auspices of the local Non Profit Company, United Twenty-13.

As a collective, our mission is to harness sustainable developmental change through youth driven initiatives. Our vision is to achieve long-term sustainable change in the City of Johannesburg and beyond.

United Twenty-13 is formed by 10 ambassadors from the One Young World 2013 Summit. The 10 young leaders were selected to be part of the City of Johannesburg Mayoral Delegation to the summit and decided to form the NPC thereafter.

Registration number: 2014/044519/07

story:
I'm an actress passionate about the arts and my dream has always been to become a great theater writer. I've been blessed with opportunities like a working schoolarship at Bucknell University and this half schoolarship in Peru I just got, but since I've never enjoyed the priviledges of wealth now I come to you for help to raise $1.600 which is the part I need to pay of the dramaturgy course.

By now I've got around $800 that I need for my basic needs, like transportation, a place to stay and food for the first couple of months. I intend to work in Peru as a waitress to maintain myself, but the $1.600 I need them in advance to enter the course.

Entering this course is the first step on my way of becoming the next great Colombian female playwright. 

I'm not asking for a lot from each one, all I'm asking is that if you have a little bit to give I would really appreciate it. If you can't help me, please feel free to pass this along to someone who can. 


Thanks for reading and caring.

story:
Remember The Fun Field Trips You Went On?

Growing up, some of my best school memories and events that inspired me to learn on my own were school field trips. Think back on some of the trips your school went on or some of the places you wished you could have visited when you were young. How much more did you get out of experiencing them first hand rather than reading about them in a book?

California has continuously made budget cuts to our schools and, sadly, our school is not lucky enough to have private funding readily available. Our school is located in a low income area where parents can't afford to make up the gap in funding. 

We are trying to reach out to anybody who shares our belief that field trips spark a child's curiosity and inspires them to learn beyond the four walls of a classroom.


Help Us Inspire Our Students 

We are trying to raise enough funding to take our second graders on a few field trips before the end of the school year. The money we raise will go towards busses, lunches, and admission fees to museums, aquariums, planetariums, fire and police stations, zoos, etc. The trips will depend on how much money we raise. The more we raise the more opportunities we can provide to these classes and next year's classes.

Even if we don't reach our entire goal we are hoping to get enough to fund at least one field trip for our students.


The Impact

It's amazing to see our children excited about learning and connecting the information they learn in the classroom to real world applications.

As a teacher, I need your help to give our second graders learning opportunities they wouldn't have otherwise. It's important to provide our children with hands on experiences that engage and reinforce their learning in fun and exciting ways. Field Trips leave a lasting impression on them.


Other Ways You Can Help

If you are a local business owner or manager, and you think our students can learn practical, real world applications from your business, we would greatly appreciate you donating admission fees or accommodating our students at your business.

story:
Please partner with me as I challenge myself to run 50 miles in 50 days for Areivim.

Kids sometimes fall though the cracks. I know, mine did. I cannot tell you how many schools and programs proved to be a poor fit for my child. Areivim, which is best known for their quick and effective response during crisis,  including, but not limited to: drug overdose, arrests, teen suicides and more, recently opened both a girls and boys high school. These programs  require experienced counselors, around the clock dedication and the ability to network in multiple communities and services. Areivim constantly rises to the challenge. Their passion to help , as well as their skills seems unlimited. Sadly, their finances are not.

I am committed to helping them raise $7,500 to provide much needed scholarship . I am willing to push myself (and my new hip) to run the 50 miles in 50 days if you will partner by donating $50. Of course donations of more than $50 (or less) are gratefully accepted.

I know you are approached for many worthy causes. It would mean so much to me and  my family if you would support this amazing organization and allow them to service yet another child.

Thanks

Basyah (Beth) Weinreb,

A grateful parent

story:
Our Campaign:

Urban Impact at Rainier Avenue Church seeks to fund the first ever CDF Freedom Schools in Seattle and in Washington State. Freedom Schools provides summer enrichment programming that helps Kindergartend through 5th grade children fall in love with reading, increases their self-esteem, and generates more positive attitudes toward learning.

We need your help!  We have raised $23,500 of our $30,000 budget and need your help to contribute the remaining $6,500.

Our Background:

For more than 15 years, teachers, Urban Impact staff, children and families have gathered together to support Summer Day Camp at Rainier Avenue Church. This year, we’re expanding and we’re going to need your help. We’re aligning our longstanding, 21-year old Summer Day Camp program, with the CDF Freedom schools national model curriculum. Academic instruction will remain in the morning and fun enrichment activities will continue in the afternoons with weekly field trips. Your support ensures a level playing field for 60 children in Kindergarten through 5th grades.

The Challenge:

Rainier Avenue Church is located in an ethnically diverse neighborhood, Hillman City, located in Seattle’s Rainier Valley. While rapidly gentrifying, the neighborhood remains affected by pockets of poverty.  Low-income children are vulnerable to fall behind academically during the summer. By 9th grade, these disparities account for two-thirds of the achievement gap between middle/high and low income students.  Students who don’t read proficiently by third grade and who live in poverty are four times more likely to drop out of school. 27.8% of children in Rainier Valley’s 98118 zip code live in poverty, a risk factor for losing literacy skills over the summer.  At the two elementary schools closest to our site, Martin Luther King Jr. and Graham Hill, an average of 58% of 3rd-5th graders scored proficient on the state reading test (20% lower than the average proficiency for the district). For third graders, an average of just 53% of students at these two schools scored proficient on the state reading test (26% lower than the Seattle district average.)

Your Impact:

This year, we are implementing CDF Freedom Schools to address the appalling achievement gap poor and vulnerable children face. Today, we invite you to join us to make history. By adopting the CDF Freedom Schools curriculum, which focuses on literacy skills and helps children develop a passion for reading, we are leveling the playing field for the children of Rainier Valley. At the same time, this is an opportunity for Urban Impact and Rainier Ave. Church to reach out to children in the neighborhood who might not otherwise have educational or safe summer options. As part of this new initiative, we are expanding on previous summers by extending camp to 5 days per week and serving breakfast. As part of the national model, parent and family involvement are a critical piece of a child’s education.So we’re adding a weekly parent workshop where families can come together to dialogue with each other and exchange best practices.  

CDF Freedom Schools transforms children by changing their attitudes toward learning and instilling the truth that every child can make a difference. This type of change will position children to be future leaders and change-agents in schools, businesses, government, schools, and neighborhoods.

Our Vision:

The Freedom Schools curriculum aligns participatory literacy activities with Common Core standards along the weekly themes: “I Can Make a Difference in: My Self, My Family, My Community, My Country, and My World with Hope, Education and Action.” Each curriculum activity is designed around a common core competency, which reinforces the skills scholars already have, and prepares scholars for skills they will need in the following school year. The curriculum focuses on social justice themes from the Civil Rights era onward. The books feature characters that reflect the multi-ethnic diversity of the Rainier Valley. These culturally rich stories help scholars relate to books as they process their own experiences, cultural heritage, and history through the eyes of children.

$6,500 for 60 child scholars this summer in Seattle, this money will help fund:

 - $25 can provide 3 books for one child in Freedom Schools
 - $50 can power a summer field trip experience for one child
 - $100 can provide one child with dance, swimming and enrichment classes
 - $150 could mean optimal learning with a 1:10 scholar to teacher ratio
- $350 could fund the remaining expense gap of 6 weeks of tuition for one child

Make a Difference and Share Our Story! 

Tell your networks: share our post on Facebook, Tweet, Instagram us and shout it from the rooftops all your social networks!  Use the Indiegogo share tools!

story:
SPONSOR A CHILD...check the "Perks"

What is "smART play"?

"smART play" will be an after school enrichment center in Encinitas, CA designed to provide a safe environment for kids that will allow them to freely express themselves. It will be franchised and spread across the whole United States. It will offer creative classes for children grades 1-12 in improvisation, film, music, art, creative writing, and dance. Public Schools cannot provide this for children, but I can. I have the background, the skill, the passion, the knowledge, the understanding of how greatly art positively affects children growing up, and most importantly; the support and qualified staff that will help make "smART play" successful. Kids still deserve this opportunity, and it is my mission to provide it for them.

If you are aware of this rising epidemic of childhood depression, anxiety, and ADHD diagnosis, then you will understand WHY this is mandatory. I have done the research on how the arts can and WILL reduce these numbers, and it is indisputable. The links to the scientific research are all provided on the bottom of this campaign.

Original campaign video (has a few more details about "smART play"): https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=Gbvq15A8VGY

Arts and Learning

"When you are doing art, your brain is working on all 8 cylinders at full speed which cause profound and seemingly permanent changes in the brain. A child's ability to keep a rhythm is correlated with the ability to read. Brain areas are developed as the child learns songs and rhymes, and creates drawings and finger paintings. The dancing and movements during play develop motor skills, and the sum of these activities enhances emotional well-being. And sharing their artwork enhances social skills."

Arts and Healing

"Scientific studies tell us that art heals by changing a person's physiology and attitude. Art and music put a person in a different brain wave pattern. Art and music affect every cell in the body instantly to create a healing physiology that changes the immune system and blood flow to all the organs. Art and Music change attitude, emotional state, and pain perception. They create hope and positivity and they help people cope with difficulties. In fact it is now known by neurophysiologists that art, prayer, and healing all come from the same source in the body." 


My Background and Mission

I am Giovanna Maimone, and I have always loved art. All kinds. It was a way for me to work through my pains as a child and make it all better, but now I understand what it has also done for my intellect. I wrote poetry, created visual art, and studied acting at a young age. I then went to a Performing Arts High School for Drama in New Jersey where I grew up, and then on to The University of Southern California's School of Theater in Los Angeles. It was there I started tutoring Math and working with children.

I still work with kids tutoring Math and English, and have my own production company J.C.M. Productions, Inc. www.jcmproductions.us. I also play guitar, percussion, paint, draw, dance, and write songs, movies, films, and stories. I could not imagine my life without art. It has also made me able to learn more, care more, to be a better listener, more compassionate, expressive, ambitious, and confident....all the things important in human development. I know that it was art, as all the studies have proven, that contributed to my accomplishments and my spiritual well being. Kids now, unfortunately do not have those outlets made available to them and the diagnosis of childhood depression, anxiety, and ADHD is rising!

Art was introduced to me very early on in school. We had art class, music class, dance class, creative writing class, and school plays. Where are the arts in schools now? Where are our children supposed to get exposed to the arts so it will improve their quality of learning and living?  And reduce these childhood conditions? That's where I come in. I am ready to combine my business knowledge, my lifelong training and participation in the arts, and my love for; working with and helping kids learn and be more confident by tapping into their creativity, and becoming smART kidz!

What Funds are Needed and What Your Contribution Means

I need a total of about $100,000 just to open my first location.  The $20,000 cash I raise from this campaign will got towards rent, insurance, instructors payroll and immediate cash expenses. I will be renting an open warehouse space of about 3000sq feet. Renovations, which require permits, are needed to build a sound proof room for the movie making/editing, and music classes. There will be a section for day care so that babies and toddlers will have exposure to the arts while they play all day. The main room will have art tables and non toxic recycled art supplies and a dance area with a removable stage area for improvisation. The room will be safe, padded, non toxic and energy efficient and your contributions will help me provide the safest environment for these children.

I truly believe in my heart that art can help heal, and science has proven that art creates a stronger working machine (brain) for our kids. Children are being diagnosed with depression and disorders left and right and I don't think it's a coincidence that the numbers have increased, soon after art got eliminated out of the public school systems. Your contribution along with my mission will help these kids, and give them what they deserve to have; a better quality of life. If you ever "wished that there was something you could do"... by helping me open "smART play", you will not only be helping children in San Diego, you will endlessly  be helping children across our nation! This first location is the start of "smART play" Franchises all across the United States! I promise, this is just the beginning.

Other Ways You Can Help

Please help share this campaign. By sharing it to your friends, family, and coworkers across our country will impact the whole country. "smART play"TM IS the next center for our children, to get their childhood back. You can share this campaign through the indiegogo sharing tools and icons, or just copy and paste to Facebook, or send in an email. Even your emotional support and prayers are helpful. Your support for "smART play", shows your support for our kids. Let's make sure they get what they deserve to have. Thank you for your time and help, and for being smART! :)

Reference Links

http://www.aaas.org/news/how-engaging-art-affects-human-brain

http://online.wsj.com/news/articles/SB10001424052748703699204575017050699693576

http://www.aasa.org/SchoolAdministratorArticle.aspx?id=7378

http://www.artashealing.org/ahfw3.htm

Public Schools cannot provide this for children, but I can. story:
Four year old Gabrielle Pinette has an inoperable brain tumor, and has been dealing with it for the majority of her young life. Her mother, who is Gabrielle’s sole parent, has had to travel between her home in Kelowna and BC Children’s Hospital for over two years to get her the treatment she needs. On October of this year Gabrielle is undergoing surgery in a final attempt to stop the spread of the tumor. Now, five young men from Fort Langley are going to try and help.

On October 11th the band will host a charity concert for Gabrielle at the Electric Owl and will hold a silent auction at the event. All profits from the event will go directly to the BC Children’s Hospital.

BESTiE // http://bbbestie.com/
Derrival // http://derrival.ca/
Alea Rae // http://alearae.ca/

Admission by donation at the door or online at http://igg.me/at/derrivalbcchildren

Doors at 7pm

story:
Google Glass and the RCMP

Hello all,

my name is Jay and I am photographer/blogger who is facing a major life change. I have recently been accepted into the RCMP and will be embarking upon a journey like no other. 

I will be spending the next 6 months training at a unique policing facility located in Saskatchewan. Though this facility has a long standing Canadian history, not many people know too much about it. I am hoping with all of your help we can change this. I currently run a website at http://www.adventuretraveler.org and I want to use Google Glasses as a tool to help to document and write about my experiences while training to become a Mountie. 

It has been a torturous hiring process that has taken me 11 months to complete and be accepted for the training program, leaving me dry of funds. With the help of this amazing community I would like to purchase a pair of glasses that will allow me to record my experiences in a way that has never been done before so I can educate the public. 

What I Need & What You Get

I will need $1900Can or $1500US to purchase the glasses which I will order and pickup in Michigan. Every cent raised will be going to this fund to help make this dream come true. 

As a contributor you will get a spotlight on my blog and will be able to choose how you would like to be represented. Whether you wish to remain anonymous or wish to have your logo on my site I am extremely flexible as to how I will repay you. I have a great social media presence as well as a large following on my site. 

If the total amount is not reached I will still use the funding towards the glasses once I save the remaining amount.  Since I will be isolated in a compound for 6 months I should be able to save some money easily however I really want to start the documentation right from the beginning which is why I am asking for your help. 

The Impact

By being able to write and record video about my experience from the first person perspective we will be giving people an inside perspective of the RCMP and possibly inspiring people to get involved.  My blog has already reached hundreds of thousands of people and with this tool I can better serve you, the public by giving you an amazing perspective of what I go through.

    Other Ways You Can Help

    If a monetary contribution is not in your budget don't worry you can still help the cause simply by sharing this page on any social media platform to help get the word out.

story:
My two brothers, Craig and Robert, are both visual artists in the Chicago area. Yesterday, 9/19/12, their apartment was robbed and they lost thousands of dollars of equipment and years worth of work. Craig currently works as a visual projectionist to create ground breaking visuals for a number of bands and venues in Chicago and without new equipment will be unable to work. Robert is a student in his final year at Columbia College, where he studies cinematography and video editing. On top of his studies he also TA's for 2 departments and recently received an unpaid internship to add an additional 16 hours a week to his already over-crammed schedule. Until he has new equipment it will be extremely difficult for him to keep up with his work and studies.

The computers, software, and equipment they need costs thousands of dollars and as a student and an artist funds will always be tight. I wanted to create this page in an attempt to raise any funds to help them get back on their feet.

story:
Summary

Cat Widdifield needs funds to train for Aerospace's Focus Mitt competition.  A yearly event which benefits a charity.  But this is not for glory alone, it's about giving back to community while having fun!  50% of donations will go to training and 50% will go to The East Harlem School!

Cat

An NYC based actress, dancer and performance artist, Cat has been an athlete since a young child and has maintained her priority for fitness the past year and a half at Aerospace Gym.

Aerospace

A gym without machines and few weights, it is a different kind of a workout, based on boxing and ballet training techniques.  And a lot of sweat!  Aerospace is not only a positively charged environment full of support and commraderie, but also a believer in giving back.  Which is where their yearly "CTBS" (Cut The Bull Sh*t) qualifying competition and the final Fight 4 Fitness event later in the year come in.

The Charity

Last year the East Harlem School was the beneficiary of the funds raised from the Fight 4 Fitness event.  An amazing school in Harlem for low-income middle school kids where they have an extended school day, year round school year, organic vegetarian lunches (!) and small class sizes.  This year's charity is sure to be just as awesome!

Not only a believer in fitness, Cat is deeply inspired to give back.  As an artist, such goals are sometimes lofty, but with this event she hopes she can contribute on a larger scale.

The Qualifier: CTBS

CTBS is the first round of competition to qualify for the main event- Fight 4 Fitness, held later in the year.

The date of CTBS is yet to be announced, but will be either the end of June or beginning of July.

After incidentals (Indiegogo and paypal take a cut), half of the contributions will go directly to The East Harlem School.  The other half will go toward training expenses including classes and private training sessions with Teddy Singleton (shown in the video above), Michael Olajide Jr. and Leila Fazel.

With these sessions costing $50-200 each... $1,100 will make enough sessions possible so Cat can learn the combination and get fast enough to really wail on those mitts!!

The Main Event: Fight 4 Fitness

CTBS will be open to members only, but if Cat wins her round, she'll qualify for Fight 4 Fitness, held later in the year... Which will be an affair not to be missed!

story:
Short Summary

I am a single mother of a 7yr old little boy. I have been working on a Psychology degree off and on since 1998 and am only 24hrs from graduating. I am a waitress because it is the most flexible job that allows me to pay my bills but I only scrape by. I need a new/used vehicle because I have had problems with it every summer for the last 4yrs and this year it finally blew the motor.

What We Need & What You Get

I need $30,000 to help support me threw the school year, pay tuition, and to buy a reliable vehicle to transport my son and I back and forth to school and work. I don't have anything to offer other than prayer and thanks. Even if I don't reach my goal, every little bit will help!! 

The Impact

When I finally graduate I want to help children and be a light to those in need. I have a huge heart and want to help everyone because I am a giver and a healer. I'm most passionate about children and look forward to being an advocate for those in need who have lived difficult lives because I was abused as a child myself and went threw foster home after foster home. I know what it's like to be taken from your parents and thrown into the system. With your contribution, you can help me help them!!

 

Other Ways You Can Help

If you are unable to give, help get the word out about my campaign! Please remember to use the Indiegogo share tools! Thank you so much for your support!!!
